IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative In its nearly 130 years of existence, the six-week intensive lecture- and laboratory-based Embryology course has played a pivotal role in training generations of Developmental Biologists. These individuals and their students, in turn, have been at the center stage of the biomedical sciences, as evidenced by the fact that developmental biologists have: 1) provided mechanistic understanding of fundamental biological processes (e.g., pattern formation, organogenesis, tissue polarity, epigenetics, aging, cell death); 2) discovered morphogens, microRNAs, and defined the major signaling pathways used by cells to communicate with each other; and 3) have provided the foundations for stem cell biology, tissue engineering and the context to understand human birth defects and disease. Developmental Biology continues to expand into new areas of research such as regeneration, stem cells, systems biology and growth control. By teaching the next generation of developmental biologists, the Embryology course aims to continue spurring and promoting a long-standing tradition of helping transform the biomedical sciences at large.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The UC Davis T32 in Comparative Lung Biology and Medicine prepares predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees during a critical and formative period in their research careers. The program aims to train the next generation of scientists through interdisciplinary research and coursework that address issues of direct relevance to the NHLBI mission. Our faculty and trainees foster a creative training and scientific milieu that facilitates their development into independent investigators in academic and government research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Overall - Narrative The UNC Breast Cancer SPORE submits its revised Year 30- 34 competitive renewal based upon substantial productivity and impact, particularly in the areas of disparities, genomics and translation as well as remarkable CEP success with recruitment of 17 new faculty 8 of whom are URIM and 12 of whom are women. Continued evolution, innovation and institutional commitment mark the 2 continuing and 2 new projects, all linked by the theme of immune analysis and therapeutic intervention in triple negative breast cancer. The renewal includes the 30th anniversary of the SPORE funded Carolina Breast Cancer Study and the launch of Phase 4 (3000 new cases, 50% Black, 50% younger), with biospecimens, social determinants of health and clinical data in this new era of breast cancer therapy.

PHR: Project 1: Carolina Breast Cancer Study (CBCS): Linking Tumor Biology to Social - Narrative Black women experience different breast cancer outcomes, with tumor biology, individual exposures, community-level, and structural determinants playing simultaneous roles; effective interventions must be integrative, addressing multi-level determinants in a holistic model. This proposal will evaluate tumor biology in context of a multi-level cells-to-society model to identify predictors of recurrence and survival and to identify novel interventions relevant to precision management of breast cancer.

PHR: Project 2: Determinants of Response and Resistance to DNA-Damaging Radiation Plus Immunotherapy Combinations in Triple Negative Breast Cancer – PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibition (ICI) combined with chemotherapy has transformed outcomes for patients with early-stage triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). Breast SPORE Project 2 will identify biomarkers that can inform the optimal use of new combinations of ICI with targeted radiation therapy and/or neoantigen vaccination in early stage TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project 3: Development of Novel Therapies and Biomarkers for TNBC Patients - Narrative In recent years new therapies targeting and activating the immune system to attack TNBC tumor cells have become a standard of care. This proposal seeks to improve the effectiveness of these immune system activating therapies by testing new drugs, and new combinations, that activate multiple components of the immune system. In addition, we have also determined that many TNBC have a unique tumor cell metabolism and here we are performing experiments to target this characteristic, and exploring combinations of these metabolism and immune drugs, to improve survival outcomes for patients with TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project 4: Activity of CAR T cell Therapy for Patients with Metastatic TNBC - Narrative We have had success in treating patients with hematological malignancies by using their own immune cells modified with a chimeric molecule that eliminates tumor cells but spare part of the immune B-lymphocytes. In this project we intend to conduct a Phase I clinical trial to test safety and antitumor activity of a novel chimeric antigen receptor in patients with triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). Furthermore, we will implement novel approaches to enhance our capacity to generate more functional T cells for adoptive T cells therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Diseases caused by protozoan and helminth parasites and arthropod-vectored infectious diseases continue to affect millions of people in resource-poor developing countries. The goal of the Parasitology and Vector Biology training program is to recruit and train the next generation of investigators whose focus is on understanding the basic mechanisms regulating host-parasite interactions as well as animal and human parasite transmission. These future parasitology and vector biology research leaders will contribute to global efforts to control these devastating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black Americans and other underrepresented groups (URGs) face a disproportionate cancer burden, yet racial and ethnic diversity in the biomedical workforce lags behind, including cancer research. The Cancer Undergraduate Research Education Program (CUREP) offers a distinctive ten-week program with hands-on cancer research, professional development, and year-long academic coaching to underrepresented students from a predominantly White university and two Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs), aiming to prepare them for careers in biomedical cancer research. Ultimately, CUREP's long-term goal is to enhance URGs' participation, representation, and impact in cancer research, thus significantly contributing to expanding diversity in the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall Program Project This Program Project involves a novel research effort with four interrelated Projects pertaining to types of organizations that deliver oncology care to understand features of care integration that are associated with higher-quality care delivery, more equitable care, and better outcomes for individuals with cancer. Defining and assessing how health systems, independent practices, post-acute care and hospice organizations, and specialty pharmacies integrate oncology care for patients with cancer and understanding how integration is associated with key outcomes of cancer treatment will inform policies and practices that can drive improvement in patient outcomes and patient, clinician, and staff experiences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Project 1 - Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Treated in Health Systems Vertically integrated health systems (i.e., organizations that own and operate both hospitals and medical practices) deliver an increasing proportion of cancer care, but the impact of such integration on patients with cancer remains unclear. This research, together with the other Projects that will use data from Project 1, will seek to characterize how vertical integration relates (if at all) to forms of integration that might have more direct benefits for patient care. By studying care integration in systems caring for patients with cancer, the proposed research will help policymakers and cancer care leaders and clinicians to identify and facilitate care integration that leads to higher quality, more efficient care for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Project 2 – Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Treated in Independent Practices To achieve the best possible outcomes for the large number of cancer patients treated in independent oncology practices, medical oncologists and practice staff must coordinate and integrate care with other clinicians and across a wide range of organizational boundaries and settings and over time. This project will generate new knowledge about the current state of care integration for cancer patients and about how cancer care can be better integrated to improve care for diverse sets of patients. The findings will inform practice leaders and policymakers about changes in organizations, markets, and policies to facilitate care integration that leads to higher quality and more efficient care for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Project 3 – Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Receiving Post- Acute Care and Hospice There has been substantial consolidation in post-acute care (i.e. skilled nursing facilities, inpatient rehabilitation facilities, and home health) and hospice settings, but the impact of such structural integration on patients with cancer remains unclear. This research, together with the other Projects will seek to characterize how structural integration relates (if at all) to other forms of integration that might have more direct benefits for patient care. By studying care integration for patients with cancer treated in post-acute care and hospice settings, the proposed research will help clinicians, cancer care leaders, and policymakers to identify and facilitate more meaningful care integration that leads to higher quality and more equitable care for patients with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Project 4 - Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Using Specialty Pharmacies This Project will examine the extent to which pharmacy services are integrated into practices (in the presence and absence of structural integration) and the role of specialty pharmacies in working with oncologists and patients to ensure that patients can access, initiate, and adhere to prescribed oral anticancer medications and supportive care medications. The findings will inform specialty pharmacy leaders, oncology practice leaders, and policy makers about strategies to facilitate care integration to improve care delivery for patients with cancer who may benefit from oral anticancer and supportive care medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is designed to establish an interdisciplinary training program in clinical pain research at Mass General Brigham (MGB) in Boston. The long-term goal is to expand the number, diversity, and collaborative network of clinical pain researchers, advancing our understanding of pain and our ability to effectively manage pain without opioid medications. This program offers interdisciplinary mentorship and training in clinical pain research by bringing together a diverse group of mentors from an array of backgrounds, including Psychology, Neurology, Neuroscience, Psychiatry, Epidemiology to promote innovative solutions for pain management and improve patient care by providing high-quality training to future leaders in clinical pain research.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has emphasized that investigations of host-microbe interaction, vaccination, pathogenesis, and host immune responses are critical topics for inquiry in science and medicine. This Training Program takes a holistic approach to train graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in innovative and interdisciplinary approaches to study host-microbial interaction. We combine rigorous courses, mentored laboratory-based research, and an array of training activities all within a Program focused on fostering diversity and the highest standards of ethics and research conduct.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Overall The goal of this Program Project Grant is to develop improved, curative therapies for patients with hematological malignancies focusing primarily on adoptive cell therapy, including hematopoietic cell transplantation. Individual Projects will explore the mechanisms of immune escape after adoptive T cell therapy in preclinical systems and rational design of innovative approaches to improve the targeting of tumors by engineered T cells. Clinical studies will analyze the parameters of CAR T cell success and failure in multiple myeloma and study next generation transgenic T cells targeting WT1 to prevent relapse of acute leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Disease relapse, graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)/cytokine release syndrome (CRS) and opportunistic infection are the major limitations of adoptive cell therapy (ACT), be it hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) or chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) or T cell receptor (TCR) transgenic T cell therapy. We plan to utilize unique, but well-established preclinical models to define the impact of these new clinical HCT platforms on the cellular and molecular pathways that mediate pathogen and leukemia specific immune responses. We will expand these studies to new fully murine CAR T cell models of B cell leukemia and multiple myeloma, focussing on identification of pathways of both toxicity and immune escape. In this manner we will facilitate the development of a new generation of cell therapies that will optimize patient outcomes within this P01.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple myeloma is diagnosed in 35000 Americans each year. New drugs and chimeric antigen receptor modified T cells (CAR-T) have improved response rates for myeloma and prolonged survival for many patients, but most patients eventually die of disease progression. This project will develop new tumor targeting receptors and methods for adoptive T cell therapies to overcome mechanisms by which myeloma cells resist eradication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a deadly disease, especially for patients who have aggressive disease and who cannot receive a hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT). In a new Phase I/II clinical trial we propose to infuse patients who are not HCT candidates with genetically engineered T cells modified to selectively attack AML cells and prevent the disease from coming back. We also propose to perform the pre-clinical laboratory work for adding positive signals to the gene-edited cells to help them better attack the leukemia in future clinical trials.

PHR: Narrative Recent advances in single-cell genomic and high content spatial analysis technologies have shed new light on organ and tissue composition, delineating complex tissues and identifying new cell types. However, the data being generated by these approaches are becoming increasingly complex and difficult to fully analyze. The High Dimensional Cellular and Spatial Analysis Core (HDCSAC – Core C) will facilitate the efficient use of single-cell sequencing, high-dimensional tissue imaging, and support integrated high-dimensional data analysis for unbiased discovery and novel hypothesis generation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Long-Term Follow-Up Unit (LTFU, Core D) supports the Program by providing extended data collection and biospecimen acquisition services to the Projects. Through a combination of chart review, annual surveys and active contact with participants and providers, Core D is responsible for ensuring that protocol requirements beyond the acute treatment phase (generally 2-3 months) are performed and research samples are collected. Core D also interacts closely with Core B, which is responsible for early data collection and all data analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative A subgroup of brain cancers known collectively as “gliomas” are the most common brain tumor of children and a major cause of cancer-related death in young adults. Conventional therapeutics for these cancers (surgery, chemotherapy, radiation) have significant side effects on growing children and fail completely on the most aggressive gliomas. The goal of this research program is to develop non-toxic (and curative) treatments for gliomas that arise in children and young adult with glioma by developing a new generation of medicines that specifically target tumors while sparing healthy cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric low-grade gliomas are the most common brain tumors of childhood and can cause devastating and life-long quality of life problems. In this study, we will combine advanced cancer cell analysis techniques and medical imaging-based artificial intelligence to improve targeted therapies, tumor monitoring, and prediction of recurrence in children with low-grade gliomas. The research will result in knowledge and tools that help us design better and safer therapies and determine how (and when) to best use those therapies in children with low-grade gliomas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Diffuse midline gliomas (DMG) are the most common malignant brain tumors of children. Radiotherapy is the only treatment known to prolong patient survival but DMGs inevitably recur following radiotherapy and are uniformly fatal. The goal of the work proposed here is to test a class of drugs that exploit a metabolic vulnerability of DMGs and have potential to greatly enhance the clinical outlook for children with these tumors. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in genes encoding isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) enzymes define subtypes of lower grade glioma in adults and can be targeted with mutant IDH inhibitor drugs, which delay the progression of these tumors. To combat resistance to mutant IDH inhibitor drugs, we propose to test two treatment strategies designed by our group to exploit vulnerabilities in glioma cells that are caused by IDH mutations. We will test these strategies in preclinical brain tumor models and in patients with IDH-mutant gliomas that do not respond to mutant IDH inhibitor drugs, thereby contributing to the development of new treatment options for this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Core Narrative This Specialized Program of Research Excellence (SPORE) proposal is focused gliomas - a subtype of brain cancer that has heavy impact on life expectancy and quality of life children and young adults. Recent developments in statistical methodology for cancer research combined with access to low-cost, fast computing have resulted in higher standards in the definition of acceptable scientific evidence. Against this backdrop, the mission of this Biostatistics Core is to work scientists and clinicians on this SPORE ensure statistical integrity in the design of their experiments and enhance rigor and reproducibility in the interpretation of their data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative (Overall) Using powerful genetic, genomic, epigenomic and statistical techniques, we will support studies of the genetic basis of traits that have well-established relevance to substance use disorders. We expect that this National Center of Excellence will transform our understanding of substance use disorders and lead to the identification of specific genes, pathways and therapeutic targets. This center will enhance our understanding of genetic susceptibility to substance use disorders in humans and may identify new opportunities to treat psychiatric disorders including, but not necessarily limited to, substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study addresses a worldwide public health emergency, antimicrobial resistant bacterial infections and continued antibiotic effectiveness. This study disseminates a successful de-implementation strategy for excessive antibiotic use, a problem-solving strategy to facilitate integration of evidence-based guidelines to eliminate unnecessary post-operative antibiotic prophylaxis at 20 children’s hospitals. Results from this study will add to the evidence of the importance of facilitation as an important de-implementation strategy to eliminate low value and harmful healthcare practices.

PROJECT_TITLE: Dissemination of a Facilitation Strategy to Deimplement Unnecessary Post-Operative Antibiotics at Children's Hospitals

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to systematically investigate epigenomic regulation in the reward circuitry following cocaine self-administration, employing a range of single-cell multi-omics and spatial genomics methods. Additionally, by utilizing a diverse panel of mouse strains, the study aims to discern how various genetic backgrounds influence these molecular alterations, to shed light on the complex interplay between genetics and epigenetics in regulating gene expression that modulates cocaine self-administration behavior. The ultimate goal is to construct comprehensive gene regulatory networks that encapsulate this interplay, thereby advancing our understanding and providing avenues for targeted therapeutic strategies to combat cocaine addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL PROGRAM NARRATIVE: Mucus-degrading intestinal bacteria and toxicities of hematopoietic cell transplantation  Some of the normal bacteria that live within our intestines can naturally break down mucus, which protects the lining of the intestinal tract. We have recently found that these bacteria play an important role in producing some of the most harmful toxicities that can affect patients undergoing a specialized medical treatment called allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation. We have assembled a team of physician- scientists and specialized experts on these specific bacteria to identify new ways to protect the intestinal mucus from these bacteria, with a goal of making allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation a safer procedure for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Work from our group suggests that functional declines in aging blood-forming hematopoietic stem cells (HSC) that affect their epigenetic status and signals from the aging niche that alter the transcriptional milieu or promote expansion of HSC compartments have an impactful role in myeloid disease progression by promoting clonal expansion of mutated (pre-leukemic) HSCs and emergence of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). The goal of our program is to apply cutting edge genetic tools and single cell technology to integrate studies of clonal mutational evolution and niche components in patients and mouse models, to establish the mechanisms through which the aging marrow supports the outgrowth of AML initiating clones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In addition to genetic driver mutations, activation of emergency myelopoiesis (EM) pathways contributes to leukemia development. However, our understanding of the role of EM pathway engagement in leukemia is still incomplete, which represents a major roadblock in the translation of our extensive knowledge of this fundamental process of demand-adapted myeloid cell amplification into treatments for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients. The overall goal of this project is to identify key regulatory nodes that could be exploited to disrupt EM pathway activation and prevent leukemia progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project 2: Microenvironmental and inflammatory mechanisms in MDM4-driven AML pathogenesis. Project Leader: Ulrich Steidl Project Narrative We hypothesize that MDM4 overexpression acts in ARCH/MDS-to-AML progression in the context of microenvironmental changes and selection pressures that are frequently encountered during aging and inflammatory stress. Our studies will provide novel mechanistic insights into combinatorial cell-intrinsic/extrinsic preleukemic to AML progression as well as a preclinical proof- of-concept for the design of preventative clinical trials in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3 NARRATIVE We have identified a stroma cell-triggered transcriptional event driving MDS to AML transformation. We will delineate the mechanism of this pathway in AML evolution and clonal dynamics. These studies will identify transcriptional and clonal events that are significant contributors to AML transformation, define the role of the stroma in their regulation and can lead to new therapeutic approaches that target stroma-elicited signals to prevent or treat AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Core B: NARRATIVE The Computational Genomics Core will provide a centralized structure to collect, analyze and integrate data from all three projects. Simultaneous genomic, transcriptomic and proteomic mapping of bone marrow (BM) tissue will provide a unique opportunity to visualize the numerous cell types, their states and pathway specific expression patterns in a spatially resolved manner. The generated datasets will be mined to chart the rewiring of both cell states in the BM niche and their aberrant signaling during AML transformation. The Core will apply methods for processing and analysis of single-cell RNA sequencing data, inference and visualization of AML clonal evolution, reconstruction of transcriptional regulatory networks and analysis of transcriptional targets, and integration of data across technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 3 - PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project will develop novel regimens by which the current standard of care (SOC) therapy for hepatocellular cancer (HCC) can be enhanced, and extended to patients who have progressed following first- line Immune Checkpoint Blockade (ICB) therapies. We will do this both by using oncolytic viruses expressing tumor antigens associated with HCC (TAAHCC) to direct populations of highly activated effector T cells into the tumor microenvironment (whose anti-tumor cytotoxic activity can be further enhanced by immune checkpoint blocking molecules, such as anti-PD-L1) and by using our novel technology in which oncolytic viruses loaded onto CAR T cells targeting the TAAHCC GPC3 can be used as potent immunological adjuvants to improve the efficacy of CAR T cell therapy against HCC. Finally, as a prelude to testing clinical efficacy, we will test the safety of a completely novel VSV platform as a means of delivering TAAHCC-targeted viro-immunotherapy in a Phase I clinical study of VSV-CSDE1-GPC3 as therapy in patients with advanced HCC who have received SOC bevacizumab/atezolizumab.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: BIOSPECIMEN AND PATHOLOGY CORE C – PROJECT NARRATIVE This Core obtains research permission from cancer patients and appropriate normal or control individuals, collects tissues and blood samples, and links the specimens with information about the patient, including their age and gender, risk factors for cancer, response to treatment, and survival. The samples are then made available for the SPORE projects and other investigators studying liver and biliary cancers, to facilitate our understanding of the biological basis of cancer, prevent cancer, and develop new treatments for cancer. Mayo Clinic has one of the world’s largest specimen collections for liver and biliary cancers. We will continue to develop this important resource by expanding our extensive network of national and international collaborators, particularly focusing on specimens from patients living in diverse and underserved communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (OVERALL) New targeted cancer drugs have transformed care for patients, but they can lead to heart disease as an unintended consequence for some patients. This Program Project uses a synergistic, multi-disciplinary approach using mouse- and cell-based models to understand how heart-related side effects occur and to create a new platform for testing future therapeutics. This ultimately has critical implications for precision medicine to better manage cancer patients who could be susceptible to side effects resulting from cancer therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Damaged lysosomes and dysfunctional stress granules have become increasingly associated with a wide range of human diseases and have important clinical applications. Pioneering research I conducted before achieving an independent faculty position was the first to demonstrate that lysosomal damage triggers stress granule formation. The proposed research will elevate these findings by providing insight into the relationship between lysosomal damage and stress granule formation, thereby offering the potential to promote significant advancements in therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: NARRATIVE The WISDOM Study, opened in 2016, is the first large clinical trial of a new, personalized approach to breast cancer screening in which women receive individualized screening recommendations based on their personal risk for breast cancer. While our initial efforts were focused on showing that personalized screening was as safe, less morbid, preferred and more likely to result in uptake of preventive strategies in comparison to annual screening, we will now focus on using advances in polygenic risk models and mammographic AI to improve our ability to predict risk for developing fast or slow growing breast cancer subtypes, and tailoring screening and prevention strategies accordingly. Four closely integrated projects will enable us to work toward the goal of a personalized breast cancer screening program that is more effective and efficient, and more likely to help find serious breast cancers early, when they are more likely to be treated successfully, and decrease the incidence of slow growing cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 1: NARRATIVE Our ongoing WISDOM clinical trial is among the first attempts to try a new approach to breast cancer screening in which each woman receives a personalized screening and prevention recommendation based on her individual risk of breast cancer. Since we began in 2016, we have learned how to better estimate a woman’s breast cancer risk and we can now begin to determine whether a woman is at risk for fast-growing cancers or slow-growing cancers. In this research project, we will investigate if more intense screening for women who are high-risk for fast-growing cancers will help detect them earlier when they are more treatable, while also offering women who are at high risk of slow-growing cancers an opportunity to begin risk-reducing therapy that has already proven to be effective for breast cancer prevention, and reduce the burden of screening for average risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT 4: NARRATIVE Mammography screening currently misses many fast-growing breast cancers. The goal of Project 4 is to use a model to define the group of women at risk for fast growing tumors who would benefit from more intensive screening for breast cancer and to define the group of women at risk for the slow growing tumors who would benefit from medicines to prevent breast cancer. The ultimate goal is to decrease death from breast cancer in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Due to the exponential rise in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), a cancer that is refractory to many treatment options, is rapidly becoming a leading cause of cancer mortality. We hypothesize that HCC initiation and malignant progression is triggered by altered lipid/cholesterol metabolism, with consequent oxidative and endoplasmic reticulum stress, activation of the unfolded protein response, that accentuate mitochondrial dysfunction leading to hepatocyte senescence allowing accumulation of genetic mutations that allow outgrowth of transformed hepatocytes. This P01 will investigate interacting pathogenic pathways, operating in different cellular compartments- cytosol, nucleus, ER, and mitochondria- that generate a vicious downward spiral responsible for NASH to HCC progression, paving the way for developing novel diagnostics and therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – CORE A: ADMINISTRATIVE The Administrative Core A will provide necessary management to this Program Project by serving as the nexus for communication and coordination of all joint activities between individual Projects, Cores, the Internal and External Advisory Boards and the NCI. The Program seeks to address NCI public health goals by addressing an unmet need in HCC research, which will be supported by Core A by disseminating research results to the health care community. With Core 2, Core A will oversee maintenance of the website and dissemination of results including data exchange. Core A with the Steering Committee will be responsible for evaluating productivity, coordinating efforts, allocating resources, and resolving any conflicts that arise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - PROJECT 1 Project 1 will study the role of the recently discovered NRF2-FBP1 crossregulatory interactions in the progression from NASH-associated hepatocyte senescence to frank hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). We will investigate the mechanisms by which stressed senescent hepatocytes downregulate FBP1 and TP53 to activate NRF2 and gain malignant potential and whether this switch directly occurs within the senescent cell, as well as the role of hepatocyte DNA damage in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE -PROJECT 2 The incidence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) will continue to rise due to the global increase in obesity and the rapid change in etiology toward metabolic drivers. Project 2 focuses on the contribution of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the unfolded protein response (UPR) transducer ATF6, which releases a soluble active transcription factor (ATF6p50). We hypothesize that chronic and aberrant ATF6 activation promotes non- alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)-driven HCC through ER stress, UPR induction, and a metabolic shift to alter cholesterol/bile acid metabolism favoring cancer development and will test the targeted inhibition of ATF6 as a therapeutic strategy for HCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 3 Overfeeding diet induced NASH has emerged as a major cause of hepatocellular carcinoma. Project 3 focuses on the contribution of two mitochondria proteins, SAB and StARD1, which increase in NASH and further increase in HCC and alter mitochondria function. Project 3 will integrate the metabolic alterations elucidated in Projects 1 and 2 with the role of the mitochondria alterations seen with increased expression of SAB and StARD1 in HCC and will lead to novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: NARRATIVE – CORE 1 Fatty liver disease is a frequent precursor to hepatocellular carcinoma. The primary hypothesis of this Program Project Grant is that stress-altered metabolism in the fatty liver leads to further dysfunction in metabolism which contributes to disease progression. The Metabolomics Core will use methods of metabolite quantification and stable-isotope tracing to support Research Projects in an extensive analysis of liver and tumor metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We are submitting a renewal for our consortium of Baylor College of Medicine located in Houston and Children’s National Hospital located in Washington DC as a BMT CTN core center. Both centers serve diverse catchment areas that have allowed us to recruit diverse subjects to BMT CTN multicenter studies. We propose a novel and highly feasible protocol to evaluate starch as a microbiome modulating agent that may reduce the risk of graft versus host disease which remains a major transplant complication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Big data, along with the associated computational and statistical tools, are transforming cancer research and cancer care in almost all aspects. Built on our previous big data training courses for general biomedical researchers and current big data training courses tailored for cancer researchers, this renewal project aims to help cancer researchers develop essential analytical skills to extract knowledge from big data and find better ways to understand, diagnose, and treat cancer. In addition, we will establish a big data community among cancer researchers to foster collaboration and knowledge sharing to advance cancer research endeavors.

PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Hawai‘i Cancer Center (UHCC) is dedicated to pioneering cancer research tailored to the distinct ethnic and cultural characteristics of Hawai‘i and the Pacific. Through a blend of innovative research, clinical trials, and robust community outreach and engagement, UHCC prioritizes underserved groups like Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders. Supported by many stakeholders, including State and Federal sponsors, our mission is to transform cancer care, emphasizing diversity, equity, and inclusion, ensuring Hawai‘i and the Pacific lead in globally impactful cancer discoveries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a disease of the brain that has frustrated patients, clinicians, and caregivers alike, given the lack of effective treatments and a poor understanding of the complex reasons that cause the variety of syndromic manifestations of the disease. This 3D Aging & Alzheimer Brain Program is a collaborative effort to generate state-of-the-art information at the microscopic level to capture the complexity of the human brain and transform our perspective of the significant variation in the severity of cognitive dysfunction and presentation of AD across individuals. The resources we generate with this Program will help to determine the combinations of genes, cell types, pathologies, and molecular signals in the context of the three-dimensional environment that are most relevant for AD, greatly accelerating the development of new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Though fewer than 20% of older adults perform the recommended amount of resistance training, systematic reviews show that it has a strong effect on improving strength and physical function. While briefer resistance training sessions, which older adults prefer, have been proven to increase strength, no Phase 2 efficacy studies have been conducted to understand their impact on improving physical function, including mobility. If this trial shows that a brief, daily resistance training program improves lower extremity performance and mobility, this study may alter guidelines for resistance training and, by making programs shorter, potentially improve their uptake by older adults and, in doing so, improve the public’s health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative We propose to use ultrasound to activate genes and epigenetics in live cells. We will engineer molecular sensors into T cells along with genetic transducing modules, and use ultrasound to induce CAR expression for therapeutic actions against solid tumors. We will also develop technology and protocols for ultrasound controllable genetic and epigenetic regulations in treating diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: This project will build capacity for participatory science among the Maine tribes in order to facilitate a balance between food and water sovereignty and environmental contamination. The incorporation of traditional ecological Knowledge (TEK) into exposure and risk assessment models will allow community members to make more realistic and informed evaluation of risks that allow a balance between traditional lifestyles and contaminant exposures. The ultimate goal is to provide the foundations for a larger program that will serve the environmental health needs of Maine’s Tribal communities while respecting their sovereignty over traditional foods and waterways.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neglect dyslexia, a reading impairment associated with post-stroke spatial neglect, presents a major barrier to regaining functional independence in activities of daily living, work, and leisure participation. The goal of the proposed research is to characterize the mediative role that gaze may have in neglect dyslexic errors. Biometric, behavioral, and neuroimaging data collected will inform basic cognitive neuroscience research on the neural networks that support spatial cognition, and applied neurorehabilitation research aimed at improving the detection and classification of visuospatial deficits such as neglect dyslexia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of our proposed study is to elucidate how mutations in the heat shock protein DNAJC7 cause ALS/FTD, an untreatable and devastating neurodegenerative disease. We will use induced pluripotent stem cell- derived neurons in combination with quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics to elucidate the role of DNAJC7 in human neurons and determine how its dysfunction leads to their dysfunction.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: At least one in three Veterans has high levels of triglycerides that raises their risk of heart disease. A high fat meal raises triglyceride levels with the greatest rise about four hours after the meal. During this peak time, the risk of inflammation and hardening of the arteries also increases. Although fats are created differently, we don’t understand how each of these fats behave after a high fat meal. This study will examine these fats separately by having Veterans with high triglycerides drink a “milkshake” containing purified coconut oil, salmon oil, or sunflower oil to better understand how these fats are processed; and whether one may be preferred due to a lower rise in triglycerides, inflammation, and other markers of heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE. Hispanics/Latinos show higher prevalence and incidence of AD compared to non-Hispanic Whites but their representation in genetic studies remains insufficient to provide statistical significance, especially for rare variant discovery. In this study we will generate whole genome sequencing data (WGS) on N=2,000 newly-recruited Peruvian and Bolivian individuals (with extensive clinical, cognitive assessment and AD-biomarkers panel) and N=4,000 HL from US (part of our recently funded study “Recruitment and Retention for Alzheimer's Disease Diversity Genetic Cohorts in the ADSP” U19AG074865). These new cohorts will increase representation of HL in AD genetic studies, particularly for samples with substantial Native American ancestry that are currently underrepresented compared to other admixed samples with predominant African ancestry (e.g., African Americans, Caribbean Hispanics).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: SCI-ENCE Project Narrative The SCI-ENCE Program will increase interest in science and STEAM careers by creating and implementing an elementary and middle/intermediate school science curriculum based on storyboards, or illustrated descriptions of the science pathways that local individuals have taken to pursue science careers. These storyboard pathways are scattered with age-appropriate and NGSS aligned games, activities and experiments for students to do during each year of school from grades 2 to 8. Science fascination, career interest, confidence, engagement and literacy will be increased, as will teacher confidence in teaching science as a result of this program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Seasonal influenza is estimated to result in 9-45 million cases of illness, 140,000-810,000 hospitalizations and 12,000-61,000 deaths in the US annually, especially in people at high risk; a pandemic influenza outbreak could account for >30 million deaths worldwide within the first 6 months and cost $600B. As current influenza vaccines target elements on the surface of the virus that are highly prone to mutations, they require annual updates, their effectiveness may be as low as 10-20% when circulating viruses do not match the vaccine viruses and are expected to provide very limited protection against emerging pandemic strains. Osivax has developed a vaccine that recognizes an internal influenza target, which is highly conserved across all influenza strains. In this grant we propose to test how broadly effective this vaccine can be in a monkey model that best mimics the human condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major goal in biomedicine is to modulate a protease solely on its disease-related substrates. To achieve this rare level of selectivity, this proposal aims to combine a novel high-throughput selection platform with machine learning tools to accelerate the discovery of substrate-selective protease modulators and decipher their binding mechanisms. Given that proteases and other post-translational modification enzymes are implicated in a vast number of diseases, including cancer, neurodegeneration, infectious and autoimmune diseases, substrate- selective modulators could have a profound impact on how we target and study enzymes with multiple substrates.

PHR: Project Narrative This research project will deliver innovative computational tools to identify genes and regulatory elements responsible for specific organismal traits. These tools will enable researchers around the world to assign functional elements to phenotypes of importance to human health and disease, including longevity, neurological function, metabolism, and congenital diseases of development. These genetic inferences will also provide new directions for the research community to pursue a fundamental understanding of biological systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulated RNA biology figures prominently in many neurodegenerative diseases for which there are currently poor treatment options, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The proposed research is significant because it will contribute a set of transformative tools for study of RNA-governed biology in ALS and related neurodegenerative diseases. If successful, our approach would open new potential therapeutic and diagnostic avenues for treating neurodegenerative diseases such as ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Women with criminal records have alarmingly high rates of behavioral health concerns and a majority experience forms of interpersonal violence victimization, yet women commonly do not receive needed behavioral health treatment and supportive services. This proposed mixed-methods study builds upon existing empirical work and a theoretically driven framework of help-attainment to examine how behavioral health, interpersonal victimization, and collateral consequences shape help-seeking and help-attainment processes for treatment and services among adult women with criminal records. The findings will identify novel facilitators to help-attainment and intervention directions to improve the behavioral health and wellbeing of women with criminal records.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Falls in the elderly most often result from frailty, which is caused by muscle weakness, impaired balance, and unstable walking. Studies in rodents have shown that age-induced changes that lead to frailty are preceded by structural and functional changes at the neurotransmitter release site within the neuromuscular junction. This proposal aims to utilize several new approaches to understand how aging alters neuromuscular synapses at an individual transmitter release site level.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The developing neural tube is vulnerable to changes in maternal metabolism, yet how maternal- fetal nutrient exchange is regulated in the visceral yolk sac, the functional equivalent of the placenta during neural tube closure, is not well understood. When the neural tube does not develop properly, the results are catastrophic for human survival and quality of life. The proposed project will identify how the yolk sac regulates maternal-fetal nutrient exchange and development of the neural tube.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is increasing awareness that psychosocial factors contribute to the persistent racial/ethnic and socioeconomic disparities in pediatric asthma care and health outcomes despite the existing and highly effective NIH national guidelines for standardized care. Maternal depression is associated with poor pediatric asthma outcomes, and there is a need to examine if treating it, particularly when integrated within the context of ongoing pediatric asthma care, improves subsequent asthma management and health outcomes for under- resourced, urban, Black children. The proposed study fills this gap by studying the integration of Enhanced Brief Interpersonal Psychotherapy (a promising depression treatment for depression for mothers who are under-resourced) into ongoing community-based asthma care and evaluating its feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy on reducing maternal depression and child asthma morbidity and increasing health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: The prevalence of asthma among American Indian (AI) children is higher (8.2% as compared to 6.4%) than in non-Hispanic White children, and over 50% of children in the U.S. struggle with uncontrolled asthmatic disease and they also suffer from higher rates of upper and lower respiratory infections as it is sadly demonstrated by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Very little information is available on how Native children are affected by specific viral infection burden and how these immunological factors may be influenced by social and environmental factors (SEF) including adverse childhood events (ACEs), tobacco smoke, and everyday life stressors that may alter immunological state. This community-based study of 550 Tribal children from both urban and rural Reservation areas of South Dakota will target both approaches in order to support culturally appropriate asthma prevention strategies as well as the appropriate local, Tribally-centered family support system in place.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sociodemographic disparities in physical function and use of rehabilitation following total joint arthroplasty have been established, but there is little to no available research regarding approaches to reduce disparities. In the proposed K23 research, we will develop and test implementation of novel post-arthroplasty rehabilitation care pathways designed to maximize function and reduce race and insurance/income disparities in outcomes. Findings from this project will lead to improved quality of rehabilitation and improved equity in outcomes following hip and knee arthroplasty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to understand pathogenic mechanisms underlying a rare neurodegenerative disorder caused by mutations of SNX13, which encodes a sorting nexin (SNX) protein, that robs children of their motor and cognitive skills. My research will define how this protein and associated biological processes are involved in preserving neuronal function and survival, which could be used to inform the development of more targeted therapeutics for patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Sudden and serious injury is a top cause of death in the United States. PHR: Innate immune manipulation holds enormous promise for reducing the severity of infections and other  human diseases. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This proposal develops a nanoplasmonic-based single-cell imaging technology that enables probing the spatiotemporal profile of protein molecules secreted by individual immune cells. Implementing this technology in studying cellular cytokine secretion behaviors is relevant to the public health because it provides scientific insight into inflammation-related immunology and cell biology governing immune dysregulations and cancer diseases. The technology can be a versatile tool for cellular paracrine/autocrine signaling, cellular immunophenotyping coupled with protein expression profiling, gene expression analysis, molecular-level analysis of infectious diseases, and human leukocyte antigen (HLA) testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a devastating stroke sub-type with no proven therapy. Based on strong supportive evidence and recent clinical trials, CN-105, a 5-amino acid peptide derived from the receptor binding surface of the apolipoprotein E (apoE), appears to be poised for translation as an acute ICH therapeutic. This project will build on prior our Phase 1 STTR by coupling use of blood proteins and brain imaging to improve patient selection for planning an Phase 3 clinical trial of CN-105 in acute ICH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will advance our understanding of how the brain changes when someone uses a brain-computer interface for many days, and how brain changes are influenced by the device. Understanding how devices influence the brain is an important step towards building engineering tools that can assure brain-computer interface therapies provide robust performance over time. The outcomes of this proposal have the potential to enable next-generation brain-computer interfaces that can reliably restore movement to paralyzed people for long periods of time across varied tasks.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCY STATEMENT) Chinese immigrants suffer a disproportionately high type 2 diabetes (T2D) burden and have poor health outcomes. They face numerous social determinants barriers to accessing evidence-based diabetes programs, including high rates of poverty and limited English proficiency (LEP), and lack of insurance. This project will provide important evidence on scalable strategies to enhance the accessibility of evidence-based diabetes programs in LEP Chinese immigrants with T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The ability of the nervous system to store new information and adapt to new circumstances depends on the plasticity and remodeling of synapses – the fundamental points of communication between nerve cells. Our project is aimed at understanding how the neuron and its partner cell are able to respond to repeated signals by orchestrating a converging set of mechanisms that allow synapse remodeling by tuning the expression of conserved genes that build the underlying structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Hypoxemia triggers cerebrovascular lesions in the white matter area of the brain associated with cognitive challenges that affect more than half of the patients with sickle cell disease by their adulthood. This project seeks to determine that microvascular hypoxemia induces hypoxia inducible factor-1a which in turn promotes the inhibition of frataxin causing activation of astrocytes, the cells that connect microvessels with the neurons, resulting increased calcium accumulation, neuroaxonal damage and cognitive dysfunction. This project will identify a novel mechanistic pathway that can be targeted for future therapeutics improving cognitive function in SCD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it aims to reconceptualize dexterity and identify critical factors in rehabilitation of hand dexterity among stroke survivors by characterizing essential behavioral components and their neuroanatomical substrates, from which a neural mechanistic concept can be built. Upon successful completion, a new model of hand dexterity and a sound rationale for developing effective therapeutic interventions will emerge, which will facilitate reacquisition of dexterity and optimization of hand function recovery. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to the application of the scientific and clinical knowledge gained from this project to enhance health and reduce disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New drugs to treat malaria are urgently needed; this project is a Phase II SBIR drug discovery collaboration between Reactive Biosciences and UCSF to discover and develop new antimalarial medicines. This program will include the lead optimization of promising boron-containing antimalarials identified in Phase I, evaluation of drug-like properties of these compounds, mechanism of action studies, profiling of activity in animal models, and safety. Ultimately, these studies will lead to the identification of a candidate compound for development as a new drug to treat and prevent malaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We will develop tools for interactome analysis in microbial communities with the long-run goal of defining  principles behind community behavior and responses to invasion. This project will generate a multi-omics  map of the THOR community's response to invasion and concepts that support inference of pathways  underlying emergent phenotypes. This will establish the foundation for reasoning about community  interactions, a prerequisite for engineering microbial systems for human and environmental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Black Americans are disproportionately impacted by firearm violence. The goal of the proposed project is to determine how residential segregation, vacant and abandoned properties, neighborhood walkability, and green space access combine in unique ways to create neighborhood profiles that differentially expose Black Americans to gun violence. This effort will inform policy and prevention strategies that more effectively reduce Black Americans’ firearm violence exposure by targeting the unique patterns of place-based features defining those neighborhoods conferring the greatest exposure risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We discovered that genetically modified cytomegalovirus (CMV) can elicit T cells that recognize non-self peptides presented by Major Histocompatibility-E (MHC-E) molecules, including peptides derived from foreign antigens inserted into CMV, and that these T cells protect against simian immunodeficiency virus suggesting that prophylactic HIV vaccines that elicit MHC-E-restricted T cells might similarly achieve protection. While peptide presentation by classical MHC-I molecules is well understood, very little is known about how MHC-E presents non-self peptides because MHC-E generally presents a self-peptide contained within classical MHC-I proteins to natural killer cells as a self-protective mechanism and to better understand why CMV is the only known vaccine platform capable of eliciting MHC-E-restricted CD8+ T cell responses to any antigen, we will study the molecular antigen-presenting mechanisms that enable CMV to elicit these responses and how these T cells recognize HIV-infected cells. 1

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses the interdisciplinary care and self-advocacy needs of youth with variations in sex traits (VST), also known as differences of sex development or Intersex. By purposively recruiting a diverse sample of youth and emerging adults with VST in a community participatory process, and developing, calibrating, and validating a self-advocacy tool for youth with VST, this psychometric initiative will provide young people greater voice in their interdisciplinary VST care—care which often involves irreversible medical decision-making during childhood and adolescence with life-long ramifications for gender-related well-being, sexual and urological function, and psychosocial health. The resulting measure will also identify and characterize VST health-related distress to inform attuned and personalized interdisciplinary clinical care practices, and will examine VST intragroup disparities to inform more equitable interdisciplinary care models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Endometriosis is a disease that promotes infertility and pain in reproductive-aged women and it remains unclear why only some women develop endometriosis. We propose that underlying genetics contribute to the pathophysiology of endometriosis. We have made for the first time, new model systems including induced pluripotent stem cells from women with endometriosis as well as a new microfluidic device in order to study the pathogenesis of endometriosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through continued practice, skilled behaviors can become rote and maintained throughout life with seemingly minimal effort. Nonetheless, disruptions to skilled behaviors can be early indicators or diagnostic of neurodegenerative diseases. The goal of this research program is to identify the cellular and synaptic mechanisms for maintaining skilled behaviors and tracking how the brain changes as previously learned behaviors begin to decrystallize.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteriophage resistance imposes severe fitness defects on bacteria. Using enterococci which are intestinal commensals and established opportunistic pathogens, we will study phage resistance in these bacteria that leads to heightened antibiotic sensitivity and intestinal colonization defects. With this knowledge we can develop phages as precision therapeutics that target drug resistant enterococci that reside in the intestine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fully utilizing the genetic, clinical and survey data in the All of Us program, we will develop the risk modeling pipeline with integrated genetic-clinical-social risk factors and composite onset-timing outcomes. We will further develop privacy preserving external validation and transfer learning strategy to facilitate demonstration and application of All of Us modeling. Our methods will be showcased in risk modeling for rheumatoid arthritis and cancer cardiotoxicity with validation on external healthcare data at Mass-General-Brigham and M Health Fairview.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is the development of a non-invasively extending distal femur replacement for children and adolescents undergoing bone tumor resection for maintaining limb length equality. Each year in the US there are 200-250 malignant bone tumor diagnoses in the distal femurs of patients 15 years and younger. Our device is simple, robust, MRI compatible, can be extended more gradually at home, has far more extension capability and is designed for a reduced complication rate when compared to its sole US competitor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inhibition of macrophages is an essential step in resolving acute inflammation. A cellular metabolite known as itaconate was shown to be the major inhibitor of macrophage activation but the exact mechanism by which itaconate exerts this function remains unclear. Here, we will test if a newfound target of itaconate, a protein called SHP-1, is responsible for itaconate inhibition of macrophage activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Foxes bred for tameness, unlike their wild ancestors, respond in a positive, friendly manner towards humans, similar to domesticated dogs, who, unlike their wolf ancestors, are friendly to people. This project studies the genetics of these inherited fox behaviors in order to understand the causes and mechanisms involved and to potentially gain broader insight into a range of human neurological disorders that are characterized by impaired social reciprocity or by anxiety-related and/or aggressive behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  RNA editing of transposable elements within cellular RNAs by the ADAR1 enzyme helps the cell distinguish between self and non-self RNAs. The Z-RNA binding domain of ADAR1 plays a role in that process, which remains uncharacterized. Our goal is to structurally, dynamically and geographically (across transcriptomes) characterize the formation of Z-RNA and their recognition by ADAR1, with repercussions on better understanding cancer and certain auto- immune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This will be the first intergenerational study to assess racial disparities in the influence of parental marijuana use on youth marijuana and other substance drug use in African Americans and Hispanics/Latinos, two NIH- designated health disparity populations. We will further assess the effects of marijuana legalization and other determinants on intergenerational drug use behaviors by racial and ethnic groups. This mixed-methods sequential explanatory study will be pursued by integrating analyses of intergenerational and longitudinal surveys and semi-structured interviews

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative-Relevance of research to public health. Nursing homes (NHs) continue to be a critical component of the U.S. system of post-acute and long-term care for people with multiple chronic conditions (MCCs), Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), serious illness, and functional impairment, yet numerous challenges remain to achieving consistent quality care that optimizes resident outcomes. There is widespread, long standing consensus that NHs are a challenging setting for research. The NEXT STEPs (Nursing Home EXplanatory Clinical Trials: Supporting Transformation by Enhancing Partnerships) Network creates a national infrastructure that will address systemic barriers to conducting research in NHs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed studies will investigate the association of chronic periodontitis with the hallmark pathologic features of Alzheimer’s Disease in individuals with Down Syndrome. More specifically, we will address the role of a new class of dihydroceramide lipids, named phosphoglycerol dihydroceramide (PGDHC), produced by the key periodontal pathogen Porphyromonas gingivalis in sex-associated pathogenic amyloidogenesis of amyloid precursor protein using mouse models of Down syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of the Texas Doctoral Bridge Program, a formal partnership between Hispanic Serving Institutions Texas State University (master's degree granting institution) and the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio (UTHSA) (Ph.D. granting institution), is to increase the number of students from historically marginalized groups (HMGs) who complete doctoral studies in the biomedical sciences. There is an urgent need to strengthen and diversify the biomedical research workforce to address disparities linked to race/ethnicity and socio-economic status amongst other factors. Through a series of programmatic activities involving rigorous didactic preparation and integrated research training, M.S. students from HMGs at Texas State will be bridged into competitive Ph.D. programs at UTHSA or other first-rate biomedical institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE  Graduate trainees with hearing loss or other diverse backgrounds will be recruited to participate in research rotations in auditory and vestibular neuroscience research laboratories of the Bellucci Translational Hearing Center at Creighton University prior to selecting their doctoral thesis advisors within the Department of Biomedical Sciences. While working with Internal and External Mentors, including those with hearing loss or other diverse backgrounds, all R25 trainees and alumni will develop the capacity, resilience, and preferred career trajectories to become research leaders in science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medicine (STEMM), preferably in NIDCD mission areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevancy Statement Gene expression is tightly controlled in time and space and is governed by protein-nucleic acid (DNA and RNA) interactions. There are hundreds of DNA- and RNA-binding proteins that regulate gene expression and many are mutated in disease, but we lack facile approaches to map these proteins to their DNA/RNA targets. Here we propose to develop an innovative set of tools that will give every molecular biology lab the possibility to obtain comprehensive cell-type specific protein DNA/RNA interaction maps, a necessity to understand gene expression regulation and therefore disease development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with advanced solid tumors such as pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma desperately need novel and effective therapeutics. Macrophage allotransplantation seems permissive, making them a safe choice as a “third- party, off-the-shelf” cell therapy option. The proposed research will not only examine macrophages genetically engineered with a chimeric antigen receptor targeting phosphatidylserine as a universal adjuvant cell therapy of KRAS inhibitors for pancreatic cancer treatment, but it will also enhance the understanding of macrophage self- renewal, plasticity, signaling transduction and function execution.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Determining accurate models of the developing brain’s functional architecture during the first two years of life is necessary to make predictions about developmental and clinical outcomes. Crucially, developmental differences in sleep cycles between infants and toddlers and individual variability in time spent in each sleep stage pose a challenge for both understanding early brain development as well as mental health outcome prediction reproducibility and accuracy in extant pediatric, sleeping state fMRI studies such as the Baby Connectome Project, Developing Human Connectome Project, Early Life Adversity, Biological Embedding study, and Healthy Brain and Child Development study. Disentangling the relative contributions of sleep stage and age in early brain network development and decoding sleep stages in extant infant and toddler sleeping state fMRI data will be transformative, providing a state-based understanding of early developmental brain networks and a framework for accurate developmental outcome predictions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Given that suicide is the second leading cause of death of children and adolescents, this study addresses the National Institute of Mental Health's call for greater understanding of the brain/behavior mechanisms underlying youth suicide. Specifically, we will use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and real- world ecological momentary assessment (EMA) to advance what is known about the brain/behavior mechanisms underlying self-critical rumination (defined as persistent negative self-evaluation) and self- reassurance (providing compassion to self) in the context of youth suicide risk. Ultimately, greater understanding of these two constructs will facilitate the development of novel interventions targeting these symptom/circuit mechanisms related to youth suicide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma is a lethal tumor of the central nervous system with a median survival rate of less than fifteen months. The perturbation of gene expression patterns is a major driver of glioblastoma progression. Therefore, the overall goal of this project is to understand a novel gene regulatory network in glioblastoma cells that may enlighten development of additional, more effective therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: University Of North Dakota Epigenomics Of Development and Disease OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to facilitate the growth and sustainability of our Center of Biomedical Research Excellence “Epigenomics of Development and Disease” at UND. This will be achieved by supporting (1) a Pilot Project Program focused on epigenetic mechanisms in development and disease to bolster collaborative research, (2) a Genomics Core providing infrastructure and technology essential to our group and the wider research community, (3) an Administrative core to provide educational, oversight, and faculty development programs. These endeavors are poised to strengthen our group and enhance our ability to perform cutting- edge research with direct relevance to human health in the context of epigenetic mechanisms in disease and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE We will continue to develop a multidisciplinary research center focused on understanding and treating childhood diseases. The Center will sustain its supportive environment for scientists investigating the basis of and approaches to treat pediatric disease, specifically through high quality research Cores and sustained training and mentorship. Additionally, through careful and continual evaluation the Center will ensure its Cores and investigators are set up for success and self-sustainability post COBRE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH The goal of the proposed research is to develop ground-breaking targeted digital twin strategy for non-invasive guidance of optimal ablation therapy for ventricular arrhythmias in patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy based on uncovered new insights regarding the arrhythmogenic potential of penetrating adipose tissue in the zone of infarct. The project will utilize the combination of imaging, personalized computational modeling (digital twins), experimental and clinical measurements, and machine learning. Successful execution of the proposed studies will provide new mechanistic understanding of the role of penetrating adiposity in promoting and sustaining ventricular arrhythmias, and will lead to significant improvements in determining the critical ventricular tachycardia circuits that are the targets of ablation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Black or African American professionals account for no more than 3% of the workforce in the fields of Otolaryngology and Communication Sciences. The Duke Black or African-American research training Pathway to Otolaryngology and Communication Sciences (BAA-POCS) program seeks to address this career disparity by engaging undergraduate students from two Historically Black Colleges and Universities in North Carolina for a robust mentored research training curriculum, augmented by comprehensive clinical observation, in which they will gain exposure to different subspecialties in Otolaryngology and Communication Sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vision impairment reduces the effectiveness with which vision can be used to travel safely and pursue intended activities at home and in public spaces. Evaluating and enhancing the visual accessibility of environments supports the highest level of independence for people with vision impairment before relying on assistive technology or human assistance. Using computer vision algorithms and sensing technology, this research aims to develop an objective tool to complement the current observational practice in visual environmental evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals living with likely incurable cancer need feasible, accessible evidence-based depression treatment options. To address this need, we propose a Hybrid Type I effectiveness-implementation trial to: 1) comprehensively assess the effectiveness of a proactive identification (ID) + digital mental health intervention (DMHI) approach among individuals living with likely incurable cancer, 2) gather information on intervention (proactive ID + DMHI) delivery to guide best practices for implementation, and 3) develop an Electronic Health Record-derived phenotype of likely incurable cancer to enhance ID of individuals living with likely incurable cancer. This program of research has the potential to expand evidence-based psychosocial treatment access in a manner that is scalable across oncology settings and will enhance scientific knowledge for improving comprehensive survivorship care for individuals living with likely incurable cancer.

PHR: The Center for Targeted Therapeutics (CTT) at the University of South Carolina (USC) brings together junior and senior faculty with a common interest in the discovery of new molecular targets and prototype targeted drugs for the treatment of different diseases. The CTT has been instrumental in creating and supporting the critical mass of Targeted Therapeutics researchers at USC and the research resource cores required for their studies. During Phase 3, the CTT will work to assure continued growth of Targeted Therapeutics research at USC and the sustainability of the resource cores that are critical for this research.
