IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Bacterial pathogens require specific adaptations to colonize their infectious niche including a subset of these pathogens, such as Listeria monocytogenes, have evolved to utilize the cytosol of mammalian cells as their replication niche. Through our previous genetic screens we have identified two critical pathways, cell wall stress responses and metabolic adaptations, required for L. monocytogenes to survive and thrive in the cytosol and to ultimately cause disease. Aim 1 of this proposal will characterize how L. monocytogenes responds to cell wall stress and in turn how the host imposes cell wall stress, while aim 2 will characterize L. monocytogenes metabolic adaptation to the cytosol and how altered bacterial metabolism impacts the host response to infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Weight stigma is pervasive and harmful; it contributes to poorer physical and mental health outcomes due to stress processes, lower quality care from healthcare providers, and avoidance of healthcare services by patients. Psychologists play a large role in behavioral health programs, as well as care for eating disorders, body dysmorphia, and other conditions that make it essential that they are able to effe ctively communicate with higher-weight people in a non-stigmatizing way. This research seeks to examine how weight stigma changes among students in doctoral clinical psychology programs and the mechanisms underlying the development of weight stigma over time to inform training activities to reduce weight stigma and increase the preparedness of future mental health professionals to provide high-quality care to patients of all sizes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop a virtual platform to computationally assess the pathogenesis scenario, diagnostic steps, and therapeutic procedures for excess glucose-related cardiovascular and gastrointestinal diseases at a relatively low cost and time. The project is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing a new and alternative strategy for addressing excess glucose concentration in the body, which is a major precursor to most gastrointestinal-cardiovascular diseases, including diabetes mellitus, obesity, cancers, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Therefore, the proposed research is pertinent to one of the NIH's missions, which is to reduce illness and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The cells within many of our tissues, particularly the brain and muscles, maintain themselves for long periods of time without being replaced. This research will explore the intricate processes that enable cells to preserve their integrity and function post-developmentally. As deterioration of cellular maintenance contributes to numerous diseases as well as pathologies of aging, this research aims to pave the way for innovative treatments that reduce illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the overactivity of the sympathetic nervous system (the “fight or flight” branch of the autonomic system) plays a key role in the pathogenesis or progression of numerous cardiovascular diseases. In this project we will use high-resolution, live-cell imaging techniques to visualize the changes that occur in sympathetic neurons during disease states. An increased understanding of the molecular underpinnings that are responsible for sympathetic neuron overactivity can help in earlier diagnosis and prevention of cardiovascular diseases, as well as enhance our ability to develop novel therapies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Significant differences in the local placental renin-angiotensin system (RAS) have been implicated in adverse maternal and fetal outcomes. Using both mouse and rhesus macaque models, this project will determine how the RAS at the cell-specific level affects placental development. Understanding how abnormal placentation occurs, is important because proper formation and function of the placenta is critical to the survival and long- term health of babies, as well as the health of the pregnant person.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Public Health Narrative: Poor care quality and safety in long-term care (LTC) facilities (i.e., nursing homes, assisted living)—particularly for persons living with dementia (PLWD)—leads to adverse events and increased mortality. Decision-support technologies (DS tech) have been proven to increase safety/quality of care and decrease staff burnout in acute and primary care settings. However, to date, DS tech has not been tailored in context- and workflow-specific ways to LTCs. This innovative study aims to improve quality of work (for staff) and quality/safety of care by implementing context- and workflow-specific DS tech in LTCs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing decision support for long term care
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: There is a significant difference in clinical competencies for treating voice between speech-language pathologists (SLPs) at expert pediatric voice centers and SLPs at other practice locations; this will disproportionately impact children with voice disorders who cannot afford to travel to specialty clinics. The proposed research is a necessary foundation to address this critical issue. Outcomes will establish the key themes that characterize expert voice therapy, including communication style, structure of the therapy sessions based on clinical decision-making, and implementation of therapy tools, with the ultimate goal of translating this knowledge of clinical expertise to SLPs in all practice locations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative With longevity setting them apart from other primate species, humans experience high rates of cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, and neurodegenerative diseases during aging. Older great apes also exhibit cerebrovascular abnormalities, neurodegeneration with Alzheimer’s disease-like pathology, and frequent mortality from heart disease, but lack atherosclerosis and neurotoxicity that are devastating to humans. The goal of the proposed studies is to examine the interrelationship between age-related changes in cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease in humans and great apes as a means of understanding their impact on longevity and health as well as the unique susceptibility of humans to cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The University of Utah Program to Provide Pain Research Knowledge (UP3RK) mission is to impart the science knowledge, skills, and core competencies needed by post-graduate, interdisciplinary Scholars to address the nation’s scientific needs in clinical pain research. UP3RK trains Scholars through mentorship and concentrated training in: 1) our four focus areas (nonpharmacological pain treatments; effective interventions for pain and co-morbidities, particularly substance use disorders; implementation science; research within vulnerable, diverse, and underserved populations), 2) career development and programmatic skills, and 3) interdisciplinary research skills. We train Scholars through dedicated UP3RK Mentors within an innovative, multi-level mentor model develop independent clinical pain investigators and successful academic research careers.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: The NGRRC provides germ-free (GF, sterile) wild type and genetically-engineered gnotobiotic mice not available to most investigators due to the specialized technical expertise for their creation, breeding and study that are beyond the resources and expertise of most NIH grantees so they can explore host/microbe, microbe/ microbe and dietary/microbe interactions by examining physiologic and pathogenic differences in GF selectively colonized and conventionally raised mice, the functional relevance of bacterial genes, individual and defined microbial groups. Gnotobiotics enable precise microbial manipulation by colonizing GF normal, knockout or transgenic inbred mice with single or combined resident or pathogenic bacterial, viral or fungal species, including genetically engineered bacterial strains and by transplanting human fecal microbial communities into GF mouse recipients to explore their functional consequences. Overall Goal: Support broadly based basic and translational gnotobiotic research by local and national NIH-funded investigators with reliable, cost-effective, and easily accessed resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antimicrobial peptides named defensins are detected in patient urine following urinary tract infections (UTIs), but their functions are not clear. We will utilize newly developed Defensin cluster knockout mice to reveal how defensins regulate urinary immunity and pain during UTI. Successful completion of the project will aid the development of immune therapies to treat UTI and the associated pelvic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nemaline myopathy with intranuclear rods is a rare and severe disorder of skeletal muscle leading to infantile-onset muscle weakness and death in early childhood caused by a subset of pathogenic variants in ACTA1, which encodes the skeletal muscle-specific α-actin (SKA), in particular those affecting Val163. The eponymous intranuclear rods are made up of SKA, and we propose to study whether SKA has nuclear functions in healthy skeletal myocytes that are disrupted by the formation of intranuclear rods. We will test the hypothesis that nuclear SKA is required for complete differentiation of skeletal myocytes, and that incomplete differentiation in cells with ACTA1 p.Val163 variants underlies the severe and early-onset disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutations in CHAMP1 are a major risk factor for neurodevelopmental disorders, yet little is known about its function and role in brain development. This proposal utilizes forebrain cortical organoids, calcium imaging, cutting-edge single-cell omics, and in vitro electrophysiology to elucidate the role of CHAMP1 in early-stage human brain development. The findings will provide key insights into how CHAMP1 regulates process related to cell differentiation and proliferation and will potentially inform the development of new therapeutic strategies for CHAMP1-associated neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement Recently, we identified a new role for nucleotide biosynthesis in cellular differentiation. We found that inhibiting nucleotide biosynthesis impairs the ability of multipotent progenitors to become adipocytes while promoting vascular smooth muscle cell signatures. Our proposed studies will investigate the specific mechanism by which nucleotides regulate cell fate switching and whether targeting this pathway in vivo using genetic mouse models promotes angiogenesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Building on our promising efficacy findings using skin cancer genetic testing information to motivate prevention activities, this study examines the effectiveness and potential moderators and mediators of a precision prevention intervention to reduce tanning and sunburning and increase uptake of skin self-examination and physician-patient conversation about skin cancer prevention and early detection in ethnically diverse patients receiving health care at a federally qualified health center. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Concern has been raised over parallel increases in social media use and mental health challenges, particularly for racially/ethnically minoritized adolescents, highlighting the need to understand bidirectional associations between social media use and mental health in these youth. This innovative study will use a longitudinal mixed-method design and ecologically valid assessments to provide missing information critical to understanding the bi-directional dynamics between social media use and mental health among racially/ethnically minoritized adolescents. A more comprehensive and accurate understanding of the risks and protective mechanisms will inform the development of targeted, just-in- time interventions designed to reduce the harm and increase the benefit of social media use for vulnerable underrepresented adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Using immune cells to target and kill tumor cells is a promising therapeutic approach but currently lacks efficacy for many cancers due to the dysfunction of the immune cells in the tumor. This proposal seeks to identify the optimal modifications to genetically engineer into immune cells to help them resist dysfunction. By engineering new ways to control the transcriptional state of the immune cell, our approaches will improve the anti-tumor efficacy of T cells for multiple cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The chemical synthesis of bioactive molecules is of pivotal importance to the development of new drugs given the central role natural products have played for decades and continue to play in drug discovery. This proposal outlines the design of new approaches to forge pivotal bonds and access densely functionalized polycyclic frameworks describing their implementations in the efﬁcient preparations of structurally complex, bioactive molecules that already demonstrate promising biological activity. In doing so, these studies lay the foundation for the development of new medicines and accelerate the study and treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Each year, smoking kills 8 million people worldwide. Developing scalable, population-level behavioral treatments for smoking cessation is a priority of the National Cancer Institute (NCI) and aligned with the White House’s Cancer Moonshot goal to reduce smoking. This project addresses those priorities by testing the efficacy of a promising mobile health (mHealth) app designed exclusively for people who are not yet ready to quit smoking—the majority of people who smoke. To date, there are currently no effective population-based interventions for this critical group. If this novel intervention is found effective, it could be broadly disseminated, help reduce smoking prevalence, and inform the optimal design of future interventions targeting people who are not yet ready to quit smoking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dynamic contrast optical coherence microscopy (DyC-OCM) is distinguished from traditional scattering-based OCT by its emphasis on dynamic fluctuations: the motions of viable cells are accented against the motionless regions in the OCT images, enhancing the image contrast and revealing both cellular morphological and physiological information. In this program, we aim to develop the first 3D DyC-OCM technology that simultaneously breaks through the voxel rate and resolution barriers. We will accomplish the goal by developing a novel swept source architecture and a scalable parallel imaging platform.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY LAS CRUCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Consumption of arsenic-contaminated water is associated with an increased risk of lung, hepatobiliary, bladder, kidney, ureter, prostate, breast, and uterine cervix cancers. This project aims to achieve three main objectives: 1) Assess arsenic contamination in rural New Mexico water wells; 2) Identify DNA damage (8-hydroxy-2'- deoxyguanosine) and oxidative stress (F2-isoprostane, 4-hydroxyneonal) biomarkers through urine samples; and 3) Determine arsenic levels in urine specimens of residents from the rural underprivileged New Mexico- Mexico border population, who rely on water for domestic use. The study will investigate the link between arsenic- contaminated well water and the development of associated cancers within this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia patients account for nearly 3500 stem cell transplant procedures annually in the US of which > 2/3 are for individuals aged < 65 and occur in first complete remission (CR1). Relapse after transplant and treatment related mortality remain major obstacles for assuring the long-term effectiveness of these efforts and have high associated mortality. Our proposed investigations using novel induction regimens to more expeditiously gain CR1 in AML patients with rapid progression to allogeneic transplantation, will enhance overall transplant outcomes and provide opportunity to determine optimal measurable residual disease assessments and to directly compare the patient experiences, both in need for hospital care and direct reported outcomes when receiving standard care vs intensive, sequential induction and transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac sarcoidosis is a serious inflammatory disease in the heart that can cause heart failure and arrhythmias. There is limited knowledge about one type of immune cells in the heart that may be causing the disease, called T cells. This project aims to use high-throughput immune profiling technology to study the types of T-cells in the heart during cardiac sarcoidosis, and test whether blocking a receptor called CXCR3 can help direct T-cells away from the heart and reduce cardiac inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Active caregiver involvement is a key feature of state-of-the-science early evidence-based interventions (EBIs) for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and is federally mandated in publicly-funded early intervention services. Latino children are increasingly being diagnosed with ASD at younger ages, yet experience disparities in service access and quality which may extend to disparities in caregiver engagement in services. The present study seeks to characterize patterns and determinants of Latino caregiver engagement in ASD early intervention services as a means of informing culturally- and linguistically-responsive engagement tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) exhibit sleep disturbances. Since the most common treatment for pediatric ADHD is stimulant medication, methylphenidate (MPH), there is interest in whether MPH results in exacerbated sleep disturbances and development of sleeping disorders later in adulthood. This grant will advance the field by better understanding the complex relationship that early psychostimulant exposure and ADHD can have on sleep and neurophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative:  The transition to menopause is inevitable for aging women and is a stage in her life where she is vulnerable to developing a multitude of psychiatric conditions, including psychosis. The experiments detailed in this application aim to provide a mechanistic understanding into how aberrant regulation of dopamine neuron activity can lead to psychosis-like behavioral deficits in a rodent model used to study perimenopause. We will also investigate the utility of a novel GABAAR positive allosteric modulator that we believe may be used to treat symptoms of psychosis during perimenopause.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interpersonal trauma (IT) is a social determinant of health causing enduring adverse impacts on victims’ biopsychosocial and emotional health. The purpose of this exploratory sequential mixed methods study is to generate a rich understanding of the impact of exposure to IT on engagement in care (EIC) among Latino immigrant men living with HIV (LIMWH) and the protective resources such as emotional support (ES) that can be promoted to address psychosocial and HIV-related disparities in this population. This study will advance the sciences of trauma-informed-care, HIV management, psychosocial health promotion, and health engagement for Latino immigrant men and inform future clinical and community-based interventions and research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Driven by structural racism, non-Hispanic Black women are two times as likely as non-Hispanic White women to suffer from severe maternal morbidity, which increases risk for maternal mortality. Using participatory system dynamics modeling methodologies, this project will generate a holistic understanding of the dynamically complex systems that perpetuate severe maternal morbidity disparities among non-Hispanic Black women. This understanding will then be transformed into a system dynamics simulation model that will be developed, tested, analyzed, and disseminated to provide an evidence-based decision-making tool to inform intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: A previous fracture is one of the best predictors of future fracture risk, but the causes of this relationship are unclear. Systemic bone loss following a fracture is an understudied process that may contribute to a decrease in bone strength and increase fracture risk at all skeletal sites. In the proposed studies we will investigate systemic bone loss following an upper arm fracture in human subjects, determine how this injury response is different in older people vs. younger people, and explore potential mechanisms driving this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is a deadly malignant brain tumor with poor survival outcomes attributed to low efficacy of standard treatment strategies. Cell therapies are a promising new platform for treating GBM, however, therapeutic cells injected into the GBM post-resection cavity are rapidly cleared from the brain, resulting in limited therapeutic durability. We propose the development of a novel 3D printing technique known as bioprinting, in which therapeutic cells are embedded in a 3D printed hydrogel for use as a protective cell delivery system for treating GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Restriction of protein or specifically restricting the amino acid isoleucine results in drastic improvements in metabolic health and lifespan. However, adequate protein is required for muscle hypertrophy during exercise and frailty prevention during later life. During this F99/K00 award, I will examine the necessity of FGF21 for lifespan extension by examining the role of exercise and diet in the response of skeletal muscle to rapamycin while learning new skills, analytical techniques, and continuing to engage with the local science promoter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Stem cells are a critical aspect of aging as decreased stem cell capacity can contribute to age- related diseases, such as neural stem cells in the brain predisposing the hippocampus to Alzheimer’s. Therefore, understanding neural stem cell aging will provide opportunities to harness neural stem cells as a therapeutic for age-related cognitive decline and dementias like Alzheimer’s. This proposal will uncover central mechanisms of how neural stem cells decline with age and will reveal how to target them therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Current state-of-the-art methods in assessing infant emotion regulation and infant-parent interaction—both critical to healthy brain and behavioral development—have been stymied by brief laboratory paradigms that are burdensome to families and limit ecological validity. Next-generation methods, including wearable sensing and machine learning approaches, promise to advance science and clinical practice among infants with prenatal substance exposures. Characterizing dynamic real-time processes of infant emotion regulation and infant- caregiver interaction (a) via multiple modalities, (b) across the day and (c) in the home will provide a level of granularity that has not been previously possible, while at the same time decreasing participant burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative An estimated 6.5 million Americans age 65 and older are living with Alzheimer's disease (AD) today and this number could grow to 13.8 million by 2060 barring the development of medical breakthroughs to prevent, slow or cure AD. Current treatments for AD are symptomatic, with modest effect sizes and limited impact on longer- term disease outcomes. The goal of the proposal is to develop orally available and brain-penetrant neutral sphingomyelinase 2 (nSMase2) inhibitors mechanistically distinct from other therapeutic approaches, aiming at bringing a novel treatment option that can potentially delay or slow the progression of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative High-quality mother-infant interactions set the stage for secure parent-child attachment, self-reliance, and children’s ability to flexibly solve problems and “bounce back” from difficulties. This constellation of behaviors reduces the risk of later developing problem behaviors, including substance use. The current proposal will develop algorithms that use data from wearable sensors to assess the quality of early mother-infant interactions objectively, automatically, and remotely in natural home environments, with the goal of developing tools to facilitate identification and prevention of early risks for substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to develop and test a fully-autonomous (no-human operator) CBT-based digital therapeutic for comorbid opioid use disorder (OUD) and internalizing (anxiety and depression) disorders that targets compulsive opioid use motivated by relief of unpleasant emotions. We will modify an existing digital therapeutic in the project's first phase and test it in a clinical trial in the second phase. The success of this project would provide a relatively cheap and easily scaled intervention for OUD based on a well-developed neuro-behavioral model of addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of cognitive decline and there remains no known cause of sporadic cases and no cure. The transcription factor PPARd has recently emerged as a promising disease- modifying therapy for AD and is currently the focus of a Phase 2a clinical trial for mild-to-moderate AD. In this proposal, I will evaluate the mechanism of PPARd neuroprotection in microglia and assess the value of PPARd as a therapeutic target for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative A lack of access to language during early childhood has lifelong affects not only on linguistic and communicative competence, but can cause cognitive delays, mental health difficulties, higher incidence of trauma, limited literacy, and lower quality of life. Globally, language exposure for deaf children begins at a variety of chronological ages and varies based on whether the local sign language is developed or emerging. The proposed studies will provide insight into how deaf people with various ages of language exposure use their cognitive and pragmatic resources to acquire and create language in a variety of settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Navigation ability throughout the lifespan is critical to independent mobility and our quality of life. Here, we propose to study how we rely on our hearing along with our other senses to form a spatial map of our environment. Understanding how individuals with and without sensory impairments integrate their senses will help us learn how important it is to provide auditory health care with age, use auditory information during rehabilitation, and will help us decode how the brain perceives our world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project responds to the National Institutes of Health, through the HEAL Initiative (RFA-DA-23- 051), solicitation for applications that test sustainable, scalable interventions to prevent opioid misuse and co- occurring conditions by intervening directly on social determinants of health (SDOH). The proposed project will take an important step toward addressing this need for research by evaluating the effectiveness of The Inclusive Skill-building Learning Approach (ISLA), an instructional and restorative alternative to exclusionary discipline, on the SDOH of education access and quality, and social and community context to prevent school exclusion and opioid and other substance misuse. This study has the potential to achieve meaningful outcomes including (a) reducing the use of exclusionary and racially discriminatory discipline practices, (b) improving inclusive teaching practices and student engagement, (c) improving student-teacher relationships and school climate, and (d) reducing student opioid and other substance misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Vocal communication hinges on the integration of auditory and motor systems in the brain, enabling the continuous use of auditory feedback to guide the motor actions that produce spoken language. In this proposal, we aim to understand the neurobiology of sensorimotor integration by simultaneously examining auditory and motor brain regions in European starlings while they sing and listen to song. This proposal outlines a novel approach for comprehending how the brain multiplexes and coordinates information across neuronal subpopulations, creating an opportunity to develop a network level understanding of neurobiological processes that substantiate language.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia disorders are incurable aging related brain diseases causing severe disability and death around the world. RNA binding by tau contributes to pathological tau protein deposition in the brain neurons of Alzheimer’s disease patients leading to neuronal dysfunction and neurodegeneration. Completion of this project will advance the field by illuminating the molecular mechanisms of abnormal tau function through RNA binding and measure the influence of tau RNA complexes on neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current proposal aims to provide significant pre-clinical evidence that metformin, an FDA-approved Type II Diabetes drug, has therapeutic potential in reducing the risk of relapse in cocaine use disorder (CUD) while providing evidence for its mechanism of action in the nucleus accumbens core. Elucidating the pharmacological, behavioral, and neuronal impact of oral metformin dosing will contribute to the development of novel interventions for stimulant-related relapse behaviors. The long-term goal of this proposal is to yield significant justification for the repurposing of metformin as a treatment for CUD, a major public health concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative While experiences of early life adversity (ELA) have been shown to increase risk for depressive symptoms and the onset of major depressive disorder (MDD) during adolescence, the biobehavioral and neurobiological mechanisms underlying these associations are not well understood. Leveraging data from a multimethod longitudinal study, the proposed project investigates sleep disturbances as one pathway by which ELA is associated with altered frontolimbic development and increased risk for MDD across adolescence, a developmental period characterized by heightened sleep disturbances, ongoing brain development, and increased vulnerability to MDD onset. Findings from the proposed project will increase our understanding of the neurodevelopmental mechanisms by which ELA is related to increased risk for MDD and provide insight into sleep disturbances as a target of intervention during adolescence to ameliorate the effects of ELA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because patients with both opioid use disorder (OUD) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) are at high risk for dropping out of buprenorphine medication therapy and experiencing overdose. Our phased project will first examine how helpful patients with PTSD and OUD find a device that administers therapeutic electrical stimulation to their vagus and trigeminal nerves through the skin around their ears and then complete FDA pre-submission for using the device with this population more broadly. Finally, we will study how effective the device is for helping patients with PTSD and OUD stay in buprenorphine treatment by comparing the results of those who received therapeutic stimulation versus those who believed that they had but, in fact, did not.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Responsibilities of caregivers of people living with dementia increase over time, and without adequate training and support American Indian caregivers experience adverse health consequences. This community-based study addresses caregiver concerns by enhancing the Savvy Caregiver Program with a peer component to improve caregiver mastery and reduce feelings of depression and isolation among American Indian caregivers of White Earth Nation in Minnesota. Our findings will promote knowledge translation and inform the development of peer- based interventions grounded in cultural values to improve quality of life and outcomes for American Indian dementia caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Neuroscientists use computational models of neurons and networks of neurons to gain insight into the nervous system in health and disease by testing hypothesized mechanisms and by making predictions about data that cannot be readily measured experimentally. Because of the increasing complexity of these models, there is an increasing need for the development and dissemination of methods to accelerate these simulations across multiple spatial scales. This project addresses those needs, building on the strengths of the widely used, open- source NEURON simulator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain and alcohol use disorders are highly comorbid conditions with a complex, bidirectional relationship. Relapse to alcohol use is associated with increased pain, but therapeutics to reduce relapse risk in the context of chronic pain are lacking. Experiments in this proposal will use a rodent model of chronic pain to investigate the role of discrete neural circuits in the regulation of alcohol relapse-related behavior in animals with chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol consumption stimulates the release of endogenously-produced opioid peptides that influence the rewarding effects of this drug. With continued consumption and over time, the ability to stimulate the same level of response changes fundamentally, although it is not known if such changes include the production of novel peptides from the same family. Here we will apply the use of advanced analytical platforms and animal models of addiction behavior towards the discovery of new peptide sequences that may assist in the development of pharmacotherapeutics for treating individuals with Alcohol Use Disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this project is to use cell-based high-throughput assays to reliably predict the consequences of genetic variants of unknown significance discovered in the course of genetic testing in a subset of muscular dystrophies caused by mutations in a set of alpha-dystroglycan glycosylating enzymes: FKTN, FKRP, POMT1, POMT2, and POMGNT1. We propose to use an integrated experimental and computational approach that combines multiple high-throughput assays of protein trafficking and function and machine-learning to generate pathogenicity predictions for all possible single-nucleotide variants in these dystroglycanopathy genes and then validate and disseminate our predictions with respect to disease risk and severity using extensive clinical data and primary tissue samples from patients with muscular dystrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury (TBI) imposes an enormous public health burden in the United States, affecting 2.8 million people yearly, comprising the leading cause of death in patients aged 1-44 years old, and causing a “silent epidemic” of persistent disabilities afflicting 5.3 million Americans and culminating in a $102bn yearly cost. However, as no targeted therapies exist for TBI, there is a critical need to uncover molecular mechanisms that could unlock the potential for effective cellular regeneration by NG2-glia, the largest population of regenerative cells in the adult brain, to aid in recovery from TBI. Using techniques in chronobiology, developmental biology, neurotrauma, and omics sciences, it is the goal of this proposal to identify the downstream effectors of the circadian clock that regulate NG2-glia regenerative potential to be able to identify the molecular pathways that could serve as future targets to enhance post-TBI cellular regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perturbation of sphingolipid metabolism, which is regulated by saposins and their precursor protein prosaposin (PSAP), has recently emerged as a critical risk factor for the onset and progression of neurodegenerative diseases. The goal of the proposed research is to determine how PSAP cleavage into saposins is regulated by lysosomal enzymes, progranulin, and age, and how this contributes to lysosomal function. Successful completion of these experiments will provide novel understanding of the causes and mechanisms underlying lipidome changes neurodegenerative disease and hopefully bring us one step closer to a cure.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: In 2014, Congress enacted the Veterans Access, Choice, and Accountability ACT (VACAA) to establish the Veterans Choice Program (VCP) and expand the availability of community care for eligible Veterans. VCP has grown by 138% since its inception to include more than half a million providers. This rapid growth has led to concerns within VA related to the adequacy of non-VA provider networks and a need to develop appropriate measures of network adequacy. In the context of these questions is also the need to better understand organizational decision-making processes regarding Community Care at the local level as these decisions affect which Veterans receive care within the VA or in the community. This service directed research proposal aims to develop standardized measures of network adequacy and examine VAMC characteristics associated with high rates of Community Care provision. Upon completion of this project, we will be poised to assist policymakers in decisions shaping community care standards for the VHA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Methadone Patient Access to Collaborative Treatment (MPACT) is a staff-level, trauma-informed practice change intervention for US opioid treatment programs (OTP) to increase treatment retention and decrease in-treatment overdose and patient- and staff-reported posttraumatic stress symptoms (PTSS). It is based on the theory that current OTP practice and culture likely contribute to treatment interruption and relapse rates of 30%-50% which, in turn, increase the risk of opioid overdoses. MPACT will be designed for immediate implementation and scalability; and includes four evidence-based components: 1) a 4-module CME/CEU-accredited trauma-informed psychoeducation training program for OTP staff, 2) a trauma navigation model for patients and staff, 3) clinic trauma-informed care (TIC) self-assessment, and 4) separate reflective supervisory structures for counselors/case managers and medical providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease (AD) represent urgent biomedical and social problems that remain poorly understood and with no effective treatments. Major theories of causation of AD invokes deposition of proteins known as amyloid and tau, and disruption of the blood-brain barrier (BBB), but we do not understand what aspects of aging first “trigger” the disease process and the interaction between these separate potential culprits. In this project, we will use both mouse models of AD, as well as studies in older cognitively normal people, to explore the relationships between alterations in the BBB and amyloid and tau deposition in order to understand the mechanisms that may drive the initiation and progression of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This high-risk, high-reward proposal will test whether we can use novel machine-learning methods to design drug mixtures that jointly activate or inhibit, respectively, the activity of neurons that increase or decrease satiety, while sparing off-target neurons types to reduce side effects. We will optimize this approach using cutting-edge imaging of 1000s of hypothalamic neurons that control energy balance, and then test customized optimized mixtures in mouse models of obesity. In future, we hope to use this approach to guide ongoing polypharmacy approaches to treating diabetes and obesity in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Data Coordinating Center (DCC) will support all activities of the Blood and Marrow Transplant Clinical Trials Network, using the extensive expertise of its investigators in clinical and translational research, biostatistics, transplantation, and cellular therapies. The DCC will take advantage of collaborations with other organizations and initiatives to maximize efficiency and trial participation. The goal is to facilitate trials that pro- vide definitive answers to important clinical questions that will lead to changes in practice that increase survival and enhance quality of life for patients with serious malignant and non-malignant blood diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop new computational methods to analyze data from in situ spatial transcriptomics, which measures gene expression profiles in a spatial context. The proposed methods aim to enhance the analysis of in situ data, yielding more reliable cell boundaries, cell type annotations, and characterizations of the cellular microenvironment. These methods are anticipated to offer new biological insights into cell senescence and the tumor microenvironment, contributing to a deeper understanding of complex human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pain, fatigue, and distress are highly prevalent, co-occurring, and interfering symptoms in patients with advanced cancer. Our team will test a brief telehealth-delivered psychosocial intervention that aims to decrease symptom interference and improve quality of life in patients receiving care in medically underserved areas. Our patient-centered approach will lay the foundation for future symptom management interventions, toward the goal of reducing suffering in those facing life- threatening illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Muscle mass and strength change in response to a range of physiological and pathophysiological conditions, including neurodegenerative diseases, cancer, diabetes, neuromuscular disorders, and aging. Dual-specificity phosphatase 4 (Dusp4) has been found to be upregulated in response to neurogenic atrophy, but its role in the complex molecular events that modulate muscle mass remains unknown. This study will investigate the functional role of Dusp4 in skeletal muscle and identify the in vivo substrates targeted for dephosphorylation by Dusp4. This study will advance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of muscle wasting and could lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets for the treatment of skeletal muscle atrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRITIVE There is a global mental health crisis that is particularly problematic in the context of HIV in high impact settings where there is low reach of evidenced based mental health treatments. Based on our successful prior efficacy and effectiveness work with cognitive-behavioral therapy for adherence and depression (CBT-AD) in HIV, the current study is designed to identify replicable implementation strategies to enhance the reach of depression / adherence treatment in people living with HIV in S. Africa. If successful, the model can inform policy, funding decisions for HIV treatment delivery, and be extended to other low-resource settings for HIV and, potentially, other integrated medical/mental health settings and contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative There are no cures available for neurodegenerative diseases including Dementia with Lewy Bodies, Parkinson’s disease, and Parkinson’s disease-dementia. These diseases are characterized by accumulation of protein aggregates. Our proposal includes methods to test the hypothesis that simultaneously improving protein folding, trafficking, and lysosomal clearance will synergistically improve phenotypes in cultures and mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintaining muscular strength into old age is essential for independence, safety and daily activities; therefore, understanding contributors which lead to the progression of muscle fibrosis in aging will provide novel therapeutic strategies to delay or prevent sarcopenia. I have identified fibro/adipogenic progenitors (FAPs) as novel contributors to aged muscle fibrosis but the cellular and molecular events that lead to this are unclear. The goal of this proposal is to investigate FAPs through sarcopenia development to elucidate therapeutic approaches which leverage FAP metabolism to delay or prevent fibrosis and weakness associated with sarcopenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Animals host complex communities of microbes that are part of the proper functioning of our bodies, and control of the microbiome by the immune system is critical for host health. This project will study how beneficial microbes and animal immune systems coevolve. By seeking this basic understanding of the evolutionary dynamics governing the microbiome, this research is relevant to the NIH’s mission to develop fundamental knowledge of living systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sarcopenia is a condition that causes a loss of muscle mass and function, which can greatly affect the quality of life and overall health outcomes of those with advanced lung disease. The built environment, which refers to the physical surroundings of individuals, is an important factor in the development and progression of sarcopenia, but it is often overlooked in research. Our proposal aims to investigate how the built environment is associated with sarcopenia and identify any barriers and facilitators in accessing exercise spaces and nutritional support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular defense protects individual cell against infection across all three domains of life. This proposal focuses on a new group of host immune proteins - the Guanylate Binding Protein-Like (GBPL) GTPases - in plant immunity. By employing cutting-edge techniques and interdisciplinary approaches, our efforts have the potential to unveil novel host defense mechanisms and should have broad implications for the development of innovative strategies for controlling infectious diseases in both plants and animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance (Narrative): Infectious lung diseases carry devastating personal and economic costs, and as one of the world's most deadly infectious diseases, tuberculosis and its causative bacterium, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, remains a persistent and costly threat to public health. I have developed a research platform to investigate mycobacterial susceptibility and resistance genes, connecting findings from the molecular to organismal levels. In this research proposal, I seek to identify the molecular function of the mycobacterial protein and potential drug target, BrkB (aka Rv2707 in M. tuberculosis), and characterize how it protects bacteria from the host.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the demographic, molecular, and clinical basis of health across the life course in translationally-relevant nonhuman primate (NHP) species is fundamentally important to the study of human aging. Not only will this study test hypotheses regarding differences in the lifespan and healthspan of NHP species, it will generate the largest NHP lifespan database to date, create a new clinical measure for biological aging in NHPs, and identify blood-based biomarkers associated with differences in aging within and between species. Thus, this study is relevant to NIA’s mission to support genetic, biological, and clinical research on aging in furtherance of the NIH’s overall goal of seeking fundamental knowledge about the nature of living systems to enhance health and lengthen life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Reconstruction of large and major bone defects remains a significant challenge in orthopedic surgery. Yet, the golden treatments so far, using replacement auto or allo-grafts, struggle with many problems of immune rejection, infection, donor-site morbidity and especially, limited tissue supplies. Here, we propose a new approach to combine special biodegradable piezoelectric Poly-l-Lactide (PLLA) nanofibers with Tricalcium Phosphate (β-TCP) to create a bionic bone composite scaffold which can be activated by ultrasound (US) to electrically stimulate a complete healing of critical-sized bone defects in vivo.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-acute rehabilitation utilization after stroke is poorly characterized, leaving us unable to improve the continuity of care, patient outcomes, and the value of rehabilitation after stroke. This proposal aims to fill this gap by comprehensively characterizing longitudinal post-acute rehabilitation utilization during the first year after stroke and determining its impact on one-year outcomes. This will establish the foundational knowledge needed to improve the value of rehabilitation after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Clinical bulk samples contain mixed cell types, resulting to an admixture of signals from multiple pure compo- nents. We propose to develop novel statistical approaches to address the problem of cell type mixture identifi- cation for subjects with multiple observations, construct methods to estimate individual-specific pure profile ref- erences, and retrieve more accurate cell type mixture proportions at individual levels. Our project will break new ground for many studies by enabling the investigation of personalized pure cell type associations with the disease outcome, and the individual-level, cell-type-specific biomarker discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dopaminergic neurons are particularly sensitive to age-related oxidative stress, and evolutionary changes in the human lineage exacerbate this vulnerability by extending lifespan and disproportionately expanding axonal target regions, while requiring increased innervation density in multiple basal ganglia regions. We will use experimental, computational, and functional methods in human and non-human primate stem cell-derived dopaminergic neurons, complemented by analysis of primary brain substantia nigra tissue to identify human-specific oxidative stress-responsive regulatory elements and genes supporting neuroprotective compensatory adaptations. As many age-related disorders involve damage from oxidative stress, understanding evolved mechanisms of neuroprotection in a particularly vulnerable neuron will support general strategies aimed at targeting dynamic oxidative stress responsive elements and pathways in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We have found that sickle red blood cells can directly activate neutrophils, resulting in abnormal neutrophil function. In this application, we will define the properties of sickle red blood cells which cause neutrophils to become activated, and we will determine the consequences which occur as a result of neutrophil activation. These findings may provide new explanations for how complications occur in sickle cell disease and may identify new strategies to prevent such complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While one of the most remarkable features of the human species is our capacity for extreme longevity, understanding the marked variation in life spans within and between populations and the capacity for further life span extension are key priorities for aging research that can be informed by comparative research. This study leverages 170 years of rich life course data from three wild populations of humans’ closest living evolutionary relatives, chimpanzees and gorillas, to determine how variation in the prevalence of and resilience to early life adversity shapes the capacity to achieve long life span. Specific aims will determine how the response to early life adversity shapes variation in individual risk of mortality and frailty within populations and between sexes, and evaluate the effects of early life adversity on population and species differences in aging and life span.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Soil-transmitted helminth infections represents a significant global public health and economic burden. Therefore, there is an urgent need to improve our understanding of genetic and environmental modulators of type 2 cytokine-dependent immunity in order to identify novel preventative and therapeutic approaches for this group of infectious agents. Based on our new preliminary data, the focus of this proposal is to dissect the influence of diet-induced modulation of microbiota-derived metabolites in regulating type 2 cytokine responses and protective immunity to helminth infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Population genomic inference currently assumes that all segregating mutations are neutral and does not account for the effects of selection across the genome, which is problematic when modeling genomic variation in species with compact genomes (i.e., those with a high density of protein-coding and regulatory regions) where natural selection is pervasive. The goal of this project is to generate a more accurate estimate of the fitness effects of new mutations across the genome and to develop statistical and computational methods that simultaneously account for the effects of selection jointly with other evolutionary processes to make accurate evolutionary inferences using sequence variation from natural populations. As most pathogenic species tend to have highly compact genomes and experience strong bouts of selection and drastic repeated bottlenecks, our methodological advances and their applications would be absolutely essential to uncovering the population and selective history of human pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Behavioral Research on Acculturation and moderating and mediating Variables Observed Specifically among Latinos: BRAVOS Project Narrative Childhood obesity is on the rise and disparities exist particularly among Latino preschool-aged children and approximately half of Latino kindergarteners in Nevada are overweight or obese. It is crucial to identify determinants of childhood obesity and one possible determinant of obesity is parental acculturation to the United States. The purpose of this project is to examine the longitudinal association of parental acculturation with child outcomes: fruit and vegetable intake, and BMI by using a new technology, skin carotenoid spectroscopy which measures biomarkers of fruit and vegetables (carotenoid intake) that is fast, and easy to use to measure child’s fruit and vegetable intake which can help identify and monitor child’s fruit and vegetable intake and to promote healthier dietary patterns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer treatment can cause side effects on the heart including arrhythmias. Cardiospheres derived from stem cells can provide a new model for efficient detection of drug-induced cardiotoxicity, which will improve the safety of cancer treatment. Our high throughput assay will also allow to examine antiarrhythmic drugs in human cardiospheres in a highly efficient manner, facilitating future effort on large-scale drug discovery study which is challenging with animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal supports the NCI’s public health goal of improving the quality of survival of persons diagnosed with cancer and the goal of preventing, minimizing, or managing adverse effects of cancer and its treatment. It does so by advancing evaluation of a novel intervention that pairs a collection of first-hand, survivor-written peer support narratives with coordinated educational content and stress/coping resources for hematological patients preparing for, undergoing, and recovering from hematopoietic stem cell transplant. If successful, this research would yield a low-cost, scalable intervention that fills a gap in supportive resources for transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chicago EYES on Cancer is an innovative two-year program for high school students, college students, and high school science teachers from across Chicago’s diverse communities, engaging them in cutting-edge cancer research, science education, and biomedical career exploration. This proposal details plans to build on the success of EYES via strong integration within the University of Chicago’s scientific community; strategic partnerships with the city’s educational and cultural institutions; and the dedication of an experienced and passionate leadership team. In these ways, EYES will continue to empower the city’s talented youth to pursue careers in biomedicine, supporting NCI’s mission to build a diverse cancer workforce, advance scientific knowledge, and help all people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury causes communication and swallowing deficits and impacts health, work productivity, and quality of life. Enhanced central neuromodulation via electrical stimulation to the vagus nerve, paired with a motor-specific behavior, may help restore motor function to the muscles of the larynx. Understanding the role of enhanced central neuroplasticity on functional and neuroplastic outcomes in the context of RLN injury chronicity and laterality in an animal model will provide a springboard for novel treatment approaches for laryngeal motor impairments after RLN injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SARS-CoV-2 is responsible for current pandemic and the development of intervention strategies against coronaviruses with pandemic potential is most critical. This proposal seeks to develop novel vaccine immunogens and vaccination strategies that can induce pan-betacoronavirus broadly neutralizing antibody responses by vaccination. A robust and durable vaccine against coronaviruses will be a powerful intervention to control and eventually eliminate SARS-CoV-2 infections and potential emerging coronaviruses and thus the application is highly relevant to human health and welfare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to identify modifiable factors that promote cognitive reserve, slow cognitive decline, and reduce risk for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) among older adults who lack formal education. Using longitudinal data from a nationally representative study of older adults in India, we will identify the roles of life course employment, social relationships, and social engagement in cognitive reserve, cognitive change, and ADRD risk, overall and according to access to early-life formal education. Our results will advance scientific theory on resilience to aging-related brain pathology in the absence of education and support the identification of intervention targets to reduce the global ADRD burden for diverse older populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Many glaucoma patients experience continued vision loss despite maximally reduced intraocular pressure, indicating that additional factors contribute to the pathology of the disease. Our preliminary studies have indicated that the T-cell population of some patients exhibits a markedly pro-inflammatory skew and that the removal of T-cells protects vision in animal models of the disease. The goal of this project is to identify which T-cell population is active in this process and to elucidate the mechanisms of T-cell mediated damage to the retina in glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deficits in executive functioning (EF) disproportionately impact children living in poverty and increase risk for psychopathology, particularly disruptive behavior disorders. This randomized clinical trial seeks to determine whether childhood EF, assessed across neural and behavioral units of analysis, is an experimental therapeutic target that can be directly modified through caregiver participation in the Chicago Parent Program (CPP), if increases in EF predict reduced disruptive behavior trajectories in low-income children over a short-term follow-up period, and identify which CPP-driven parenting skill improvements are the most influential in modifying EF. This work will contribute new knowledge as to whether a cost-efficient parenting intervention, developed for and with low-income families raising young children in poverty, can modify EF, a neural- behavioral mechanism implicated in risk for childhood disruptive behavior problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A key feature of familial dementia syndromes is the acceleration of processes that normally take most of a lifetime to occur, with devastating consequences. We will harness well-defined and vetted molecular systems developed in our lab to define how dementia peptides found in patients cause the observed accelerations. Understanding the underlying molecular mechanisms can provide novel paths to disrupt the processes that lead to accelerated formation of amyloid plaques and fibrillar tangles that are the hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE The University of Michigan Consortium partners transplant teams from the two leading cancer centers—the University of Michigan (U-M) and Karmanos Cancer Institute (KCI)—and the two leading pediatric hospitals in the State of Michigan. The U-M Consortium will emphasize strategies to reduce the toxicity of transplants for patients with non-malignant blood disorders, including patients with sickle cell anemia and immunologic disorders. This study proposes administering a novel oral agent (Vorinostat) to patients during the initial month of transplant in an attempt to lessen organ toxicity, reduce the incidence and severity of graft versus host disease and improve overall survival in this patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Complex cognitive behaviors are thought to be supported by distributed activity across the brain, but we do not know which exact activity patterns cause specific components of cognitive behavior. This knowledge gap exists partly because most current perturbation methods target single or few brain regions at a time, and do not account for off-target changes in neural activity. Here, we proposed to develop new methods to fill this gap, using simultaneous neural recordings and large-scale spatially stochastic optogenetic perturbation across the mouse dorsal cortex, combined with computational methods, to infer how distributed neural processes generate cognitive behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The insertion of oxygen atoms into molecules by non-heme oxygenase enzymes is involved in numerous biological processes, and therefore greatly impacts human health. These diverse enzymes share a common active site but it is unclear how they achieve such a wide range of functions. A better understanding of the active site structure-function relationship, which we will achieve using accurate model systems, is expected to illuminate fundamental chemistry that will help explain the importance and versatility of the non-heme oxygenase active sites. Thus, the research aligns with mission of NIGMS to better understand the fundamental biological processes of living organisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sustained attention, the ability to focus on an activity or stimulus over time, is significantly impaired in many neuropsychiatric disorders. In this application we optimize key parameters in a touchscreen-based continuous performance test in mice to validate electrophysiological correlates of behavioral performance as putative translational biomarkers and provide mechanistic insight about the circuits underlying this behavior. This proposal is relevant to the part of the NIH mission that pertains to the translation of basic mechanisms underlying mental illnesses into innovative treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This application proposes a newly instantiated Coordinating Center for Primate Aging Research (CCPAR) to coordinate the work of a broad array of specialists across gerosciences and facilitate integration of data from NIA-funded research programs across sites, endpoints, approaches to measurement, and species. A major focus of the supported grants will be comparative studies across multiple nonhuman primate (NHP) species with the goal of illuminating determinants of lifespan and healthspan in humans. This proposal is aimed at coordinating multi-species data that identify intrinsic and extrinsic factors of age resilience that which could be leveraged to slow biological aging in humans and lead individuals to live longer, better lives with fewer age-associated comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has emerged as the most prevalent chronic liver disease with increasing incidence rates worldwide; but no FDA-approved treatments are available currently. Absence of Lipocalin Prostaglandin D2 Synthase (L-PGDS) developed fatty liver disease accompanied with insulin resistance and weight gain in mice; however, the precise role of L-PGDS in NAFLD is unknown. Research in this SuRE First (R16) proposal will investigate the molecular mechanisms of signaling by L-PGDS and its metabolite PGD2 that has potential for the discovery of novel NAFLD therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This educational research program targets high school students from a rural, lower socioeconomic status area to promote a more diverse future biomedical workforce. Faculty-mentored research projects, development of a training curriculum, bi-directional feedback with community stakeholders, undergraduate mentors, community education, and integration of cancer disparities throughout all aspects of the program are highlights of the proposal. Program evaluation, including tracking students 15 years to determine future career pursuits, is emphasized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heavy workload contributes to burnout and job dissatisfaction among nurses. Computational modeling of nursing workflow using a scalable platform is an important first step toward testing interventions to reduce workload-driven burnout. Understanding workload contributes to health equity efforts by identifying patient populations most likely to experience inadequate care due to inconsistencies in nurse workload and staffing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation in the brain results in the accumulation of excess waste, fluid, and immune cells which require mechanisms of drainage and coordination with the peripheral immune system. Failure to do so may result in the exacerbation of a variety of brain diseases like Alzheimer’s, traumatic brain injury, Parkinson’s, glioblastoma, multiple sclerosis and stroke. Our lab discovered that meningeal lymphatic vessels at the cribriform plate near the front of the brain are highly dynamic regulators of neuroinflammation and we seek to understand if local crosstalk between these lymphatic vessels and migratory dendritic cells controls disease related immune response in the brain. Pharmacological manipulation of the cross-talk between dendritic cells and cribriform lymphatic endothelial cells may have potential therapeutic value for diseases of the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) due to Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is clinical stage of AD that precedes the onset of dementia, making it an opportune stage for both elucidating early consequences of AD on neural function as well as identifying novel neural markers of AD that are reliable and affordable. The present proposal will address both goals by using non-invasive electroencephalographic (EEG) measurements to characterize how processing of acoustics and linguistic features of continuous speech is affected in MCI with AD biomarkers, and to assess whether these measures can reliably distinguish participants with and without MCI. These results will represent an initial step towards the longer-term goals of developing more reliable measures of neural function in AD that can be used for tracking of disease progression and evaluation of the effects of novel clinical interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal utilizes a rat model of extended-access oxycodone self-administration to study long-lasting changes in the brain underlying the time-dependent intensification (incubation) of oxycodone craving. We will expand upon the preliminary finding that subanesthetic ketamine doses given during withdrawal can reduce this incubation by examining the duration of ketamine’s effects, the timing and impact of single-dose administration regimen, and the potential anatomical loci and mechanisms that underlie these observations. Determining when, where, and how ketamine reduces incubation will help identify key targets aimed at reducing the neuroadaptations that occur during withdrawal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After years of development and refinement, large-scale genomic analysis has overcome many analytical challenges, enabling researchers like myself to harness its power as a tool to address additional major gaps in human health research. This proposal focuses on developing innovative, quantitative methods and enhancing existing resources that improve phenotype precision, harmonization, integration and accessibility, and their associations with markers of human health. In both the short and long-term, our approaches which refine and improve a diverse set of phenotypes for use by a broad set of investigators across many disciplines will aid in the identification of novel risk factors for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) elevates the risk for life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias. We seek to utilize innovative and comprehensive approaches to examine altered T2DM-related leukotriene B4 mechanisms that promote adverse electrical remodeling and propensity for arrhythmias. We expect our mechanism-based studies to inform targeted therapies with significant implications for safer and more effective clinical interventions.

Therefore, this project will profoundly impact our understanding of autism and will inform future biomarker and therapeutic strategy development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no high throughput genetic methods to uncover mechanisms that drive chronic liver disease's progression to cirrhosis, limiting our ability to develop new therapies. Recently, we showed that some somatic mutations within diseased livers can exert adaptive effects that might benefit tissue health. Using new technologies developed in my lab, we propose to exploit somatic mosaicism as a genetic strategy to 1) identify adaptive genetic pathways and 2) understand how mutant clones expand within chronically damaged tissues, and potentially protect from disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The vast diversity in lifespans among organisms provides a remarkable natural experiment in which to explore the evolutionary innovations that have shaped the extensive variation of this phenotype. Non-human primates in particular represent a critical taxon for understanding the evolution of human lifespan due to their close phylogenetic proximity and broad range of lifespans. Here, we propose to characterize the somatic mutational landscape of aging across multiple tissues in primate species spanning 70 million years of evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Toxoplasma gondii is a foodborne parasite that causes a highly prevalent infection and can lead to life- threatening disease in immunocompromised individuals and the developing fetus. Although it is well documented that immune cells called neutrophils infiltrate the site of acute T. gondii infection, there is limited understanding of how human neutrophils respond to T. gondii. This proposal will characterize and determine the importance of one neutrophil antimicrobial mechanisms in the immune response to T. gondii.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VETERANS ADMIN PALO ALTO HEALTH CARE SYS
PHR: The VA currently provides care for approximately 43,000 veterans with spinal cord injury (SCI), making it the single largest provider of care to patients with SCI. Up to three-quarters of individuals with SCI will sustain a fragility fracture in their lifetime. Half of patients who fracture will experience a serious medical complication. Fracture is a constant concern as seemingly innocuous activities such as joint range of motion exercises and transfers can result in fracture. SCI clinicians have neither evidence-based nor consensus guidelines for assessing skeletal health at the most fragile sites for patients with SCI. As a result, physicians must rely on experience and clinical judgment, rather than data, when recommending whether it is safe for a patient to participate in traditional rehabilitation activities, sports, or when using emerging technologies such as exoskeletons. The goal of the proposed study is to alleviate those shortcomings. Given the long history that VA has played in the care of individuals with SCI, we believe that the field will gain significantly from this research.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Veterans with a lower limb amputation typically use a rigid prosthetic socket that can result in impaired function and discomfort, which could increase the risks of osteoarthritis, leg/back pain, and diabetes/obesity. A prosthetic socket that allows adjustments in volume could alleviate these risks. Thus, we will determine the movements, forces, and comfort/satisfaction of female and male Veterans with below the knee and above the knee amputations using a conventional rigid socket and a novel socket with adjustable panels during walking. These outcomes could improve function and decrease secondary injury risk in Veterans, specifically female Veterans, with lower limb amputations by enhancing the mechanical coupling between a person and their prosthesis and reducing asymmetry. Decreasing residual limb movement within a socket could reduce skin irritation, which could lower abandonment of prostheses. A better fitting socket could improve comfort, which could ultimately improve rehabilitation, function, and quality of life for Veterans with amputations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Two fundamental goals of genetic epidemiology, the estimation of individual-level disease risk and the identification of mutations that cause disease, promise to help inform personalized medical interventions, identify drug targets, and elucidate disease biology. However, existing genetic datasets overrepresent European ancestry individuals, limiting the identification of causal mutations and accuracy of disease risk prediction in non-Europeans populations, exacerbating ancestry-based health disparities. Most methods in genetic epidemiology consider data for one ancestry and disease at a time, whereas we will develop methods that share information across ancestries and diseases to further these fundamental goals in an equitable and powerful way.
