IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Visual injury and disease affect millions of patients annually, but there is still much to learn about the mechanisms that impair visual processing in these conditions. Here, I will determine the chronic effects of an acute injury on distinct subpopulations of retinal ganglion cells, the retina’s output neurons that signal the brain. The results of the proposed experiments could contribute to understanding human diseases that affect the optic nerve, including glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Pathophysiologic disturbances in phosphate homeostasis involving the hormone FGF23, such as those in rare Mendelian disorders or common disorders such as chronic kidney disease (CKD), lead to severe endocrine and skeletal disease. These disorders involve a critical renal-bone regulatory axis and currently have inadequate treatments. We expect that our proposed studies will allow high-level training of a predoctoral fellow and reveal new mechanisms involved in crossover phosphate and localized inflammation providing novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE: Psychopathology places a substantial cost on individuals and society, yet there has been limited success in deriving neuroimaging-based models with enough accuracy to be clinically useful in predicting symptoms. This proposal seeks to integrate two distinct frameworks using a novel multi-task neural network approach that may better capture the neurodevelopmental origins of psychopathology. The overarching goal of this work is to derive accurate neuroimaging-based predictions of psychopathology that can better differentiate individuals and map onto within-subject changes across time, which may prove useful in uncovering novel neurodevelopmental biomarkers of psychopathology.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Transfers into and out of bed for wheelchair users can be dangerous and stressful to both the wheelchair user and caregivers who are assisting them with the transfer. Several mechanical transfer devices are commercially available, but they can be very large, expensive, and difficult to use. The AgileLife Patient Transfer System is a robotic bed and custom manual wheelchair that work together to automatically transfer a person to and from a bed. The goal of this proposal is to adapt the patient transfer system and a standard power wheelchair (Group 3) with seating functions so that the patient transfer system will be able to be used by wheelchair users with more complex and severe impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Inhibiting beta-adrenergic and COX-2 signaling during the perioperative period to reduce  ovarian cancer progression Project Narrative: In women undergoing ovarian cancer surgery, most deaths are related to cancer progression and cancer metastases. Stress and inflammatory responses to having cancer and undergoing surgery have been shown to contribute to cancer progression and metastatic outbreak, and thus we herein propose to treat ovarian cancer patients with repurposed non-patented medications to reduce these deleterious responses around the time of surgery. If this exploratory study will yield promising outcomes on ovarian cancer progression-related indices, including reduced metastatic progression, larger studies will be justified to test long-term survival advantages of this novel approach in ovarian cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Stress is a major contributor to the development and maintenance of alcohol use disorder (AUD). Our preliminary data  in rats show that the neural mechanisms that signal alcohol’s aversive effects, which may serve to limit alcohol  drinking, are dysregulated following predator odor stress exposure. The proposed studies will elucidate the role of a  neural circuit in stress-induced tolerance to alcohol aversion and stress-induced escalation of alcohol self-administration in rats, and inform future research to identify novel targets for the prevention and treatment of AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE People with disabilities, including those who are deaf and hard of hearing, are still vastly underrepresented in STEM graduate education programs, health science professions, and cancer research settings. The University of Rochester James P. Wilmot Cancer Institute, in partnership with the Rochester School for the Deaf, seeks to establish the Future Deaf Scientists program in Rochester, NY and nationwide to inspire, grow, and increase deaf student participation in STEM and cancer research fields. The FDS program is an inclusive mentored research education and training program that empowers deaf high school students to envision themselves as future STEM researchers capable of decreasing cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE- OVERALL While Delaware has high quality healthcare compared to other states, Delaware still has significant inequities in health and healthcare for non-White Delawareans; further, Delaware lags behind other states in a number of areas, including drug deaths, obesity, high preventable hospitalization rates, multiple chronic conditions and cancer. As such, the overarching goal for the continuation of the ACCEL CTR Program is to create a unified Delaware Clinical and Translational Research Community (inclusive of investigators and community members) that breaks down existing barriers, capitalizes on the unique strengths of its partners to establish infrastructure and accelerates the creation of equitable solutions that improve the health of all Delawareans and all Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Resistance to endocrine therapy and recurrence are the leading causes of mortality in breast cancer patients. Prolyl hydroxylation (P4H) is an enzyme that hydroxylates proline into 4-hydroxyproline of collagens. This investigation will uncover a novel uncanonical role of P4HA1 in endocrine resistance by regulation ROS-ER stress pathway, and explore P4HA1 as a novel therapeutic target for endocrine resistant luminal breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT AIKEN
PHR: One third of all human birth defects are associated with craniofacial malformation, such as cleft palate, suture closure defects, or lack of bone formation. We are using the zebrafish model to investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying development of cartilage and bone of the skull and jaw. By identifying the mechanisms producing normal craniofacial patterning in zebrafish we can investigate how disruption of these processes causes craniofacial diseases in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our cells are constantly subjected to DNA damage, with single-stranded breaks (SSBs) being the most common form; fortunately, intricate mechanisms are in place to repair this damage. This research project focuses on unraveling how three essential DNA repair proteins (PARP1, LIG3, and PNKP) mend SSBs within nucleosomes, the physiologically relevant form of DNA. The insights gained through this study hold the potential to develop innovative treatments for cancer and neurological disorders, directly contributing to improved health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Brown adipose tissue in adult humans has been associated with reduced prevalence of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease, suggesting that modulating brown fat function could result in significant public health benefits. Although we have developed an increasingly detailed understanding of environmental and biological determinants of brown fat function in humans, we know very little about its genetic determinants. The goal of this proposal is to identify genetic variants regulating brown fat function that are associated with metabolic phenotypes, determine whether predicted functional variants in brown fat genes regulate metabolic traits, and dissect the function of these variants in cellular models, offering the potential to identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Natural killer (NK) cells play a key role in early control of multiple viral infections. Recent evidence from our group has shown that CD89, the IgA receptor, is expressed on a subset of NK cells particularly enriched in the mucosae. Further, unlike typical functions, this receptor may serve as checkpoint receptor for this cell population. This proposal is designed to explore the biology and therapeutic potential of this novel population. The outcome of these investigations will provide the rationale to further harness NK cells for vaccine design, curative or other therapeutic interventions against HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trichotillomania and excoriation disorder are disabling psychiatric conditions with limited effective treatments. This research uses a series of complementary neurogenomic investigations to significantly advance our understanding of the genes and neurodevelopmental pathways that contribute to these conditions. This is relevant to public health because it advances our fundamental knowledge of the underlying mechanisms that lead to trichotillomania and excoriation disorder, which has the potential to identify novel treatment targets to ultimately reduce the burden of these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health. Metastatic melanoma is the deadliest of all skin cancers and new therapies are needed to treat primary and recurring diseases. The proposed project will identify novel FHP analogues that will be capable of overcoming clinical taxane resistance either as a single therapy or as an adjuvant to existing therapies with broad therapeutic utilities and desirable PK profile. The application will also provide new FHP analogues that are efficient against diverse cancer cell lines, including multidrug resistant sublines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many basic biological processes depend on RNAs that must first adopt specific conformations. Our research will determine how the conformation of a critical RNA element located at the end of the hepatitis C virus genome changes when it interacts with other viral RNAs and how these conformational transitions control essential biological processes like viral replication and assembly. The insights made during this project will elucidate the fundamental biochemical mechanisms governing the function of this specific viral RNA element and contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of the functional capabilities of non-protein coding RNAs.

PHR: Narrative The study aims to develop advanced computational methods to understand how our genes affect our response to disease treatments. By applying cutting-edge techniques like deep learning, we hope to create personalized treatments for various complex diseases, such as cancer, autoimmune disorders, infectious diseases, and more. This research aligns with the NIH’s mission to advance disease treatment and has the potential to benefit many individuals in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) is part of a spectrum of sporadic and hereditary neurodegenerative disorders called α-synucleinopathies (SPs) which includes Parkinson's disease (PD) and Parkinson's disease dementia, with no disease modifying interventions and in which progressive accumulation of intracellular inclusions of the misfolded protein α-synuclein (α-syn) into Lewy bodies in the nervous system is a characteristic feature. Investigators at the University of Florida have developed a novel molecular guided T cell therapy (MCT) that can target patho- logical α-syn, improving survival and behavior and reducing brain microstructural impairment in a preclinical mouse model. This research supplement will evaluate non-invasive and quantitative tracking of this novel therapy in an animal model of LBD using a new molecular imaging modality called magnetic particle imaging, providing a tool for mechanistic studies of MCT accumulation in the brain during LBD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic inflammation and the resulting autoxidation of polyunsaturated fatty acids to lipid electrophiles form deleterious protein post-translational modifications and are major drivers of many human diseases. Our research program will use a model cell system, Staphylococcus aureus, to characterize polyunsaturated fatty acid autoxidation in cells, elucidate the molecular determinants of lipid electrophile formation, and identify the protein targets of lipid electrophiles. These studies will define the molecular interactions in cells that drive diseases associated with inflammation and validate targets for future therapies to treat and prevent these diseases.

PHR: Telomere maintenance is essential for genome stability and the prevention of cancer and degenerative diseases. This project will reveal how various forms of telomeric DNA damage impact telomere function, cellular function and organism health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The chronic comorbidity of migraine and temporomandibular disorders is a significant, but overlooked, public health concern. Its underlying molecular mechanisms are not well understood, and there is a lack of evidence- based treatment approaches. Using a multidisciplinary approach our studies are anticipated to validate S1PR1 as a novel target, with FDA-approved functional S1PR1 antagonists as a unique monotherapy approach, for therapeutic intervention in this chronic comorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The use of medications with risk of harm is prevalent among persons with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) during post-acute care transitions, and associated with dire consequences; yet multiple barriers exist that make it difficult to deprescribe these medications in this population. This proposed study aims to use the mixed methods approach to develop a home-based intervention to improve deprescribing of risky medications for older adults with ADRD during post-acute care transitions that is based on existing services and resources in home health care. Study results and training from this K76 application will result in a potentially sustainable deprescribing intervention based in home health care services, which can improve medication safety and health outcomes of older adults with ADRD during post-acute care transitions and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative Immune checkpoint inhibitor blockade (ICB) with monoclonal antibodies against CTLA-4 and PD-1, is widely used to promote anti-tumor immune responses in a range of human cancers but can also lead to inflammatory toxicities. Colitis is a common and severe type of adverse which can lead to treatment discontinuation. Using a newly developed model of ICB-induced colitis, we propose studies to understand how the microbiota and intestinal immune cells trigger colitis after ICB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative By exchanging genetic variants between populations, admixture has profoundly shaped human population history, courses of natural selection, and phenotypes and disease burdens across populations. Failure to consider admixture or the use of wrong models can lead to major adverse consequences in biomedical applications. This research combines analytical, computational, and experimental approaches, and will generate novel insight into the evolutionary and functional consequences of admixture, improve our knowledge of complex traits etiology, and inform strategies to help reduce health disparity in admixed, underserved populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narratives  Obesity is a risk factor for several diseases, two of which are diabetes and chronic wounds:  85% of adults Americans with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) are overweight or obese,  and 30% of obese adults have the disease.  The overall premises of this proposal is to develop a predictive mathematical model of  obesity-induced diabetic chronic wound that focuses on better understanding the role of  major glucose/glycogen exchange factors, which were previously represented by constant  parameters, by modeling them with variable functions.  This project offers a potential to reinvent the modeling of glucose-insulin dynamical sys-  tem in obesity-induced diabetic chronic wound by enhancing the quality of virtual patients  development, necessary for assessing new experimental or approved drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human disease is inherently heterogenous, and every cell in a person’s body has a different protein expression, presentation of antigens, and structural environment. The proposed research aims to develop microscopy techniques that will allow us to reconstruct not only the three-dimensional structural network of cells and tissues in biological material such as tumors, but also the 3D variation in molecular expression, simultaneously. Such techniques will ultimately allow us to determine how cells and tissue work, or fail to work, cooperatively in the progression of diseases such as cancer and identify new opportunities for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Preventive care with delayed benefits and short-term harms, such as breast cancer screening, may be unnecessary or inappropriate in older adults with AD/ADRD. This project aims to examine the perspectives of older women with AD/ADRD and their caregivers on how they respond to messaging on breast cancer over- screening and make decisions about de-implementation. The results will enhance the generalizability of messaging strategies for reducing breast cancer over-screening from the parent R01 and inform new interventions to de-implement unnecessary or inappropriate care in older adults with AD/ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the genomic basis of traits that affect survival and reproduction is of great importance to understanding human health and disease. Our proposal leverages tissue-specific assays of gene regulation, field collections, and the integration of predictive models for sequence data with population/quantitative genetic approaches to address the fundamental challenge of connecting genotype to phenotype in the premier biomedical mammalian model system (house mice). In doing so, we will address fundamental questions on the evolution of gene regulation and complex traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This R03 project aims to establish the foundation for developing an extracellular vesicle (EV)-based therapy for treating critical Volumetric Loss Defects (VML) injuries caused by traumatic incidents such as road accidents, major falls, or fire breakouts. Specifically, in this project, we will develop a new class of customizable therapeutic EVs by controlled pre-conditioning of parent cells and understand the role of the therapeutic EVs in influencing myogenesis towards healthy muscle formation. The results of this pilot project will set the basis for future elaborate studies that will introduce a full-proof EV-based regenerative medicine therapy for treating patients with critical VML injuries or other injuries that require muscle regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our primary objective is to elucidate the intricate regulatory mechanisms through which membrane lipids and cell signaling pathways modulate voltage sensing of ion channels. By using state-of-the-art techniques, notably patch-clamp fluorescence lifetime imaging (FLIM) and Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET), the proposed experiments will yield comprehensive mechanistic insights. These insights have the capacity to unravel novel therapeutic avenues for addressing disease conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In Type 2 diabetes (T2D), the loss of controlled release of the hormone, insulin, by pancreatic islet β-cells is well-defined as a key event in the transition from insulin resistance to frank diabetes. The molecular mechanisms underlying these defects are not completely understood yet could have considerable therapeutic value if islet β-cell function could be restored. Our studies will use sophisticated imaging techniques to explore how metabolic changes in glucose sensing lead to defects in insulin production in the development of T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perturbations of the intercellular signaling systems that control organ growth are a major source of human disease, associated with a wide range of developmental, physiological disorders as well as most forms of cancer. The proposed research is relevant to public health because solving how such systems normally function to direct as well as terminate growth as organs develop is essential for the development of more effective diagnostic and therapeutic treatments for this enormously broad range of afflictions. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission to reduce the burden to society arising from genetic and environmental disorders of fundamental aspects of human development and physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phenotypic heterogeneity is a process that allows populations of genetically identically bacteria to form behaviorally distinct sub-populations, such as antibiotic tolerant persister cells. Small RNAs (sRNAs) form regulatory feedback loops associated with many heterogeneously expressed processes. This proposal aims to examine how sRNAs contribute to phenotypic heterogeneity in bacteria and how sRNAs themselves are expressed across individual bacteria in a population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The next generation of human health improvements and medical advances will continue to be driven by the ability to use cells as therapeutics. Current strategies to utilize cell-based therapeutics have made remarkable progress but remain limited in terms of persistent efficacy and patient safety in large part because they rely upon disruption of our native genetic code. This project will enable innovative new ways to safely and effectively repurpose human cells as customizable medicines without alterations to the human genome to ultimately prevent and better treat a wide range of human ailments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative (Supplement) This supplement aims to bring Kylie Wright, who is underrepresented (i.e., disabilities, first generation of college, low socioeconomic status, female in neuroscience) in the sciences, our institution, and the U.S., to work under the parent grant (R01AG072658). This project offers an ideal context for Kylie's research and career development, given her future career goals to complete a postdoctoral fellowship and become an independently funded academic scholar on neurobiological and physiological changes underlying decision making in aging/ADRD. Working towards all three parent grant aims, Kylie will have the opportunity to (i) acquire a strong conceptual background in aging/ADRD and decision neuroscience; (ii) gain invaluable hands-on experiences in advanced statistical analysis of behavioral, physiological, and neuroimaging data; and (iii) enhance her academic writing and scientific communication skills via completion of her dissertation and publications/presentations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Hearing loss is a major health problem that is frequently of genetic origin and commonly disrupts the development and function of hair bundles of cochlear hair cells. We propose here to study several genes linked to genetic forms of hearing loss that affect hair bundle development and function. We propose to elucidate the molecular function of these genes and the pathophysiological processes associated with mutations in these genes that cause hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is aimed at the fundamental development of exploiting acetal radicals in organic synthesis to provide rapid delivery of high-value ketones and vicinal heteroatom compounds. This research is poised to tackle challenges in forging challenging C–C bonds to provide chemists with new synthetic capabilities that improve access to pharmaceutically relevant compounds. Specifically, readily available, environmentally-friendly acetals are used to promote reactions that streamline the synthesis to fluorinated ketones and a diversity of chiral molecular scaffolds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human Immunodeficiency Virus Type 1 (HIV-1) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus Type 2 (SARS-CoV-2) remain significant public health concerns. Assembly of HIV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 virus particles occurs within cholesterol-rich membrane microdomains, or lipid rafts. This study will determine how the lipid- raft scaffold protein AnnexinA2 recruits both HIV-1 Nef and SARS-CoV-2 Spike to sites of viral assembly, which may inform the development of novel antiviral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Despite the recent clinical successes of RNA therapeutic systems such as the COVID- 19 mRNA vaccines, there remain fundamental knowledge gaps in RNA therapeutic design and delivery that must be addressed to enable broad clinical translation. To bridge these gaps, the proposed program will develop ultrasensitive multiplexed tools to interrogate how RNA cargo and carrier properties govern functional RNA delivery and how RNA therapeutic systems and the host influence each other. Success of this work will build an integrated understanding of RNA therapeutic system design rules and host factors that govern RNA delivery and individual response.

PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies have confirmed that endocrine interactions play a significant role in causing and contributing to various common health issues, especially obesity, type 2 diabetes, and the resulting cardiovascular problems. The objective of this proposal is to establish a strong connection between mammary gland and metabolic tissue in order to thoroughly investigate the way by which mammokines communicate in health and disease conditions. Our approach involves initially utilizing newly developed precision proteomics, transcriptomics, computational methods, validation, and assess the potential for new endocrine interactions to be used as therapies in mouse models of metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Narrative It is well known that patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) are at a high risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD). However, the choice of antihypertension medications for blood pressure-lowering is still a topic of debate. The differences in the effects of these agents also remain unclear due to the limited number of clinical trials conducted. To address these questions, we will leverage data from two large-scale observational and clinical studies, namely the Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC) and the Systolic Blood Pressure Intervention Trial (SPRINT). Our goal is to exclusively investigate the effects of these medications in CKD patients by employing advanced causal inference techniques. The methods we propose are general and can be applied to other studies and medical specialties facing similar analytical challenges. Software packages and a Shiny app will be publicly available for applications in research and clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – The vast majority of patients with advanced gastric cancers become refractory to anti- HER2 antibody-drug therapies. The use of predictive biomarkers to guide antibody-drug response are necessary for improving survival in patients with gastric cancer and for sparing them from unnecessary toxicity. This proposal seeks to optimize a novel non-invasive imaging approach that can identify the sensitivity or resistance of Trastuzumab-drug conjugates in gastric cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA binding proteins (RBPs) help manage cell functions by interacting with RNA in specific locations within cells, and these interactions can change, especially under stress or in disease. Current techniques struggle to pinpoint these interactions precisely inside cells. Our proposal outlines innovative methods to map these interactions, which could improve the understanding and treatment of diseases linked to RBP malfunctions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the deleterious effects of traditional cigarette smoking have been documented widely, significantly less is known about the health effects and safety profiles of new (introduced widely only within the past 15 yrs) and emerging tobacco products, i.e., E-cigarettes, on the lung. This proposal seeks to expand upon our understanding of the use and effect(s) of new and emerging tobacco products. Through these studies, we will (1) mechanistically investigate the pulmonary consequences of E-cigarette use, or vaping, and (2) whether vaping renders the lung more susceptible to pulmonary disease initiation and progression due to microbial challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a fatal disease with altered epigenomics and associated with high mortality. This proposal will explore if blocking Brd4, an epigenetic regulator, will block the upregulation of profibrotic genes thus alter the cell phenotype. This study will evaluate the efficacy of using Brd4 inhibitor as a therapeutic method to improve the resolution of persistent lung fibrosis; the completion of this study will further our understanding of this deadly disease and uncover novel therapeutic molecular targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This investigation addresses the clinical need to assess the long-term impact of thoracic endovascular aortic repair using multiple endografts for the dissected aorta, by identifying the key biomechanical and hemodynamic features to characterize aortic remodeling. The proposed technology will provide essential data to select the patients who can expect a favorable outcome, help find the optimal composition of devices to treat the patient, provide a reliable guideline for CT-based feature extraction to track the long-term aortic remodeling during the follow-up period and determine the optimal interval to acquire the follow-up CTs. The results data will be applicable to improve the current endograft design to the next level to treat extensively dissected aorta.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Air pollution represents one of the largest public health burdens world-wide and is associated with increased risk of many neuropsychiatric disorders that are characterized by social dysfunction, including autism spectrum disorder (ASD). This project seeks to understand how prenatal exposure to a combination of air pollution and maternal stress (which unmasks vulnerability to environmental toxins) synergize to produce dysbiosis of the gut microbiome, and consequently, disruption of the neuro-immune mechanisms that regulate social behavior. The results of these experiments will answer outstanding questions about the relationship between the gut microbiome and the social brain and how this is impacted by environmental toxin exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: 8. Project Narrative: Overall The increased life expectancy of older Americans makes the maintenance of functional independence a major public health priority. The functional impairments and disabilities that occur in older people can emanate from acute events, such as stroke, heart attack, and hip fracture, or reflect the progression of chronic diseases. The UM-OAIC’s outstanding environment for research and research training in geriatrics, exercise, and rehabilitation sciences allows investigators from multiple disciplines to work together to develop and test novel exercise and activity-based and multi-modal rehabilitation interventions to restore function and minimize disability following acute disabling events and gradual declines related to serious chronic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute and chronic graft-versus host disease (GVHD) remain one of the major complications in allogeneic transplantation, occurring in 40-70% of recipients, particularly when peripheral blood stem-cells are used. We have compelling evidence that co-stimulation blockade with abatacept (CTLA-4 Ig) can significantly reduce grades II-IV and III-IV acute GVHD and that B-cell depletion can prevent and treat the most serious complications of chronic GVHD, while others have shown that post-transplant cyclophosphamide (PTCy) is a powerful strategy to reduce severe acute and chronic GVHD. This study will help us define the superior strategy to prevent acute and chronic GVHD without compromising the graft-versus-tumor effect by comparing the following two rational strategies in a randomized fashion: Abatacept/Tacrolimus/Methotrexate/Obinutuzumab maintenance and PTCy/Tacrolimus/Mycophenolate mofetil.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a devastating consequence of prematurity that results from an aberrant pro- inflammatory immune response and leads to intestinal necrosis. In the United States, NEC has a mortality rate that can approach 50% and is responsible for 1 in 10 deaths in the neonatal intensive care unit. My innovative research program is dedicated to preventing and curing this deadly disease through studies focused on mechanisms of disease pathogenesis, identification of early disease biomarkers, and development of targeted preventative and therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes for these vulnerable neonates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing in noisy listening environments is an everyday challenge that increases in difficulty with hearing loss and normal aging. The proposed research in an animal model advances our understanding of the basic neural mechanisms for perception of amplitude-modulated sounds in noise, which are currently poorly understood. Expanded knowledge of this critical hearing-in-noise mechanism will help lay the groundwork needed for efforts aimed at restoring auditory perceptual abilities in people with hearing loss, ultimately improving quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Surveillance of antimicrobial resistance has traditionally been centralized to research-focused institutes due to the high cost associated with pathogen identification. Given the recent advances in long-read sequencing technologies, we now have the potential to identify pathogens and even antimicrobial bacteriophages with low- cost resources. It is imperative to test the capacity of long-read sequencing in the context of AMR, to reinvent the surveillance of local infection outbreaks as a low-cost decentralized system, where resource-constraint institutes such as California State University, Fresno can play a proactive role in monitoring and investigating drug-resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: . Protein levels of apolipoprotein L1 (APOL1) and other biomarkers in donor kidney tissue from African Americans at the time of transplantation may more accurately assess the likelihood of shorter kidney transplant survival than risks imparted by donor and recipient APOL1 genotypes, and other genetic and non-genetic factors. This application, an ancillary study from the NIH-sponsored APOL1 Long-term Kidney Transplant Outcomes Network (APOLLO) Consortium, seeks to evaluate effects of APOL1 protein levels, APOL1 genotype, and expression of APOL1 and other genes in donor kidneys using state of the art approaches on outcomes after transplantation of kidneys from African American deceased donors. Our results could transform the process of organ allocation in kidney transplantation and optimize survival of transplanted kidneys in the growing numbers of patients with end-stage kidney disease for whom transplantation is their best treatment option.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our objective in this proposal is to provide biobehavioral evidence in support of the idea that discrimination compounds stress in minority populations, and to apply this model of compounding stress to ADRD spousal caregivers. By identifying discrimination as a key factor contributing to disease burden and premature aging in the largest minority in the United States, we may be able to reduce disease burden and chronic stress in underprivileged communities. Additionally, we may be able to learn more about the factors that promote adverse health outcomes in ADRD spousal caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Heparan sulfate (HS) proteoglycans play critical roles development, homeostasis, pathogen infection, and disease development. HS polysaccharides are essential in metazoan organisms and heterozygous defects lead to skeletal and connective tissue disease. Our goals are to provide a structural understanding of HS synthesis and insights into how defects lead to pathology. Unraveling the mechanisms governing HS backbone synthesis will shed light on the molecular basis of HS-mediated cellular processes and potentially for targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance This research is relevant to public health and NIH’s mission because it aims to enable patients who have undergone hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT) to effectively cope with multiple, interfering symptoms – fatigue, pain, and distress – to improve their ability to engage in physical activity that can improve physical disability. Demonstration of efficacy will allow for (1) increased access to and implementation of an efficacious intervention, ultimately reducing long-term suffering caused by cancer and HCT therapy and (2) future work generalizing this efficacious intervention to the growing number of healthcare systems across the US providing HCT patients with home-based care, as well as to other types of cancer and/or chronic disease populations with a similar comorbid symptom presentation. Positive results could lead to a paradigm shift in outpatient care for a cancer patient population who experiences high symptom burden and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Sleep deficiency is common and detrimental in persons with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD), but improved sleep measures are needed to understand of the relationship between sleep and neurocognitive function in ADRD. The goals of the proposed research are to characterize sleep deficiency in persons with ADRD using feasible, accurate, and comprehensive measures and to evaluate the cross-sectional relationships between sleep deficiency, markers of neuronal damage/plasticity, and ADRD pathology. The work proposed may elucidate mechanisms linking sleep deficiency and neurodegeneration and establish targets for future sleep- promoting interventions, ultimately helping to slow progression of disease and improve quality of life in persons with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Human population dynamics and evolutionary history have combined to shape the genomes of people living today, impacting human health, disease susceptibility and our understanding of broader societal and historical questions. We learn about evolutionary processes by studying genetic variation among sequenced individuals, analyses which are grounded in mathematical and statistical innovations. This research will integrate mathematical and empirical approaches to learn key features of our species’ evolutionary history and how that history shapes genetic and phenotypic variation across populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's Disease affects about 6 million people in the United States, every minute one American develops Alzheimer’s Disease. APOE4 is the major genetic cause of Alzheimer’s Disease, more than 60% of the patients have one copy of APOE4 yet this genetic knowledge has not been translated to treatment. Leveraging our recent discovery of an enhancer RNA that regulates APOE expression, this project delves into this regulatory relationship and the function of APOE to set the stage for precision Alzheimer's Disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our physics and biology collaboration will develop new mathematical and gel-based models of eye morphogenesis, and test the models' predictions against experimental data from zebrafish and other organisms. This work will address a basic research need for quantitative eye morphogenesis models, shed light on the biophysical mechanisms of choroid fissure closure and foveal pit formation, and lay groundwork for future studies aimed at treatment and prevention of colobomas, foveal hypoplasia, and other developmental diseases of the eye. Undergraduate physics and biology majors at the University of Northern Colorado will be involved in all aspects of the proposed research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Medical College of Wisconsin hematopoietic cell transplant (MCW HCT) and Cellular Therapy program aims to support the Blood and Marrow Transplant Clinical Trials Network (BMT CTN) as a core center in its mission by leveraging our patient population and faculty expertise in HCT and Cell Therapy for efficient trial conduct in hematologic non-malignant and malignant diseases. In addition, we will build upon our center’s successful development of bispecific chimeric antigen receptor (CAR20.19) T cells as a novel treatment for relapsed B cell malignancies for the treatment of high-risk mantle cell lymphoma. This proposed trial is titled, “Phase II multicenter study of MB-CART2019.1 (zamtocabtagene autoleucel) therapy as frontline consolidation for high- risk Mantle Cell Lymphoma” and is designed specifically to address a priority area of interest identified at the BMT CTN State of the Science meeting in 2021.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) are retroviruses that have colonized the germline to become heritable and in rare instances during animal evolution, specific ERV genes have been coopted to perform host functions. Our understanding of ERV biology, and their contributions to human health or disease, have largely been restricted to their nucleic acid sequences as DNA or mRNA. Using a >40-million-year-old, primate-specific, highly potent cell-cell fusogen of unknown function as our model, we will establish methodologies to study the evolution of functional ERV proteins in cells, tissues, and tractable animal systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative Many increasingly popular study designs in genetic association studies require large-scale hypothesis testing on non-standard hypotheses known as composite null hypotheses. For example, such testing is used to find genetic variants with pleiotropic, mediated, and replicated effects, however the number of validated discoveries remains low relative to the frequency of the investigations. We will develop new methods to perform composite null inference in a robust and interpretable manner, and we will demonstrate the potential of our approaches through application across varied traits.

PROJECT_TITLE: Development of large-scale composite null hypothesis testing approaches to perform translational genetics analyses

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Although it is widely known that people with opioid use disorder struggle to abstain from opioid use even when receiving evidence-based opioid substitution treatment, the cognitive and neural changes that give rise to reuse risk remain poorly understood. In this project, we use new behavioral, computational, and imaging tools to evaluate the role of a potential modifiable neurocognitive mechanism of reuse risk: unrealistic optimism driving more uncertainty tolerant decision making. Ultimately, our findings have the potential for clear benefits in a clinical setting, providing easily implementable tools to monitor and potentially manage reuse risk, and evaluate clinical status in individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The risk of developing mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias increases with advancing age, largely due to declines in cerebral blood vessel function, which is influenced by age-related increases in mitochondrial oxidative stress. As the aging population is projected to increase in the coming years, establishing effective, preventive strategies to improve cognitive function in older adults by improving cerebrovascular function and decreasing mitochondrial oxidative stress is an urgent biomedical research priority. This administrative supplement will assess the efficacy of a new therapeutic intervention – supplementation with the mitochondrial-targeted antioxidant MitoQ - for improving cognitive and cerebral blood vessel function in older adults and assess the possible mechanism(s) contributing to these benefits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Mast cells play a critical role in the induction of immune responses, promoting both IgE-dependent allergic responses such as food allergy and non-IgE-mediated inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. Our studies provide a unique opportunity to dissect the mechanisms by which IL-10 modulates mast cell function in the context of both IgE-mediated activation as well as IgE- independent signals such as IL-33 stimulation. These investigations will not only provide key mechanistic insight into the proinflammatory effects of IL-10 on activated mast cells, but also further enhance our understanding of how mast cells promote the development of allergic responses towards better therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Memories in the central nervous system are an essential component of human physiology and behavior, but whether memory exists in the peripheral nervous system, and in particular the enteric nervous system, remains unknown. This proposal explores the concept of memory engram formation in enteric neurons. The results of this study have the potential to transform our understanding of how the enteric nervous system contributes to numerous functions and diseases of the gastrointestinal tract, ranging from infection and inflammation to metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to understand processes contributing to high rates of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias in Black Americans by examining how the neighborhood environment may interact with allostatic load, a biomarker of stress-related physiological dysregulation, to affect cognitive function among midlife and older Black adults. Therefore, this research can inform the design of interventions and policies to target social-environmental and biological risk factors related to adverse cognitive outcomes, including Alzheimer’s disease, specifically among Black Americans. Moreover, the proposed research is relevant to the missions of NIH and NIA of preventing and slowing the development of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias as well as supporting quality of life among aging Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement The ability to rapidly synthesize a diverse array of chemical structures is critical for the discovery and manufacture of new pharmaceuticals. This work aims to provide two enabling technologies, nucleophilic cobalt catalysis and organic single-electron photoreductants, for the rapid and efficient construction of carbon–carbon bonds. The methods enabled by these technologies will provide new tools for practitioners of medicinal chemistry, streamlining drug discovery and development and thereby positively impacting human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will significantly contribute to our understanding of how exercise interventions impact stem cell aging. By using a multidisciplinary approach, we will uncover the key molecular complement and gene regulatory signatures affected by a conserved cell signaling pathway known for its role to mediate inflammatory responses. Determining how exercise modulates this pathway to render the purported benefits for aging stem cells is critically important for devising intervention strategies to combat aging-induced stem cell impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Prostate cancer patients treated by radiotherapy can experience treatment-related toxicities that have life-long negative effects on health-related quality of life. The proposed studies will investigate if the urinary microbiome changes after radiotherapy, and if any changes correlate with the severity of urothelial toxicity after radiotherapy. These questions will be investigated using both banked urine from prostate cancer patients that experienced bladder toxicities after radiotherapy and urine from mouse studies investigating mechanisms of urothelial toxicity, with the long-term goal of using the microbiome as an inexpensive readout of the susceptibility to radiation toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Delayed Sleep Wake Phase Disorder (DSWPD) is a circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder characterized by a difficulty in initiating sleep at night and subsequent difficulty in waking at times required for work or school. Several distinct phenotypes of DSWPD have been identified with respect to the timing of circadian and behavioral rhythms, as well as the sensitivity to circadian light signals. This project aims to characterize the physiology and behavior of these subtypes, and using that information, develop targeted physiologically informed diagnostic and treatment strategies for these individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Development of medical countermeasures for high-risk chemicals has been limited by several factors, including a lack of standardization among the various experimental models, regulatory constraints faced by individual investigators or small companies, high resource costs to conduct fundamental and translational studies, and a lack of experience in working with highly toxic chemicals. We propose to utilize our established expertise in toxic chemical research to develop a state-of-the-art facility providing analytical and technical expertise to CCRP- supported investigators studying the effects of vesicants and related chemicals in vivo and in vitro using ocular and dermal experimental models, including human microphysiological platforms that increase translational relevance while reducing the need for animal research. It is envisioned this facility will serve as an expert and interactive resource for CCPR-funded investigators to conduct fundamental studies into toxic mechanisms mediating acute injury and chronic injury, as well as early-stage medical countermeasures development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with Down syndrome are disproportionally impacted by Alzheimer’s disease as they age , and current research indicates that TREM2, which is a protein that is expressed in microglial cells in the brain, plays a critical role in the development of Alzheimer’s disease in both this population as well as others without Down syndrome. In this project, we propose to study MS4A molecules-mediated regulation of TREM2 and microglial activation in mouse models of Alzheimer’s disease in Down syndrome by using CRISPR-based genome engineering. Success of this project will significantly enhance our understanding of the molecular processes underlying Alzheimer’s disease in Down syndrome and potentially lead to the identification of novel therapeutic targets, which may hold promise for treating all people suffering fromAlzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neutrophils play a crucial role in establishing innate immunity and must metabolically adapt to persist and perform the inflammatory functions across a variety of metabolic environments during bacterial septicemia. This proposal investigates how neutrophils leverage their mitochondria to sense metabolic disruptions during infection and applies cutting-edge technology to unbiasedly identify alternative metabolic pathways influencing modifications to the epigenome, gene transcription, and inflammatory processes during sepsis. The fundamental insights into the interplay between metabolism and inflammation discerned by this proposal is ideally suited for the Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award and will establish a scientific and technological foundation to expand into novel metabolic pathways, other innate immune cells, and alternative inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to enhance our understanding of cell-specific protein quality control in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). It outlines three goals: establishing the principles governing selection for ERAD and ER-phagy systems, defining the mechanisms by which glycan site occupancy regulates ER quality control, and understanding cell-type specific ER-phagy. By utilizing isogenic induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) derived hepatocytes and neurons, the research aims to shed light on complex protein homeostasis processes, potentially leading to new therapies for protein misfolding disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The amount of genetic shuffling due to meiotic recombination each generation (i.e., recombination rate) has profound effects on patterns of inheritance and is a key modulator of evolutionary processes such as adaptation and speciation. Despite its wide-ranging importance across many domains of biology, we have a poor understanding of how and why recombination rate varies across biological scales. To address this gap, my lab will shed light on the genetic and evolutionary causes and consequences of recombination rate variation in natural populations by testing long-standing hypotheses using modern genomic tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we will characterize the interactions between Pichia pastoris, a protein expression system, and C57BL/6 mice to determine the extent to which P. pastoris can colonize the murine gastrointestinal tract. Our goal is to have P. pastoris survive in the murine gut and secrete β-galactosidase to aid the digestion of ingested lactose. Results from this project will demonstrate the potential of P. pastoris to express other recombinant proteins in the digestive tract of living organisms to either investigate protein function or to be used as therapeutic proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The study of brain recordings can more effectively be pursued by employing machine learning methods that are based on nonlocal equations, due to the highly complex dynamics of the brain. We propose to use models based on integral equations (highly nonlocal) to model and predict brain dynamics. Such models are explainable, in the sense that the self-attention weights of the model can be used to characterize brain dynamics, and therefore develop diagnosis scores.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While oral diseases are extremely common and can meaningfully reduce quality of life, relatively few studies have examined the causes of oral diseases during young adulthood, a time when many individuals experience a transition in their economic and social circumstances that can lead to changes in their behaviors and their risk of disease. This study will collect detailed information about economic status, social environments, and health behaviors, as well as general health and oral health, among a diverse population of college students, many of whom are from disadvantaged backgrounds. Such information will increase our understanding of the early stages of long-term oral diseases, including diseases that can lead to future problems like tooth loss, in order to help develop programs and policies that can eventually improve oral health for everyone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The objective of this project is to prepare Dr. Ian Boys to transition to an independent position as a tenure-track investigator. This project focuses on 1) using structural homology screens to identify and classify antiviral proteins in biodiverse genomes, as well as anti-immune genes in diverse viruses, and 2) the study of protein families that have diverged to serve distinct functions, with some of them evolving to become antiviral proteins. This multidisciplinary evolution-driven study of the biology of infection presents an opportunity to study functional convergence, with implications for our understanding of how proteins evolve to acquire novel function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Perceived social isolation—also known as loneliness—has a significant impact on mental and physical health, increasing risk of death. Individuals (N = 300) with an opioid use disorder reporting perceived social isolation will be randomized to either (1) therapist-delivered Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy for Perceived Social Isolation, (2) therapist-delivered Health Education, or (3) self-guided Health Education. We will assess perceived social isolation, opioid and other substance use, the amount and quality of social interactions, and mental health prior to and up to 6 months following the interventions to see how well the they work compared to each other.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic resistance is currently a major public healthcare concern. Two notoriously hard to kill bacterial, Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. tb), have emerging strains that are resistant to many antibiotic treatments and require new drugs that target alternate biosynthetic pathways, such as DNA biosynthesis. Since M. tb and C. diff use an alternate enzyme, (Flavin-Dependent Thymidylate Synthase—FDTS) not present in humans, to synthesize the essential DNA base, thymine, this presents an enticing new direction to target and inhibit these enzymes providing a pathway towards new antimicrobial agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Life must ultimately balance chromosome compaction and accessibility to proliferate, but how organisms mediate this dynamic challenge is poorly understood. Our discoveries of a bacterial chromosome packing regulator and proteins in bacterial viruses that hijack this and other regulators, have pinpointed the mechanisms that bacteria and viruses utilize to regulate DNA packaging. By studying these mechanisms, our long-term goal is to identify new targets and facilitate development of new antibacterial therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This time-sensitive research study characterizes changes in airborne particulate matter (PM) and its constituents and local population exposure in the aftermath of a policy change to cease open-burn/open-detonation (OBOD) activities at a thermal treatment site that primarily handles munitions wastes in Colfax, LA. Through our work, we will compare concentrations of ambient PM and associated chemicals and their presence in household dust and biological samples at key time periods during OBOD, during site demolition and construction of the closed- burn containment system (CBCS), and at the start of operation of the CBCS in Colfax. We are committed to community engagement best practices including co-production of our study design and frequent report back to community partners to allow for ongoing feedback and input.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Aging is the single most important risk factor for Alzheimer’s Disease AD, yet the transition from synaptic and cellular alterations that occur with aging and lead to cognitive decline to the pathology of AD is not well understood. We have now developed rhesus macaque models of AD, but it has become very clear that in order to fully exploit these models we need to have a comprehensive understanding of the nature and extent of AD- like pathology in normal aging with no experimental manipulation to create an AD model. We will employ the NIA-supported geriatric colony at the California national Priumate Research Center to begin to characterize this interface and potential basis for a transition to AD.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to Veteran health because it focuses on defining the sites (peripheral vascular, mitochondrial, and neuromuscular systems) and underlying mechanisms (elevated ROS) contributing to the exercise intolerance induced by stage I-III breast cancer (Phase A) and cytotoxic and endocrine therapies (Phase B). These results are expected to have an important positive impact because they will provide information that is fundamental for developing targeted therapies to mitigate the systemic effects of breast cancer and cytotoxic and endocrine therapies, thereby preserving quality of life. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the Women Veteran’s health priority research of CSR&D and the VA National Cancer Strategy objective to improve quality of life of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As respiratory infections result in millions of deaths annually, these pulmonary diseases are considered as the global leading cause of communicable mortality. This research proposal aims to investigate the regulatory contributions of chromatin remodeling during the development, maintenance, and immune response of alveolar macrophages to respiratory infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a lifelong chronic condition characterized by platelet hyperactivity and significantly increased risk of thromboembolic disease, the most significant cause of mortality in IBD. Our preliminary research has identified the hyaluronan receptor layilin as a regulator of platelet activation that links inflammation and thrombosis in IBD. Since there are no cures available for IBD, the research proposed in relevant to public health and the proposed studies investigate innate immune mechanisms that are important to the onset and progression of disease which is relevant to the NHLBI’s mission.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Our observation that microglia, key innate immune cells of the central nervous system, are found circulating with cerebrospinal fluid of patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), has led us to hypothesize that these cells are phenotypically unique in different diseases. We will examine patients with MS and ALS to determine any disease-specific features of CSF microglia and explore the nature of these cells in rat models of MS and ALS.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT), the evidence-based psychotherapy for PTSD most frequently delivered within VHA, yields large magnitude reductions in primary PTSD outcomes. Corresponding gains in occupational, social, leisure, and sexual functioning, and in health-related concerns, including chronic pain have also been demonstrated. Despite CPT’s effectiveness, there is room for improvement in overall outcomes (about 2/3 retain their PTSD diagnosis) and patient engagement (35-40% drop out prior to treatment completion). Further, improvements in functioning and quality of life are more modest than those observed in PTSD and associated mental health symptoms. Unaddressed difficulties in functioning contribute to premature dropout from EBPs for PTSD among Veterans. Directly targeting impairments associated with psychosocial functioning has the potential to substantially increase the scope of recovery beyond the core symptoms of PTSD and facilitate greater patient engagement, resulting in more Veterans benefitting from CPT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Loss of function mutations in the voltage gated potassium channel KCNQ1 cause type 1 long QT syndrome (LQT1), a cardiac disorder associated with arrythmias, cardiac arrest, and sudden unexpected death. Previous studies suggest that decreased efficiency of trafficking to the plasma membrane (mistrafficking) may be a common mechanism of KCNQ1 loss of function in LQT1. In the proposed project, I plan to investigate the role of KCNQ1 mistrafficking in LQT1 by classifying the trafficking phenotype of all possible KCNQ1 variants and determine whether KCNQ1 trafficking can be altered with small molecules by performing a high throughput screen for compounds that modify the trafficking of KCNQ1.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Improving stroke-related disability and stroke rehabilitation are major priorities for the VA healthcare system. Over 15,000 Veterans suffer from stroke each year in the United States, the majority of whom have resulting arm and hand motor impairments that limit their everyday function. Current treatment options to improve motor function after stroke are limited. Therapies including neurotechnological approaches (i.e. non-invasive brain stimulation and brain computer interfaces) for motor neurorehabilitation have not yet realized their potential to maximize recovery because the precise neuroanatomic and neurophysiologic mechanisms of upper extremity hemiparesis have not been clearly defined. Dr. Lin’s proposed career development plan has outstanding potential to advance knowledge about the neuroscientific mechanisms of upper extremity hemiparesis after stroke, which is a crucial step towards the development and translation of novel neurorehabilitation therapies to maximize functional recovery, improve stroke rehabilitation, and reduce stroke-related disability for Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a deadly disease of the pulmonary blood vessels that may in part be caused by mutations of a person’s DNA. My proposal aims to establish the role of one such mutation, its regulation of abnormal blood vessel behavior, and its effects on PAH severity. These findings may aid in developing more effective ways to detect and treat this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Vocal folds are the vibrating parts of the human larynx that produce voice. Vocal folds can be damaged from a number of injuries, including surgeries for laryngeal cancer or non-cancerous masses, radiation therapy for other head and neck cancers, smoke or chemical inhalation injuries, and chronic severe acid reflux. Once the vocal folds are scarred, there is little that can be done to restore their vibration. Veterans with vocal fold injuries can suffer disabling voice difficulties with poor voice quality and vocal fatigue. The communication impairment limits social interactions and job opportunities. This project aims to develop an implantable vibrating replacement tissue to restore voice for these Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood-based biomarkers including hyperphosphorylated tau-181 (p-tau181) have emerged as a possible efficient and accurate tool to assist with early detection and disease monitoring for Alzheimer's Disease (AD). However, further validation and understanding of how these biomarkers reflect underlying AD processes and changes in white matter microstructure are necessary. This study will examine the relationships between plasma p-tau181 and the role of early white matter changes in the context of preclinical AD within a longitudinal research cohort with the goal of further validating this biomarker for research and clinical implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Title: Advancing Prevention Research In Cancer through Ontology Tools (The APRICOT project) Project Narrative Research into cancer prevention through behavior change, like other areas of behavioral science, is hampered by imprecision and heterogeneity in the use of constructs across studies and data sets, limiting integration and knowledge accumulation. We have developed a large, semantically rich, Behavior Change Intervention Ontology (BCIO) with associated tools and resources that together provide a starting point for developing an innovative solution to this problem. We will engage with a diverse Community of Practice to set up an ongoing and sustainable program to: (i) enhance and extend the BCIO, specifically focusing on the behavioral cancer risk factors of tobacco use and physical (in)activity, and including causal relations between intervention components and mechanisms of action (processes of change), (ii) integrate the BCIO with other ontologies capturing ‘real-world’ data to better address issues relating to the Social and Environmental Determinants of Health (e.g., poverty, educational level, gender identity and sexual orientation, racial and ethnic group, and built environment), and (iii) develop tools and resources to promote effective and widespread adoption of the BCIO for writing study reports and protocols, and evidence synthesis for theory building and intervention development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The purpose of the current proposal is to understand the molecular structure and functional interactions of human telomeres. A related goal of this project is designed to identify the molecular changes in telomere proteins that are the result of diverse pathogenic mutations and the associated interference related to nucleotide concentrations and administration of nucleotide/nucleoside analogs. This knowledge is a prerequisite to developing rational drugs for treating human disease related to telomere dysfunction, aberrant DNA damage, and chromosome instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic diseases such as autoimmune diseases are genetically complex and it is hard to predict whether certain mutations increase disease risk and how they increase disease risk, especially when they are not present in DNA regions that directly code for proteins. In this proposal, we will utilize and develop holistic approaches to systematically investigate how specific regions of the genome affect the long-term gene function in T lymphocytes, a class of cells that are highly relevant in autoimmunity, and to delineate how these regions ensure that T cells remain fit and protect against disease. Once we define the importance of these genomic regions on long-term gene function, and unravel how they alter disease, we will be able to develop appropriate therapeutic strategies to reduce poor disease outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Proper epigenetic gene regulation is required for health and often disrupted in disease. Metabolism supports this regulation by converting nutrients into usable chemical forms for the placement of a one- carbon unit, known as methylation, onto chromatin. The goal of this research program is to use quantitative metabolism techniques to investigate how metabolic homeostasis is achieved through production of these one-carbon units to meet demand for methylation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will characterize the poor outcomes of Shigella diarrhea that can be prevented by appropriate antibiotic treatment and evaluate strategies to identify Shigella at the point-of-care to target therapy. The results from the study will define the value of targeted treatment interventions for Shigella and optimize their implementation. Targeted treatment of Shigella may reduce morbidity and mortality from Shigella diarrhea among children in low-resource settings while reducing antibiotic use for diarrhea overall, limiting antimicrobial resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, working-age adults (age 20 to 64 years) in rural areas experience significantly higher cardiovascular mortality rates than their urban counterparts due to worse access to care and a higher burden of risk factors, and there is concern that the spillover effects of the COVID-19 pandemic (disruptions in care, unemployment, financial strain) will further widen these inequities for years to come. We will use a combination of national datasets to understand changes in access to care and cardiovascular health for rural working-age adults after the pandemic, determine the potential effects of lowering the age of Medicare eligibility on access to care and the screening, treatment, and control of cardiovascular risk factors for this population, and evaluate whether the expansion of broadband internet in rural areas under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (2021) leads to increased telemedicine use and improvements in cardiovascular health. The identification of policies that improve access, care delivery, and cardiovascular health in rural communities could have major public health implications, and ultimately inform strategies to address rural-urban inequities nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Product labeling for the nicotine concentration of liquids used in Electronic Nicotine Delivery Systems (ENDS) currently is not sufficiently informative to the public, so this project will improve upon FDA-required labeling of ENDS nicotine concentration by producing an optimized nicotine concentration label that is linked to an objective scaling metric: the nicotine content of combustible cigarettes. We expect our new concentration label to improve understanding of the nicotine strength and, secondarily, addiction potential of ENDS liquids among youth and adults. The project also will generate data on the utility of labeling nicotine emissions from closed- system ENDS (i.e., non-refillable pod/cartridge-based devices and disposables) via nicotine flux, a complex but potentially more informative index of nicotine from closed-system ENDS that better approximates nicotine delivery than does liquid nicotine concentration alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Opioids interfere with the normal functioning of brainstem circuitry that controls breathing leading to respiratory depression and cessation of breathing (apnea). The proposed studies will provide mechanistic details on the neurons that continue to function unopposed during opioid exposure to determine the role of these opioid- insensitive neurons in respiratory failure. The outcomes of this research will advance our understanding of the pontomedullary circuitry that controls breathing and mechanisms of opioid-induced respiratory depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses the mutation process, which gives rise to genetic variants that are responsible for heritable disorders and cancer. This work will significantly advance our understanding of how fundamental evolutionary forces influence genome maintenance. By testing theories for how DNA replication and repair processes evolve and mechanistically affect the genome, this research will improve our ability to predict genetic change, which is relevant to the core mission of the NIGMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narratives The progression of complex diseases, such as cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and diabetes, is driven by interactions among various cell types present at disease sites. This project aims to develop innovative computational methods for inferring the cell-type-specific protein dysregulation. Successful completion of the project will significantly advance the translation of both current and emerging large-scale proteogenomic data into accurate protein-based clinical biomarkers and effective therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Enzymes are dynamic and flexible proteins that catalyze chemical reactions in the living cell. These motions are vital to the proper functions of these enzymes as well as the discovery of drug candidates to modulate the activity of these molecules. The project studies the dynamics of enzymes involved in metabolism by time-resolved structural methods and develops techniques to observe the movements of these flexible proteins in response to stimuli, which will improve our understandings of these important molecules.
