IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will provide novel large-scale data on emerging workplace practices in the service sector related to surveillance and sanctioning, schedule unpredictability and constraint, and automation, and assess their implications for worker’s health and healthy aging. Our study will reveal how temporal dimensions of job quality differentially affect health across the life course and how social supports at the individual and macro levels may buffer any negative effects on health. The proposed data collection will take advantage of natural experiments at the local and company level that induce exogenous changes in job quality and thus build the evidence-base on the effects of emerging workplace practices on population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research aims to uncover the molecular function of the retinal disease gene H3.3 in retinal cell fate specification and differentiation. Individuals with mutations in H3.3 have devastating neurodevelopmental issues and specific mutations have been linked to retinal degeneration. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative HIV-uninfected individuals born to mothers with HIV are known to exhibit adverse health outcomes in early life, yet the long-term clinical consequences for this population – exceeding 18 million people worldwide – are largely unknown. This project will delineate metabolic and immune sequelae of in utero HIV exposure among HIV- uninfected young adults, and identify mechanisms that may contribute to these outcomes. Only by characterizing lifelong disease risk among HIV-exposed but uninfected individuals can we optimize screening, prevention, and treatment strategies for this group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE  The cytochrome P450 4F (CYP4F) family are fatty acid -hydroxylases and involved in generating lipid mediators from arachidonic acid, the clearance of drugs, and the metabolism of vitamins and proinflammatory eicosanoids. They are associated with human diseases such as hypertension, cancer, and traumatic brain injury, yet little is known about their cellular function and their structural properties. The Brixius lab proposes in-depth functional and structural studies to unravel their role in cellular processes and their association with human disease using cell biology, biochemistry, and X-ray protein crystallography.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed administrative supplement project builds on the parent grant, “Advancing Geriatrics Infrastructure and Network Growth,” which bridges the Health Care Systems Research Network, and the Claude D. Pepper Older Americans Independence Centers to advance an interdisciplinary research agenda focused on older adults with multiple chronic conditions, including persons living with Alzheimer’s disease. The work undertaken under the proposed supplement will develop and validate a claims-based algorithm for important safety-related events relating to novel therapies for Alzheimer’s disease and create a protocol for data linkages between registries and national health plan administrative data. This work will lay the groundwork for assessing the safety of anti-amyloid therapies for Alzheimer’s disease in real-world settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative  Telehealth is one of the most promising tools to help increase buprenorphine treatment for people with opioid use disorder (OUD), yet we know little about effectiveness of telehealth compared to traditional in- person care, which limits use and poses a major barrier to developing evidence-based policies and implementing high-quality care. The overall goal of this project is to generate clinical guidance to optimize buprenorphine care by evaluating effectiveness of telehealth-delivered buprenorphine, including for high-need and high-risk populations, using novel target trial methods, and incorporating stakeholder perspectives and expert consensus. This study will use national data from the Veterans Health Administration and Medicaid, encompassing the largest U.S. provider and payer for OUD services, and incorporate novel methods to systematically inform best practices for tele-buprenorphine care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Martell project narrative Technologies that enable the identification of which proteins reside in specific locations inside cells are critical for elucidating biological processes and disease states, including neurodegeneration, pathogenic infection, and cancer. One promising strategy to achieve this goal is proximity labeling (PL), but in order to enhance the sensitivity and specificity of proximal protein detection, improved PL catalysts are needed. We propose that hybrid biological-abiotic PL catalysts developed in our laboratory will enhance both sensitivity and specificity in spatially- resolved proteomic mapping, and we are employing these catalysts in neurons to benchmark their performance against existing methods and establish their broad utility as research tools.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) macrophage therapy offers great promise against solid tumors including glioblastoma (GBM). Our current study proposes an innovative strategy to use exosomes-loaded with mRNA encoding a CAR that targets the epidermal growth factor receptor variant III (EGFRvIII), a mutant receptor expressed in 40% of GBM, to produce CAR macrophages in vivo for GBM immunotherapy. If successful, the results generated from the proposal will pave the way for a new strategy to produce CAR cells in vivo and greatly expand the utility of cell therapy against GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with advanced cancer experience substantial prognostic uncertainty, leading to increased psychosocial burden, which, in turn, contributes to worse survival. The proposed research will examine the psychosocial sequelae and their biological and social determinants among patients with advanced (i.e., recurrent) head and neck cancer receiving immunotherapy. Findings from biological determinants will be instrumental in developing individual, personalized, and targeted interventions; those from social determinants will be informative for public health and community-level interventions, with an ultimate goal of using multilevel (combining individual and community) to improve psychosocial outcomes and, subsequently, QOL and long- term survival for those with advanced diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Many neurodegenerative diseases that result in dementia involve misfolded proteins that can cause normal proteins in cells to clump. Recently, injection of these misfolded proteins into the gut of mice have been shown to cause protein misfolding in the brain, suggesting a gut-to-brain transmission route. This proposal investigates if a brain scan can detect brain transmission before symptoms appear, and if the same brain scan can detect the ability of exercise to slow brain spread.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drug discovery is expensive and time consuming, and applying computer-based rational design in the early stages can accelerate the process and lower costs. However, computational investigations of carbohydrates, nucleic acids and fluorescent molecules are challenging to simulate without inclusion of complex physics. This proposal aims to combine simulations, high quality automated database generation, and the development of machine learning models in order to understand the binding and behavior of carbohydrate-based heparanase inhibitors as possible anti-cancer drug targets, and the photophysical behavior and connection to structure for fluorescent nucleic acids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed study fills a major gap in knowledge about how state medical and adult-use (i.e., recreational) cannabis laws have impacted opioid receipt and pain outcomes in cancer. We will triangulate findings from a quantitative policy evaluation with information from surveys and interviews that explore cancer centers’ implementation of state cannabis laws, physicians’ practices for recommending, and patients’ practices for using cannabis for cancer pain. To inform a rapidly evolving policy landscape—in which states are continuously considering, enacting, or expanding cannabis laws— it is essential to understand how these laws affect pain management practices and outcomes for patients with cancer as one of the largest groups of consumers of therapeutic cannabis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary cilia concentrate molecular machinery of all major signaling pathways thus allowing cells to communicate with their environment, and cilia defects cause a spectrum of disorders called ciliopathies. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to identify new genes and map pathways in cilia assembly and post-developmental remodeling. This fundamental knowledge has the potential to facilitate development of therapeutic strategies to manage human conditions caused by anatomical and functional cilia abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This application describes a novel mechanism of liver injury caused by the anti-leukemia drug PEGylated asparaginase (PEG-ASNase) involving drug-induced activation of adipose triglyceride lipase (ATGL) and the onset of adipose tissue lipolysis leading to liver injury. PEG-ASNase is a crucial drug used to cure leukemias; however, its use in adult patients is largely avoided due to its high risk of liver injury, which is hallmarked by the onset of hepatic steatosis. The goals of this project are to elucidate the mechanism of PEG-ASNase-induced liver injury and to identify pharmacological strategies that can prevent PEG-ASNase-induced liver injury, increase ALL survival rates, and extend the therapeutic benefit of PEG-ASNase to adult patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol-induced analgesia is a phenomenon related to two major public health problems in the US: alcohol use disorder and pain conditions. Alcohol confers analgesic effects in a dose- dependent fashion, but the genes and networks underlying this heritable process are poorly characterized. In this training proposal we will study the genetic aspects of ethanol-induced analgesia in mouse models using the complementary, genome-wide methodologies of behavioral quantitative trait locus mapping, differential gene expression analysis in critical brain regions, and weighted gene co-expression network analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Medicinal chemistry has historically been driven, to great positive effect, by organic chemistry. There are, however, medicinal problems that can best be solved by exploiting the unique chemistry of inorganic compounds; this research program will broadly take the approach of identifying and solving such problems. During this award period, the focus of the proposed research program will be on the development of (i) a small-molecule metalloporphyrin-based antidote for carbon monoxide poisoning and (ii) an understanding of the biologically relevant chemistry of the pentavalent antimonial drugs used to treat the neglected tropical disease leishmaniasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The inability to quickly and accurately diagnose tuberculosis (TB) in children and initiate treatment is a major contributor to the high mortality of childhood TB worldwide. This study will identify novel Mtb- and host-derived biomarkers, and determine the best biomarker panels (i.e., biosignatures) that can meet the World Health Organization-recommended diagnostic accuracy thresholds for a TB triage or diagnostic test. If successful, the results will the first step needed to make progress toward addressing the critical unmet need for non-sputum biomarker-based tests for childhood TB.

PHR: Polyomavirus (PyV) is a DNA tumor virus responsible for causing many debilitating human diseases, ranging from neurological disorders and kidney diseases to cancer. At the cellular level, PyV must target to and enter the host nucleus in order to cause infection. In this proposal, we intend to investigate how the prototype PyV SV40 exploits the actions of two nuclear membrane protein complexes – LINC and NPC – to reach the nucleus enabling infection.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gonadotropin surge-induced ovulatory changes include the infiltration of leukocytes into the dominant follicle, implying a significant role of leukocytes in the ovulatory process; however, underlying mechanisms remain elusive. Our pilot single-cell transcriptomic data using human follicular aspirates revealed specific cytokines produced by leukocytes and their corresponding receptors in follicular cells, indicating a collaborative role of leukocytes and follicular cells in successful ovulation. Consequently, the proposed study will characterize leukocyte-derived cytokines and their receptors in the human dominant follicle and elucidate their actions and roles in periovulatory granulosa cells, thereby better understanding the mechanisms of how leukocytes facilitate the ovulatory process and luteal formation in the human ovary and its impact on female fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE – PARENT GRANT Intestinal parasites, including soil-transmitted helminths (STH), infect over 1.5 billion people worldwide, resulting in a massive global burden of disease. Mass drug administration (MDA) to high risk populations is the cornerstone of the global strategy for controlling STH infections; however, varied MDA program success indicates that re-infection from environmental reservoirs is common. This proposal leverages a novel, sensitive and specific molecular assay to detect STH DNA in large volumes of soil within a multi-country community-wide MDA randomized controlled trial to define, for the first time, the impact of an MDA intervention on soil reservoirs of STH, and to evaluate the potential for using soil STH DNA as a non-invasive surveillance tool to monitor human infection prevalence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary vascular remodeling is a critical hallmark of Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension. Nicotinamide phosphoribosyltransferase (NAMPT) has been shown to promote pulmonary vascular remodeling, and its inhibition can be a potential therapeutic target. The proposed research will seek to elucidate cellular and metabolic mechanisms governing how NAMPT contributes to PAH pathobiology via metabolic reprogramming mediated pulmonary vascular remodeling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the advancements in the management of propionic acidemia (PA) through dietary interventions, patients with PA still experience complications, and there is currently no effective drug treatment available. In this project, we propose to explore the potential of using triacetin to rebalance the acetyl-CoA/propionyl-CoA ratio for the treatment of PA. The anticipated outcome of this project is to enhance the therapeutic effectiveness of PA management, increase tolerance to dietary protein intake, and reduce the complications associated with a low- protein diet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed clinical trial addresses the significant challenge of relapse prevention post-allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (alloHCT) by introducing a novel strategy that simultaneously suppresses graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and enhances graft-versus-leukemia (GVL) effects. Utilizing a pioneering combination of post-transplant cyclophosphamide (PTCy) with sirolimus and VIC-1911, an oral selective Aurora kinase A inhibitor, the study aims to harness the benefits of selective immune modulation while eliminating the broad immune suppression of tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil. This innovative approach aims to establish a new standard for GVHD prophylaxis that reduces the risks of both GVHD and relapse, leveraging the University of Minnesota’s longstanding and productive collaboration with the Blood and Marrow Transplant Clinical Trials Network (BMT CTN) to accomplish this goal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is an allergic disease of the esophagus partially mediated by epithelial barrier breach, resulting in normally harmless antigens penetrating the underlying tissues, encountering immune cells, and initiating allergic responses. We uncovered that the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) acts as a sensor molecule that in response to divergent environmental signals can maintain epithelial homeostasis or elicit innate immune response. Thus, we suggest that AHR plays a key role in EoE pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative After a fall-related trauma, evidence indicates older adults living with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) spends substantially less time at home after injury than those without ADRD; however, there are currently few useful tools to help clinicians prognosticate home time for patients with ADRD. Thus, the overall objectives of this administrative supplement expand meaningfully on the parent grant research and career development goals supporting additional research and training to 1) develop, validate, and assess the equity of a predictive tool designed to help clinicals prognosticate home time for older adults following fall- related trauma, and 2) determine how older adults living with ADRD, their care partners, and clinicians caring for them could best utilize these predictions to guide care decisions. Using prediction model outputs as a starting point, this project will inform an R01 testing tailored care pathways based on these predictions to optimize home time for older trauma survivors living with ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In view of the ongoing threat of mass casualties due to radiological accidents or nuclear terrorism, there is an urgent need for blood assays that determine radiation exposure and predict injuries that may follow. This joint project aims to develop a novel multi-component blood assay that reconstructs absorbed radiation dose and at the same time predicts injury in the heart, one of the organs at risk for long-term loss of function due to radiation exposure. This work will create a novel concept for minimally invasive assays that streamline treatment decisions for victims of a nuclear event.

Teefe MD PROJECT NARRATIVE: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) and tic disorders, including Tourette Syndrome (TS), are debilitating neuropsychiatric conditions with few effective treatments. This research project integrates neuroimaging and genetic techniques to deepen our understanding of the genes and neural pathways contributing to these disorders. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative. Communication between the lymph node and the organs it drains is imperative for predicting immune responses to vaccination, infection, and chronic disease, but have been difficult to study in vivo or in vitro. To address this gap, we will develop a user friendly, microscale system specifically co-culture intact samples of live tissue from the lymph node with other organs and allow recirculating of white blood cells between them as occurs in vivo. After determining the effects of various modes of fluid motion on intact lymph node tissue for the first time, we will generate a simple model the response of the lymph node to vaccination, as a proof-of-principle of this new system for modeling multi-tissue immunity outside the body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disruption of the enzymes that write and erase DNA methylation is associated with numerous diseases, including cancers. Despite their fundamental importance, the genetic mechanisms that regulate methylation writer and eraser genes during development remain poorly understood. We will uncover the mechanisms that regulate writer and eraser genes over the cell cycle and during tissue and organ development, as well as during tissue aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental exposure to neurotoxicants including pesticides is strongly linked to the etiology of Alzheimer’s disease, yet the mechanisms by which these exposures contribute to Alzheimer’s pathology and neurodegeneration remain poorly understood. Building on our existing NIEHS-funded R01, we will employ an innovative suite of imaging, genetic, and biochemical tools in combination with induced neurons (iNs) from male and female Alzheimer’s disease patients and unaffected individuals to answer longstanding questions about the mechanisms by which environmental toxicant exposures drive Alzheimer’s disease pathology. These studies will also provide the basis for a larger Alzheimer’s focused R01 grant to uncover how gene-environment interactions contribute to Alzheimer’s disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal is relevant to public health because there is currently no available treatment for children with long- segment airway defects. Tissue engineering has the potential to replace diseased tissue with healthy, living tissue capable of repair and growth. A composite tracheal graft that possesses the mechanical properties needed to maintain graft patency and the biocompatibility to support regeneration will provide a viable solution for this complex population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Population-level maltreatment prevention could significantly improve public health, but it is not yet clear how to prevent maltreatment at scale. The proposed project will estimate the potential for major social safety net policies (EITC, CTC, SSI, TANF, SNAP/WIC, and Medicaid/CHIP) to prevent neglect and physical abuse in young children. To accurately and comprehensively identify the policies with the greatest potential impact, the project will measure and account for the ways that policies interact with one another and examine effects on both maltreatment-related injuries and Child Protective Services reports.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emergency Departments (EDs) are increasingly providing the first line of clinical contact for adolescents with suicidal ideation and attempts, many of whom remain at high risk for recurrent crises following discharge. This proposal will lead to a novel text-based intervention supporting parents in engaging in recommended suicide prevention activities to promote post-discharge youth safety. Findings from this study will inform a scalable intervention approach intended to improve post-ED continuity of care and reduce youth suicidal behavior and related crises during a high-risk care transition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, the long-term durability of a gene editing therapy for Duchenne muscular dystrophy will be assessed in a humanized mouse model. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biliary atresia is a neonatal inflammatory, sclerosing lesion of the bile ducts that results in cirrhosis. This proposal will determine the mechanism of neutrophil extracellular trap formation (NETosis) in biliary atresia and the role of NETosis in promoting fibrosis. Knowledge gained could result in the identification of novel therapeutics targeting NETosis, thus preventing cirrhosis in children with biliary atresia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Candida albicans is a commensal fungus that colonizes the intestine of most healthy people but has the capacity to cause infections and exacerbate inflammation in susceptible people. Immune status determines risk for C. albicans-associated disease, but the impact of immune environment on C. albicans inherent pathogenic potential is not well understood. This proposal aims to comprehensively define the impact both homeostatic and pathogenic immune environments on C. albicans pathogenic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The mission of this grant is to form a network of established blood and marrow transplant centers, such as the Stanford BMT-CT Program, that will collaborate and conduct impactful multicenter clinical trials investigating leukemia, lymphoma, and myeloma, as well as non-malignant diseases such as sickle cell anemia and aplastic anemia. The Division of BMT-CT at Stanford has been an outstanding contributor to past CTN clinical trials with 579 patients enrolled on 25 clinical trials and has been an active participant in CTN committees and related activities. The trial proposed in the current application aims to identify a safe and novel GVHD prevention strategy in patients lacking HLA matched donors, and if successful, will address a main complication that limits safe allogeneic transplantation and is a major source of morbidity and mortality following allogeneic HCT for patients with ALL, AML, or MDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapies have emerged as a revolutionary advancement in the treatment of many advanced malignancies and have shown remarkable promise in a variety of non-malignant disorders. However, Cytokine Release Syndrome (CRS) represents a major cause of morbidity associated with CAR T-cell therapy. Enhancing the safety and efficacy of CAR T-cell therapy through the amelioration of CRS represents a significant unmet need, and it has the potential to dramatically improve outcomes and further expand the clinical application of CAR T-cell therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Both HIV and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) establish life-long infections that, despite the development of antiretroviral therapy and antibiotics, cause millions of deaths every year, emphasizing the need to develop a cure. This proposal aims to define the methods by which HIV and Mtb evade immune-mediated clearance by characterizing their common target cell, the macrophage, and how this cell acts to shield these pathogens from immune responses. Insight into these mechanisms will help identify macrophage-specific pathways that can be exploited to make these infected cells more susceptible to immune-mediated clearance, potentiating the development of cure-based strategies for HIV and Mtb infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inflammation is a major contributing factor in many leading causes of death, including heart disease and associated pathologies such as ischemia-reperfusion injury. Adhesion of neutrophils to the vessel wall, followed by infiltration into damaged tissues causes inflammation that is known to make injuries worse. This study will uncover new neutrophil adhesion mechanisms in inflammation, provide crucial insights into cell adhesion, and facilitate the development of novel drugs to limit tissue damage associated with inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: This pilot study evaluates associations between exposures to perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) and weight lost during a 10-week weight loss intervention among Hispanic children with overweight and obesity. We will quantify the association between 12 different PFAS measured in pre-intervention blood specimens collected from children at baseline and weight lost during the intervention, as well as with clinical biomarkers of metabolism, lipids and hormones measured in baseline blood specimens. The results will help to improve understanding of the impact of PFAS on weight loss in children with overweight/obesity, and will inform an R01 application to support a larger, more definitive and mechanistic future investigation of PFAS exposure and children’s weight loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studying the fundamentals of how retinal neurons and circuit ensembles respond to signaling deficits can provide valuable information as we seek to better understand and treat blinding diseases. This grant application proposes experiments that will deepen our mechanistic understanding of neural compensation in the retina and define the cellular and synaptic deficits of severe congenital stationary night blindness. The knowledge gained from these experiments will be applicable across neural circuits, as manipulation or replacement of integral circuit elements becomes leveraged for therapeutic advancements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The retina is an excellent model system for studying the function of specific neuronal subtypes within a circuit. This proposal uses a genetic approach to target a previously uncharacterized population of glycinergic amacrine cells to define their morphological properties and to test the hypothesis that this population provides inhibitory input to the direction selective circuit. It will also test whether the selective expression of Robo3 in this population is required for their proper development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A surprising revelation from the research on adaptation is that directional selection often generates significant functional diversity. In this proposal, I will test two mechanistic hypotheses in order to understand the fundamental reasons behind this peculiar phenomenon. This project will enhance our general understanding of adaptive processes and have implications for developing therapeutics for diseases that are caused by evolving entities, such as cancer and treatment-resistant pathogens.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Narrative This grant aims to improve predictability and reliability of radiation sterilization of medical devices by using com- puter modeling. Current standard of practice is to address sterilization once the product is fully developed as a manufactured device is needed. Our approach allows sterilizability to be assessed with a computer model of the device early in the development process, thereby lowering development cost and risk, facilitate regulatory deci- sion, and ultimately leading to lower cost and safer medical devices.

PROJECT_TITLE: Virtual dose mapping for radiation sterilization

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The mammalian genome is protected by an intricate network of host repair proteins that are responsible for maintaining the fidelity of the genetic code. Viral pathogens have evolved unique mechanisms to hijack these proteins to either cause cell death or long-term disease, but their mechanisms of action remain unknown. We propose to develop a research program that integrates cutting-edge genomic, proteomic and imaging technologies to dissect how host replication and repair proteins are usurped by DNA viruses, identifying new targets for therapeutic intervention to improve human health.

PROJECT_TITLE: Defining how cellular DNA replication and repair machinery are hijacked by viral pathogens

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this proposal is to identify inherited genetic variants non-coding RNA sequences that are associated with susceptibility to arsenic toxicity, and to understand their mechanisms. The successful identification of such variants will improve our understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved in host defense against and susceptibility to arsenic toxicities. The results of this study may improve identification of individuals at an increased risk of arsenic-induced lesions and provide candidate, therapeutic targets to decrease their risk of developing lesions after arsenic exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biomolecular condensate assembly is tightly regulated within cells, and failure to control condensate properties such as formation and dissolution has been linked to human disease. This research program will define biochemical and cellular mechanisms that dictate the regulation and function of biomolecular condensates in native cells. A detailed understanding of these molecular mechanisms is critical for furthering our understanding of how biomolecular condensate function in healthy cells and are dysregulated in human disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chimeric antigen receptor T cells, or CAR T, are engineered white blood cells from patients that destroy cancer. CAR T has the potential to cure several blood cancers. We will test a new approach to not only prevent these severe side effects, but also reduce cancer relapse after CAR T, by using the medications dexamethasone and anakinra.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacterial lower respiratory tract infections are of great public health interest since they are a leading cause of mortality and morbidity in children. However, their genetic and immunological drivers in humans are, for the most part, unknown. We have identified the first cases of human TANK deficiency in patients with recurrent life- threatening bacterial lower respiratory tract infections and we will decipher the role that this molecule has in human immunity, B cell function and human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to stop an action is essential for successfully navigating everyday life. Loss of this skill is a hallmark in many neurological disorders, including alcohol use disorder. Brain regions responsible for action control, like the globus pallidus (GPe), are sensitive to alcohol-induced changes, but the underlying complexity associated with this brain region and lack of detailed movement tracking have hindered a deeper understanding of the underlying mechanisms. This proposal describes experiments using new tools and high-resolution behavior analyses to define the neural basis of GPe activity both in states of health and disorder to further our understanding of how those experiencing alcohol use disorder struggle to inhibit their actions in relationship to their alcohol use.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual and gender minority (SGM) couples in the U.S. in general wish to have children and grow their families; however, having children for SGM couples is complex and expensive. There is a relatively large literature on how factors like finances may affect parenting decisions for SGM couples but little research has looked at whether deciding when and whether to have children may also be influenced by the impacts of state and local laws and public opinions about SGM people. This proposal aims to understand multiple levels of influence on SGM couples' decision-making about whether and when to have children—and to examine changes over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on measuring the cellular effects of dihydroxyacetone (DHA) exposure in pulmonary and cardiovascular models to better understand the inhalation exposure effects of DHA. DHA generated by e-cigarettes is inhaled by vapers, enters cells, and is incorporated into metabolic pathways causing metabolic changes and mitochondrial damage. These changes will directly impact pulmonary and cardiovascular cell homeostasis, cause severe declines in cellular function, and may even induce cell death. This work will establish critical links between DHA exposure and disease for e-cigarette users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Tufts IRACDA program provides comprehensive postdoctoral training for outstanding scientists who seek academic careers that combine cutting-edge research, teaching, and mentoring, while ensuring that our nation’s biomedical workforce is diverse. The structured training program provides scholars with tools needed to establish independent research programs, develop and deliver cutting-edge courses rooted in best pedagogical practices, and mentor diverse groups of students. By building teaching and research partnerships with three local institutions that serve students from a variety of racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic backgrounds, Tufts IRACDA will inspire the next generation of scientists and provide them with opportunities and experiences to launch impactful careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative. The main objective of this application is to understand the molecular mechanisms of how RNA- methylating enzyme complexes, RNMT/RAM and METTL3/METTL14, are regulated by post-translational modifications (PTMs). Protein semi-synthesis strategies will be used to install site-specific and stoichiometric PTMs, non-hydrolyzable mimics, and chemical probes to evaluate how these marks influence the structure and function of these complexes, impacts their cellular biology, and characterize the molecular machinery that modulates their presence. Results from these studies can pave the way for the rational design of new therapeutics to treat a variety of human disorders, including cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The project aims to investigate the mechanisms of a novel age-related endogenous protein, activated protein C (APC) in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This study elucidates the capacity of recombinant APC derivatives in protecting neurofunctions in AD via regulating glucose metabolism and inflammatory responses. The findings could lead to novel therapeutic strategies aimed at preserving the neurofunctions from AD in the elderly.

PHR: Project Narrative IMPACT: This project expands the reach of evidence-based cancer symptom cluster self-management to rural, underserved communities through a clinical trial. We leverage the power of technology to improve access via telemedicine and mHealth. An effective, accessible, brief alternative to medication-based symptom management is essential given the limited availability of palliative and psychosocial care for advanced cancer patients, especially in rural communities, and the impact of these symptoms on functional status, quality of life, and treatment tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) has been subject to antibiotic selection in human populations for almost 80 years. We have used population genomics to identify Mtb genes undergoing diversifying selection in clinical strain since the onset of antibiotics. By phenotyping isogenic Mtb strains engineered to carry clinically prevalent variants, we have uncovered a new form of altered drug susceptibility, a recovery phenotype that we call antibiotic resilience. Mtb strains with resilience mutations which are subject to a period of drug exposure recover and begin to grow significantly more rapidly than wildtype strains. We have identified clinically prevalent resilience mutations in four essential regulators and their binding sites; we further find that these regulators regulate each other in modulate expression of key cell growth and division genes. Here we will mechanistically dissect the transcriptional regulatory network underlying antibiotic resilience through three aims: (1) “Define the resilience regulatory response under drug and host relevant conditions” in which we will generate and transcriptionally profile Mtb strains with resilience mutations; (2) “Determine the mechanistic basis of network-associated transcription factor functions under drug- and host-relevant conditions” in which we will use biochemical and structural approaches to determine the functions of the regulators with novel mechanisms of action and the impact of the clinically prevalent variants; and (3) In mouse models, “Test the hypothesis that antibiotic resilience mutations allow Mtb to escape drug and host selection in vivo”. These studies will elucidate the genomic and protein changes underlying resilience, a clinically relevant, previously unrecognized form of drug escape in Mtb, and our findings may inform future treatment and surveillance strategies for TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The global burden of sepsis is concentrated in sub-Saharan Africa, where poor understanding of sepsis pathobiology is a fundamental barrier to the development of effective treatment strategies. The goal of this project is to stratify sepsis patients in Uganda into biologically driven and therapeutically relevant subtypes. Our results will inform design of the first precision medicine clinical trial of sepsis treatment in sub-Saharan Africa and improve sepsis treatment outcomes in high HIV-burden settings worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of this project is to develop an innovative, sensitive, specific, and more accessible spatial method to correlate metabolic changes associated with cellular manipulations. We propose combining multiple phasor approaches - the phasor approach to Fluorescence Lifetime Imaging (phasor-FLIM, for metabolic imaging), phasor approach to hyperspectral imaging (sp-phasor, protein expression/ membrane fluidity) and phasor approach to Fluorescence Correlation Spectroscopy (phasor-FCS, protein diffusion). This method will allow us to connect changes in one dimension (e.g., protein diffusion) to the changes in another (e.g., metabolism) in a pixel-wise manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Given that the median age of patients diagnosed with most hematologic malignancies is 65 or older, improving allogeneic blood and marrow transplantation (alloBMT) outcomes in older patients is critically important. Our preliminary data suggest clonal hematopoiesis (CH) in older alloBMT recipients is associated with significantly increased NRM. Detection of CH may add important prognostic information to current risk stratification strategies for older patient, and it may be possible to ameliorate the effects of CH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The biology of all multicellular organisms relies on the ability of individual cells to communicate with their neighbors, and breakdowns in cell-cell communication are inextricably linked to a broad range of diseases.This proposal outlines a plan for a careful and quantitative dissection of receptor protein oligomerization (clustering), a major class of cell-cell interactions that has been particularly difficult to study experimentally due to the small size and fleeting nature of such molecular clusters. Using Eph receptors in human cells as our primary model system, we plan to combine advances in optogenetics, genome editing, single-molecule fluorescence imaging, and high-throughput sequencing to simultaneously advance our understanding of Eph receptor biology and develop new strategies for probing key oligomeric transitions in living cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Microbial keratitis, a leading cause of worldwide visual impariment, disproportionally affects people with lower socioeconomic status. The National Eye Institute’s strategic plan highlights the critical need for point-of-care strategies to diagnose microbial keratitis. The proposed research will create open-source novel machine-learning algorithms to identify causative organisms of microbial keratitis at the point-of-care, using low-cost images and data from geographically-diverse cases, and integrate this information into a decision tool to inform treatment decisions for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), which are widely used in non-stick, water-resistant, and stain- resistant coatings for consumer products may adversely impact bone health. We have an excellent opportunity to capitalize on pre-existing, prospectively collected data and biospecimens for an innovative exploration of whether PFAS affect fracture risk, bone mineral density, and markers of bone turnover using prospective data from three established cohorts. Our work may suggest vital opportunities for fracture prevention via reduction in use of these chemicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lipids, or fats, play an important role in regulating how cells work; accordingly, when lipids are located in the wrong locations within a cell, devastating diseases can occur, like Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. This proposal seeks to functionally characterize a novel protein that regulates transport of lipids within cells. We expect this work to provide new insights into the causes of lipid-related diseases and inform the development of new treatments for these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enhancers are non-coding regulatory elements modulating gene transcription in human diseases. We will develop computational methods to dissect enhancer function through data integration and machine learning of eight epigenomic features across hundreds of human cell types. The findings will fill up missing enhancer profiles and generate tools to prioritize enhancers’ impacts in human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed PAINT, Precise Area INtroduction and Transfection, technology will be a method for highly localized, versatile, efficient biochemical delivery for “direct-write” guided administration at single cell to multi-cell resolution. The utility of this novel approach to cell modification rests on its adjustable resolution, rapidity, versatility, and ease of use: PAINT permits the simple and quick production of heterogeneously modified samples, including in vitro cell and tissue cultures. This research is relevant to public health because it will enable the in vitro growth of realistic organoids useful for modeling human physiology and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly every step of HIV-1 replication is regulated by a dynamic set of interactions between viral and cellular RNA binding proteins and viral RNAs. In this application, we propose to identify new rules by which HIV-1 selectively packages its RNA genome and why it preferentially packages a dimeric genome. We will also define the interdependence of NC-gRNA interactions with other viral and host RNA-binding proteins that bind to the same gRNA at different phases of virus replication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene expression is organized into diverse, droplet-like structures called transcriptional condensates in both the eukaryotic nucleus and the mitochondria. Here, in the context of biomolecular phase transitions, we will investigate how biomolecules–including the mitochondrial genome, its gene expression machinery and its RNA products–assemble and persist as disparate condensates within mitochondria. By studying the emergent structure-function relationships of mt- transcriptional condensates, we will determine the biophysical driving forces for the spatiotemporal organization of gene regulation in mitochondria and how anomalies contribute to mitochondrial (dys)function, with implications for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research proposal seeks to define how vaccination alters the course of gammaherpesvirus infection in immunocompetent mice, using the murine gammaherpesvirus 68 model system. While there is clear evidence that the immune system can limit gammaherpesvirus-induced infection, the stage at which infection is disrupted and the cell type(s) involved in protection remain poorly defined. By analyzing viral infection and immune parameters associated with control of gammaherpesvirus infection in the context of vaccination, these studies seek to address this gap in knowledge of gammaherpesvirus infection and disease in susceptible populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infections are one of the leading causes of mortality in kidney transplant recipients who have weakened immune systems because of immunosuppressive therapy. Identifying kidney transplant patients at high risk for future infections could lead to interventions such as more intensive screening or decreasing immunosuppression. In this study, we plan to develop gut-based, blood-based, and urine-based microbial biomarkers for diagnosing and predicting infections in kidney transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As an increasing number of older adults are suffering from Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRD); providing them with quality care in long term care (LTC) facilities is becoming problematic due to resource limitations, nursing shortage and high turnover among LTC nursing personnel. A novel approach to utilize socially assistive robotic systems that can meaningfully engage this group of older adults through physical, cognitive and social activities is proposed in the hope that such smart technology will be able to augment, and not replace, the current system of care. This study will contribute to the development of improved intelligent technology as an effective approach to engage older persons with dementia with the long- term goal of enhancing their function and quality of life as well as improving LTC staff satisfaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most firearm deaths are suicides, and over half of suicides involve firearms. Further, nearly half of firearm suicide descendants were intoxicated at the time of death making alcohol use a key modifiable risk factor for reducing firearm suicide, which is essential to ameliorating the public health crises of suicide and firearm mortality and injury. We propose to integrate the study of suicide, problematic alcohol use, and firearm access into a coordinated line of research using survey data, qualitative methods, and ecological momentary assessment to advance our understanding of firearm suicide and identify key points for intervention to reduce its harms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This program centers on developing new organometallic catalysts that can selectively activate different groups on organic molecules according to the wavelength of light irradiation. This will allow for the iterative synthesis of biological targets in one-pot, facilitating rapid access to chemical libraries for medicinal screening and the optimization of biological function. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Bioelectronic implants provide powerful tools for healthcare as well as basic research but their implantation require invasive surgery which is associated with pain and adverse physical as well as psychological effects. We are developing a technology in which ultra-miniaturized bioelectronic devices can get implanted in target regions and provide localized sensing and treatment without the need for surgery. This administrative supplement will extend our technology to Alzheimer’s disease which can lead to a novel therapeutics for preventing the spread and even development of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolites inside cells can directly regulate chromatin, the mixture of DNA and proteins in the cell nucleus. Polyamines are abundant metabolites essential for multiple biological processes, but their mechanisms of action remain poorly understood. In this proposal, we explore the hypothesis that polyamines concentrate in specific areas of the nucleus, where they bind and regulate chromatin and ultimately control cell identity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE S1P lyase insufficiency syndrome (SPLIS) is a rare inborn error of metabolism associated with kidney failure and a high rate of mortality. SPLIS is caused by inherited defects in a critical enzyme needed to break down sphingolipids. In this study, we will test whether enzyme replacement therapy using a bacterial form of S1P lyase given intravenously can prevent kidney disease and prolong survival in two different mouse models of SPLIS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson’s Disease, Huntington’s Disease, and Alzheimer’s Disease are characterized by drastic impairments in planning and decision making, some of which stem from deficits in estimating durations. By investigating timekeeping we aim to understand the circuits involved in planning and decision making. The project will enhance our understanding of the role of these circuits in cognitive control, and will help assessing potential treatment strategies in animal models with subsequent impact on clinical treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 1 in 250 newborn boys has a birth defect known as hypospadias in which the opening of the penis is on the underside instead of at the tip. Parents of boys with this condition frequently experience decisional conflict when deciding upon treatment and regret their decision after treatment. The goals of this project are to a) test whether a tool, the Hypospadias Hub, can reduce the amount of parental conflict and regret and improve parental knowledge by increasing parental involvement in complex decisions regarding their child’s treatment and to b) improve the quality of decisions in pediatric urology and overall child health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Communication that includes the child’s perspective and can be understood and acted upon by parents and clinicians is key to managing symptoms associated with childhood cancer and its treatment. The proposed project will develop and test an intervention to improve symptom communication during early childhood cancer treatment using Color Me Healthy, a game-based symptom assessment app for children. We will develop and test a clinician-facing version of the app that allows children’s data to be included in the electronic health record to improve communication about children’s symptoms during clinic visits.

PHR: Project Narrative Common genetic variation contributes substantially to human diseases. A deep understanding of the functional impact of common genetic variants is required to identify disease-causal variants and decipher disease mechanisms. We propose to bridge the gap from genetic variants to diseases by integrative analysis of functional genomics and genome-wide association studies (GWAS) data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many RNA species within a cell are spatially localized and locally translated into proteins, and previous studies in embryos, neurons, and highly-dynamic tissues have demonstrated the vital importance of RNA subcellular location in development and cellular function. However, it has been challenging to study localization transcriptome-wide, which has hampered understanding of the extent and role of such processes in normal and diseased tissues. The proposed work will apply a newly-developed tool for the RNA community to investigate spatial transcriptomics and use it to provide new insights into RNA biology by determining the contribution and regulation of cytoskeletal motor proteins and associated factors to actively transport specific RNAs to their destinations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Healthy individuals have a tremendous ability to heal after injury, which involves complex and coordinated actions of various cell types acting across sequential healing phases in space and time. This project aims to understand how oral wounds, which heal better and faster than skin wounds, optimize the healing process, and how chronic diseases such as diabetes and cancer corrupt the healing process. We will focus on studying these differential healing outcomes using an innovative analytical approach that takes into account cellular dynamics across the healing continuum in both space and time, with the goal of identifying important gene signatures in cells that may lead to new targeted therapies for chronic wounds and tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Metabolite damage and repair is a widespread and universal reality of life and disruption of repair systems causes metabolic diseases that can be fatal, yet metabolite damage remains largely unrecognized and understudied. I have identified and laid the groundwork for full characterization of a universal metabolite damage repair enzyme that is critical for operation of the TCA cycle. By characterizing this enzyme in model organisms with biochemical, genetic, and metabolomics/ fluxomics techniques, I will redefine one of the most universal core metabolic pathways in biology, providing mechanistic insights into aerobic respiration that are likely to impact human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Low oxygen delivery (hypoxia) to the developing brain is the leading cause of life-long neurological disabilities in preterm babies and is linked to learning disabilities and memory problems. This proposal focuses on the impact of a single exposure to mild hypoxia in the newborn period on long-term disturbances in the maturation of neurons responsible for mechanisms of learning and memory in adults. We will employ novel approaches to define cellular and molecular mechanisms that disrupt the establishment of learning and memory circuitry during a critical window in brain development and will test potential new therapies to improve learning and memory disturbances caused by Hx in the newborn period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research aims to understand the diversity of strategies used by the natural predators of bacteria, the bacteriophages, to kill their host targets. By studying how phage kill bacteria in depth, we can formulate new strategies to eliminate problematic pathogens that cause human disease. Thus, this proposal supports the NIGMS mission to fund research laying the foundation for advances in human disease treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Microglia and the complement pathway play critical roles in Alzheimer’s disease. The proposal seeks to understand the role of complement and associated metabolic pathways and identify novel cell-surface receptors in microglia regulation in vitro and in AD mouse models. It will provide novel pathophysiological insights and uncover potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative More than 20 million newborns worldwide each year are considered to have low birth weight (weighing less than 2,500 grams or approximately 5.5 pounds) and experience a higher rate of complications than those whose birth weight is considered normal. Prior studies have suggested that screening for asymptomatic bacteria in the mother’s urine during pregnancy and treating with antibiotics (nitrofurantoin) may reduce the incidence of low birth weight. This study explores the impact of treating asymptomatic bacteria in the urine of pregnant individuals in low- and middle-income countries, where the burden of low birth weight is the highest and the potential impact of intervention is the greatest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain metastasis is a prevalent and deadly condition for patients with metastatic breast cancer currently with no effective pharmacological interventions or cures. Our recent work suggests that Yes Associated Protein (YAP) promotes breast cancer cells’ metastatic growth in the brain through its interaction with TEAD family transcription factors; the use of YAP inhibitors to disrupt YAP-TEAD association can be a promising therapeutic approach for brain metastasis, but its practical untility is hindered by the limited accumulation of these drugs to multi-focal metastatic lesions because of multiple biological barriers such as the blood-brain and blood-tumor-barriers. Here, we propose to engineer drug nanoparticle-coated macrophages to target “hard-to-reach” brain metastatic lesions for efficiently disrupting YAP-TEAD interactions in metastatic cells, which can potentially revolutionize how brain metastasis is targeted and pharmacologically treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The family of anti-obesity drugs called glucagon-like-peptide 1 receptor agonists (GLP1RAs) have contributed revolutionary strides in combatting obesity—a growing epidemic that is estimated to affect approximately 40% of adults and 20% of adolescents and children in the US. Despite an emerging consensus that these peripherally administered GLP1RAs exert their effects on appetite suppression through the central nervous system, knowledge of the neural pathways and intracellular signaling mechanisms by which they act and how these may change over long-term usage remains limited. Given the continued prevalence and chronic nature of GLP1RA medications, my work to elucidate the intracellular and circuit-level processes of GLP1RAs in a longitudinal manner will provide foundational insights toward the improvement of pharmacological therapeutics to treat obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Emerging pathogens are continuously evolving their infective mechanisms to alter host cellular responses to establish a niche and successful infection. In the wake of increase in Legionnaires outbreaks, the ability of Legionella pneumophila, to modulate diverse number of eukaryotic cell processes to survive and multiply in macrophages, is of public health concern. Thus, in-depth understanding of infection strategies from Legionella studies can help to design effective therapeutic strategies and preventive measures against intracellular bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The number of older adults who are 60 years and older undergoing hematopoietic cell transplantation as part of cancer treatment has more than doubled in the past decade. Older adults undergoing transplants are at high risk of experiencing a decline in cognitive function afterwards that can affect day-to-day function and quality of life. Our project seeks to understand the relationship between cancer-related cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly half of adults in the United States have or are at risk of developing type 2 diabetes. The overall goal of this community-engaged research is to examine the efficacy of an innovative couple-based lifestyle intervention to prevent type 2 diabetes that is applicable to a broad range of partnered adults in the United States. By simultaneously targeting lifestyle and perceived support from romantic partners, there is a high likelihood of creating lasting changes in both.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (of Parent Grant: R01HL164348)  Stem cell-based regenerative therapies or in vitro investigations of cardiovascular disease pathophysiology, drug screening, and toxicology studies heavily rely on stem cell quality. Here, peptide nanostructures will be engineered to enable cells to be light responsive in a wireless and non-genetic manner, which can ultimately be utilized as a strategy for converting optical cues to stimulatory signals that can improve the structural and functional maturity of human stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes. With this new approach, we hope to alleviate the major technical barrier of CM immaturity, and therefore, better enable stem cell-based cardiovascular research and related fields to flourish.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Guidelines recommend use of individualized care plans (ICPs) as an important tool for improving sickle cell disease (SCD) care quality based on data from the emergency department. However, literature addressing ICP use for inpatient care is sparse and we do not know the best way to use ICPs for hospitalized patients with SCD. This proposal will engage adults with SCD and healthcare team members in 1) adapting ICPs from the emergency department to the inpatient care setting and 2) testing the feasibility of using ICPs for inpatient SCD care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  The long-term mission of the Vanderbilt Vision Research Center (VVRC) is to leverage novel technologies, strategies, and partnerships to (1) understand the biological substrates of vision and mechanisms of diseases affecting the visual system and (2) leverage this knowledge to inform, develop, and test new therapeutic strategies for vision-threatening conditions. Proposed service modules will support and enhance innovative and novel approaches spanning genes and proteins to brain circuits and behavior to better understand vision and ways to preserve it in aging and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Fiehn laboratory at UC Davis will collaborate with the Metz laboratory at PNNL and the Evans laboratory at University of Michigan to develop and validate the LC-BinBase database as generic workflow for liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry data in metabolomics and lipidomics. We aim to standardize metabolomics data processing across different mass spectrometry instruments, for different data acquisition methods, and across laboratories. We will validate result data for biofluids (plasma, urine, saliva), for different animal tissues and for cell cultures to yield reproducible and harmonized data sets that are easier to interpret for biomedical scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aberrant retinal neovascularization impairs visual function in various disease statements including retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) and proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). Although intravitreal (IVT) injections of anti- VEGF treatment options exist, many patients are refractive to therapy due to the complex pathogenesis of neovascularization, and there is a high treatment burden associated with IVT injections. Thus, the proposed research will investigate the role of the redox function of Ref-1 in retinal neovascularization and investigate the effects of an orally delivered small molecule inhibitor of Ref-1 as a novel therapeutic for retinal neovascularization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will study the impact that natural locomotion has on two key visual areas in the mammalian brain: primary visual cortex and superior colliculus. It will therefore have a direct impact on our understanding of how the visual system functions under natural conditions, thereby contributing to an overall greater understanding of active vision as well as visual impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health and aligns with the NIH’s mission because understanding the biological forces that shape and underlie variation in health outcomes is a necessary step toward personalized medicine. The proposed work will combine experimental evolution, model systems, genetic sequencing, and molecular phenotyping to study what drives differences in rates of senescence and type 2 diabetes susceptibility between individuals. Moreover, findings on how the relationship between different levels of biological organization impact organismal phenotypes could be generally useful for understanding variation in health-related traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will determine if human enzyme therapy is a tractable therapeutic strategy for cystinuria, and therefore has the potential to improve quality of life for the thousands of patients who suffer from this rare disease. It may also relieve a significant burden on the public healthcare system, as patients with this disease undergo numerous medical and surgical interventions throughout their lifetimes. Long term testing will be employed to ensure that this therapeutic approach is safe and well tolerated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 250,000 children survive pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) hospitalization each year, and many suffer persistent problems with pain and sleep that can significantly impact long-term health and well-being. Our study will be the first to longitudinally evaluate risk factors for chronic pain and sleep disturbances in PICU survivors and to determine how pain and sleep impact key long-term executive function outcomes in these children. Data from our study will inform interventions aimed at identifying and treating pain and sleep problems to optimize PICU survivorship.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C) affects girls and women throughout the world, with 3 million girls cut each year, and resulting in significant reproductive, sexual, and mental health needs for impacted patients. Implementation and evaluation of healthcare provider training programs are a top research priority to meet these needs while also creating systemic change. This project aims to conduct a rigorous (1) needs assessment, (2) build a training curriculum, and (3) conduct a randomized controlled trial of midwifery, nursing, and medical students in Tanzania, a high prevalence FGM/C country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy ends in preterm birth (PTB) for approximately 1 in 10 women, though more often for Non-Hispanic Black women, with 14.12% PTB rate, compared to 9.09% for Non-Hispanic White women. Racial and ethnic differences have also been reported in dietary behaviors in response to stress and economic adversity such as food insecurity. In this project, we will identify nutritional profiles of pregnant women with food insecurity and psychosocial stress, determine racial and ethnic differences in nutritional profiles by food insecurity and psychosocial stress experiences, and evaluate whether nutritional profiles affect the pathway by which food- and psychosocial-related stress contributes to increased risk for PTB among racial and ethnic minoritized women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transmembrane protein 178 (Tmem178) mediates a novel endogenous inhibitory mechanism in asthma. This project will characterize the role of Tmem178 in bronchial epithelial cells and asthma pathogenesis. Understanding the mechanism of Tmem178 action could lead to the development of novel strategies to inhibit lung inflammation and restore homeostasis in the asthmatic airway epithelial barrier.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: The PTCTC is the largest pediatric-focused hematopoietic stem cell transplantation consortium in the world. In this proposal we describe our plans and desire to continue to be a core clinical consortium (CCC) of the BMT CTN. These include (A) Detailing our unique capabilities of the PTCTC within the BMT CTN; (B) Proposing a clinical trial to optimize the conditioning regimen for children and adults with Inborn Errors of Immunity (IEI); and (C) Describing the operational and scientific approach of the PTCTC to HCT trials, and how this approach could benefit the BMT CTN. The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because it aims to improve clinical outcomes for patients that are undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, for both malignant and non-malignant hematologic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed supplement will investigate the contribution of extrahepatic metabolism by human and mouse cytochrome P450 enzymes influences neurotoxic outcomes in experimental animals exposed to LC-PCBs in the maternal diet throughout gestation and lactation. These outcomes are relevant to public health because they will provide data critically needed to assess the risk these emerging environmental contaminants pose to the developing brain and provide insights regarding strategies for mitigating this risk in vulnerable human populations. Therefore, the proposed research is pertinent to the part of NIH’s mission that seeks to develop fundamental knowledge about living systems to enhance health and reduce the burden of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stochastic fluctuations in gene expression impact cell-fate specification decisions from embryogenesis to viral infection creating barriers for effective treatment interventions. Based on therapeutic precedents in neuroscience that use fluctuations to improve sensorimotor function, this project will identify centralized molecular and cellular mechanisms of noise modulation, that can be therapeutically targeted, in embryonic stem cells (ESCs). The proposed research will lead to development of new broad-spectrum noise modulators, and propel clinical translation of noise-modulating molecules to guide new therapeutic approaches that overcome barriers to precise cell-fate control in diverse mammalian systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Neovascular age-related macular degeneration is a leading cause of blindness in elderly Americans and is currently treated by drugs with limited efficacy and high rates of developing subretinal scar that hinders visual acuity improvement. This project will investigate causal link between the current drug therapy and the scar. More importantly, this project will develop a novel therapy that can alleviate the disease without causing subretinal scar for better efficacy to improve vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Research narrative Resilience to perturbations is a fundamental property of biological systems, and the brain’s highly parallel and redundant information processing provides a likely substrate for resilience. This project aims to elucidate principles of modular information processing that produce the brain’s resilience to neuron loss. Understanding these principles is crucial for understanding how brains react to neural degradation in disease.

PROJECT_TITLE: Dissecting modular and redundant organization of cortical circuits

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ocular hypertension due to decreased aqueous humor drainage from the trabecular meshwork is a major but a modifiable risk factor for glaucoma, one of the leading causes of blindness worldwide. Based on our promising and novel supporting findings, this proposal will investigate whether dysregulation of the Wnt and other related signaling pathways in response to elevated levels of cell surface proteoglycans (Glypicans) plays an etiological role in inducing ocular hypertension via aberrant stimulation of trabecular meshwork contractile activity, cell adhesive interactions, and barrier activity. These studies are expected to identify the prominent upstream molecular pathways involved in ocular hypertension and support the identification of new molecular targets for the development of efficacious treatments for glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The current approach for peripheral artery disease (PAD) management is to reopen arteries with a “one size fits all” intervention that does not consider the composition of the plaque, which contributes to the high failure rate of the intervention. To solve this problem, we propose a two-pronged approach to improving PAD management utilizing a novel MRI-histology protocol on below-the knee arteries: 1) creating an MRI-based plaque scoring system that predicts intervention success in vivo and 2) using detailed plaque analysis of vessels ex vivo to assess the degree of vessel wall injury resulting from orbital atherectomy in various plaque types and evaluate its potential in reducing dissections in concentric calcium plaques. This will empower clinicians with objective, rational, and personalized approaches that decrease immediate failures and optimize device choice for PAD interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Alzheimer’s disease and related disorders are hallmarked by impaired proteostasis, which facilitates pathologic protein aggregation and causes neuron degeneration. A more detailed understanding of the dysregulation of proteostasis associated with the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease will enable the discovery of new effective and durable therapies. Here, we will employ a strategy that uses novel tools to reliably detect protein AMPylation with increased sensitivity to deliver a fundamental understanding of how changes in FICD- mediated protein AMPylation affect proteostasis in the brain of Alzheimer’s disease patients and predispose neurologically unaffected controls to a neurologically degenerative state; this is a prerequisite to therapeutically target this enzyme to improve health and fitness of the aging human brain.
