PROJECT_TITLE: Conserved regulation of proteostasis by post-translational protein AMPylation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research proposal aims to define the proteomic and functional profile of peripheral sensitization in human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC)-derived sensory neurons. We will employ a human cellular model of pain and integrative strategies encompassing stem cell technology, electrophysiology, proximity labeling, and ribosomal and protein sequencing methods to examine for alterations in key molecular signaling pathways and functional expression of cell surface proteins associated with peripheral sensitization. The overall goal of this research is to identify potential biomarker signatures and candidate genes that can be therapeutically leveraged to prevent or alleviate pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Site-one protease (S1P) is a protease within the human secretory pathway that activates signaling pathways for lipogenesis, ER stress, and lysosomal biogenesis; and is also exploited by some viruses. This research proposal aims to understand how a recently discovered co-factor protein called SPRING or C12ORF49 activates S1P so that it can proteolyze its substrates. A mechanistic understanding of site-one protease function and its activation by SPRING may lead to new molecular approaches to target this critical enzyme and ameliorate metabolic disorders like fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cardiovascular health of young women, especially women of color and low-income women, is poor during and after pregnancy, but we know little about the reasons for this and what to do about it. Although it is well accepted that a healthy diet is one of the most important behaviors people can target to prevent cardiovascular disease, research is needed on diet among young pregnant and postpartum women. Our work will guide the design of programs to alter diet to improve young women's cardiometabolic health and reduce its inequalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The major goal of the project is to develop potent small molecule and peptidic inhibitors and proteolysis- targeting chimeras for the ENL YEATS domain that plays a significant role in leukemogenesis of cells with the mixed-lineage leukemia (MLL) gene rearrangement. These molecules can be potentially used to treat MLL- rearranged leukemia that has a high fatality rate in patients. Therefore, the proposed research is highly relevant to public health and NIH’s mission in promoting health and combating diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Uncontrolled asthma in school-aged children is a significant public health problem. Low-SES Latino children are at increased risk for uncontrolled asthma compared to non-Latino white children, and psychosocial stress is an unaddressed factor in this disparity. Therefore, the proposed intervention targets coping with stress as a way to reduce risk for uncontrolled asthma in low-SES Latino children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Both ethnic/racial minority and college student populations suffer from sleep disparities, including short sleep duration, poor sleep quality, and irregular sleep schedules. Yet, there is scant longitudinal research exploring the mechanisms and pathways through which race-related sleep disparities impact health and academic outcomes concurrently and over time among diverse college students. The current study employs an innovative combination of daily diaries and actigraphy, biannual surveys, annual dried blood spot biomarker samples, and anthropometric assessments to investigate the impact of sociodemographic and environmental stress on race-related sleep disparities from the first through senior year of college; informing researchers, public health experts, and educators about the social-biomedical mechanisms through which stress impacts ethnic/racial minority health and academic disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH This study will provide new information about how social stressors contribute to obesity among Mexican and Filipino American women. Specifically, it tests the hypothesis that stressors lead to eating behaviors and dietary changes and that alter the brain-gut-microbiome axis. A better understanding of the role of how stress “gets under the skin” to contribute to alterations in the brain and gut microbial metabolites in obesity, could lead to novel therapeutic strategies tailored to treat altered ingestive behaviors and obesity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the U.S., the childhood obesity epidemic disproportionally impacts minority communities, particularly Hispanic children. Minority populations face multiple psychosocial stressors at the individual, household and community level that are associated with increased obesity risk. This research will establish the biological embedment of early-life adversity at the individual, household and community level on epigenetic marks, with the goal of developing early-life biomarkers of risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Latinos have been disproportionally represented among COVID-19 cases and deaths in the United States. Latinos with diabetes are at particularly high risk given that diabetes is associated with poor outcomes including death. In addition, Latinos have been dramatically impacted by sequelae of the pandemic including a steep rise in household food insecurity, which leads to worsening glycemic control for those with diabetes. Effective multilevel interventions that can be remotely delivered are urgently needed for Latinos with diabetes to mitigate disparities due to COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Stage 3 efficacy study aims to inform health policy by testing a novel intervention that directly reduces the racial income gap by providing a universal basic income (UBI), which is intended to promote and protect Black men's health through the influx of capital and subsequent increases in personal agency and social connections. We hypothesize that (1) providing UBI of $500 per month for six months will result in increased healthcare utilization among chronically-ill, older and aging, low-income Black men; and (2) the effect of UBI will depend on whether an individual has a recent history of incarceration, such that no incarceration history combined with UBI will demonstrate the best study outcomes. Empirical research examining UBI among older Black men and its capacity to overturn structural racism are lacking in the extant literature—much of the health disparities research intended to inform health and economic policy originated from limited perspectives of older and aging Black men—Dr. W.E.B. Du Bois said in The Souls of Black Folk that for Black people, “discouragement is an unwritten word”; this study draws on that inspiration as it ultimately seeks to fundamentally overturn the economic oppression and brutality that has defined the Black experience for generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will evaluate the effects of a parenting intervention for Hispanic sexual minority youth in preventing/reducing drug use and depressive symptoms. It will also examine whether the intervention improves parent social support for the adolescent, parent acceptance, family functioning, and whether it reduces general stress and stress associated with being a Hispanic sexual minority. The knowledge expected to be gained from this study has the potential to transform the type of prevention programs that are disseminated to communities to improve the health of Hispanic sexual minority youth.

PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of the Building Access to Food through Systems and Solidarity (BASIS) Study is to improve diet by  providing culturally appropriate food access and attending to drivers that limit the ability to achieve nutrition  security in Sunset Park – a community of Mexican and Chinese American families in Brooklyn, NY that has been  hard-hit during the COVID-19 pandemic, has lagged in economic recovery, and where residents are  disconnected from government supports. We aim to implement and evaluate a whole-of-community intervention that will prioritize sustainability in the long-term, in partnership with four farming/gardening organizations, one  elementary school and three community-based organizations with programmatic offerings that will include  linkage to federal, state and local aid and workforce development; a subsidized fresh produce box program,  gardening and nutrition education; and a social marketing campaign to promote healthy eating. BASIS presents  a powerful model to improve diet in immigrant communities by addressing determinants of food access in a  community-centered, culturally competent way, and by fortifying community empowerment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Guaranteed Basic Income (GBI) could address deep systemic social and structural inequities that lead to health disparities in Black youth, with potential to improve the financial, mental and physical well-being of Black emerging adults during their critical period of transition to independence. This study includes implementation and evaluation of an innovative, multilevel intervention to address grave inequities in health by providing GBI and access to financial coaching, peer-support, and real-time monitoring of needs and referral to services. The project will provide critical data needed to understand the potential of GBI for Black youth and how to maximize its impact on health with targeted programming at a time when multiple municipalities are considering GBI legislation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative The public health impact of rejecting federal funding for community-based HIV services in Tennessee is likely to be profound, with the potential to widen disparities in HIV testing and prevention services for racial, sexual/gender, and rural residential minorities. Thus, our overarching goal is to provide a near-real-time evaluation of whether and how policy changes to funding HIV testing and prevention in Tennessee will affect HIV outcomes, particularly among populations highly vulnerable to HIV. Although focused on Tennessee, results are relevant to broader policy discussions around the direction of federal funding to community-based organizations for public health programs already emerging across the US South.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender women (trans women; women who were assigned male at birth) experience a disproportionate burden of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), Chlamydia trachomatis (CT), Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) and Syphilis, however, there is a noted paucity of literature examining non-HIV STIs. Expanded efforts are needed to explore new STI screening options to increase STI testing rates among trans women and examine the relationship between individual, interpersonal and community factors and STI risk among trans women. Thus, this proposed K99/R00 aims to validate self-collected specimens for STI testing among trans women and examine the differences in STI prevalence and socio-spatial STI risk factors between trans women with and without neovaginas using self-collected samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research on preventing skin cancer among the Hispanic population is needed since melanoma rates are increasing among Hispanics, and mortality rates are higher than among non-Hispanic whites. The Hispanic population tends to have misperceptions regarding skin cancer: they are less aware of the symptoms and harms of skin cancers and are less likely to engage in sun protection behaviors. The proposed project will develop and pilot test a mobile intervention to increase both sun protection and skin self-examination behaviors among Hispanic individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transforming the process by which academic researchers, healthcare system leaders, clinicians, and other stakeholders (from patients to community) determine what research questions to ask is essential for addressing the health and healthcare needs of underserved populations. This transformation is only possible with an infrastructure that supports involvement in the research identification, selection, implementation, and dissemination processes. This application seeks to build on the efforts of a regional medical center located in a rural, border community in California to inform new approaches for supporting the knowledge transfer process through a clinical research network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Most surgery for seriously ill older adults, including persons living with dementia (PLWD), is unplanned or emergent, rather than elective, and surgery for hip fracture is among the most common. Given the high frequency of unplanned surgery in this population, high palliative care needs, and adverse outcomes such as increased healthcare use, complications, and mortality after surgery, it is imperative to investigate the frequency of, health outcomes associated with, and factors affecting, palliative care delivery during care for unplanned surgical illness. Building on our current studies of palliative care in elective surgery, these supplemental studies will provide an innovative and layered examination of palliative care's role in unplanned surgical care for hip fractures among seriously ill older adults, with a specific focus on PLWD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the primary cause of dementia, making up about 70% of cases worldwide, and thus the therapeutic strategies to ameliorate the clinical symptoms are urgently needed. This project aims to restore the neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory TGFb-SMAD signaling in AD using novel SMAD4 PPI inducers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Markers of Alzheimers Disease can be found in the blood (amyloid-beta (Aβ), phosphorylated tau (pTau), and neurofilament light (NfL)). Our objective is to describe levels of these markers in the blood, and factors that influence levels of these biomarkers, among a group of older adults living with HIV who do not exercise regularly. Our findings will inform dementia prevention and diagnosis in older adults living with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Our recent cross-sectional findings suggest that chronic pain is associated with multiple biological aging biomarkers where a greater pain burden is associated with accelerated aging processes. Thus, the goal of the proposed study is to determine the brain and bodily aging mechanisms whereby pain prospectively impacts function in aging and whether these are different across racial/ethnic groups. Findings will contribute towards increased understanding of pain and biological aging processes, with the potential to reduce race/ethnic group disparities and improve pain-related health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project aims to refine a novel Near-infrared Spectral Tomography (NIRST) system for probing whether changes in tumor vasculature predict early neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) responses. The rigor of prior re- search and the human data we obtained show the normalized change in tumor hemoglobin (ΔHbT %) after the first NAC cycle is a key indicator for classifying Residual Cancer Burden, with significant results in multi-class Receiver Operating Curve analysis (an area under the curve of 0.80). We will focus on the new technology developments that will elevate NIRST from a research tool to a fully functional clinical solution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative True to our laboratory’s goals of creating a CRISPR-analogous system for proteome editing, we will develop both the algorithmic and experimental tools to bind and modify target proteins in a programmable fashion. To do this, we will complement our recent peptide-guided degrader system (a protein “off” switch) with a newly-engineered peptide-guided deubiquitinase system for target protein stabilization (a protein “on” switch). To enable design of these highly-specific, programmable peptide-guided editors, we will further establish algorithms that prioritize mutant-specific peptides, and train new models that capture post-translational modification information, motivating design of peptides that bind specific post-translational protein states to selective modulate modified disease-causing proteins versus their wild-type healthy counterparts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study has important potential to impact public health and reduce youth firearm-related deaths by scaling out an evidence-based secure firearm storage intervention to pediatric inpatient hospital settings. This cluster randomized clinical trial will test both the effectiveness of an adapted secure firearm storage intervention in improving parent-reported secure storage and secondary firearm safety behaviors, as well as examine the effect of an implementation strategy bundle on intervention reach, acceptability, fidelity, and maintenance. Nurses will lead implementation, highlighting an opportunity for widescale impact by harnessing the expertise of frontline nurses in the work of firearm injury prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Persecutory delusions are extremely common in schizophrenia and cause significant disability and distress. Contemporary mechanistic models suggest that altered belief updating is a cognitive process underlying persecutory delusions, yet rigorous tests of this are needed. We propose to use a clinical trials design to determine whether behavioral and neurobiological aspects of belief updating change with intervention, with the goal of generating knowledge for translation into new treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Data findings from the parent grant suggest that monocytes and B-cells are differentially expressed in pregnant women chronically exposed to air pollution. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative von Willebrand factor (vWF) is essential for normal hemostasis and thrombosis and is involved in other important processes such as angiogenesis and cancer cell metastasis. Regulated release of vWF depends on normal maturation of its storage granule, the Weibel-Palade bodies (WPBs), and subsequent fusion of WPBs to the plasma membrane, processes which are poorly understood. Using live cell microscopy, pulldown of endogenously tagged proteins, and a genetically modified mouse model, we propose to elucidate the endosomal pathway in WPB biogenesis, the associated trafficking machinery, and regulation of WPB exocytosis by the exocyst complex.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Safe, accessible and effective strategies are urgently needed for cancer patients whose tumors fail to respond to immunotherapy. Given the importance of diet and the gut microbiome in immune response, we will examine how a prebiotic food enriched dietary intervention influences the gut microbiomeand response to immunotherapy in melanoma. Insights gained may have far-reaching implications across immunotherapy treatment for patients with melanoma and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells are surrounded by a complex and dynamic polymeric meshwork that connects cells into functional tissues and organs. These polymeric materials provide mechanical and structural cues that direct cellular processes involved in development and tissue maintenance and often become dysregulated in disease, but our understanding of how these physical cues regulate cellular behavior is limited by the lack of suitable engineered systems to study the isolated effects of these important parameters. This project will develop new biomaterials platforms that recapitulate the dynamic and complex mechanical properties of native tissues and then apply these well-controlled platforms to establish causal relationships between physical cues and a broad range of cellular behaviors.

PROJECT_TITLE: Leveraging protein-engineered biomaterials and bioorthogonal chemistries to elucidate the role of non-elastic matrix properties in regulating cell fate

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Dopamine plays a critical role in emotion- and motivation-related neural plasticity. While most prior studies examine dopamine receptor-coupled signaling within neuronal cells, led by strong preliminary results, proposed research will test the hypothesis that dopamine D1 receptors on astrocytes mediate cross-synapse signaling transduction that contributes to heterosynaptic plasticity and cue-conditioned nondrug and drug seeking. Outcome of this study may reveal novel cellular targets through which pathophysiological motivation can be manipulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Improper gene regulation is central to cancer, where transcription factors recruit chromatin machinery to drive disease promoting genes. Focusing on the Androgen Receptor (AR), a transcription factor driving prostate cancer, we will examine the chromatin mechanisms of a new small molecule strategy that swaps the AR from an activator to a suppressor of its target genes, and test this as a therapy for lethal forms of prostate cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Southern California consists of 10 contiguous Counties and is home to 10.8 million Latinos (representing 45.2% of the population) who are disproportionally affected by multiple and co-occurring chronic diseases, namely obesity, type 2 diabetes, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, and dyslipidemia. This disparity begins to develop early in life, occurs within families, is magnified by inter-generational transmission, and is driven by multi-level factors including diet, cultural values, social determinants, economic factors, and environmental-level factors like access to healthy foods and other chemical exposures such as air pollution. Our overall goal is to understand how the complex inter-play between these multi-level factors contribute to multiple chronic disease disparities in Latinos across the life course, and to develop and evaluate the acceptance, delivery, and clinical efficacy of family- based, culturally sensitive solutions by establishing the Southern California Center for Chronic Health Disparities in Latino Families and Children (SCC-CHDLFC).

We focus on cardiovascular disease and cancer, and their risk factors, as they are the two leading causes of death and that share common social context, etiological pathways, risk factors and management strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative brain disease with no effective treatment due to its complicated pathogenesis. We discovered a novel way of treating AD with EVs derived from muscle progenitor cells enriched in neuropeptides responsible for Aβ degradation, and neuroprotection eventually ameliorating AD pathology. This supplement will pave our way towards testing the therapeutic potential of muscle progenitor cells derived EVs against AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – Overall The Center for Chronic Disease Reduction and Equity Promotion Across Minnesota (C2DREAM) will reduce disparities in cardiovascular disease (CVD) and the related chronic conditions (RCC) of hypertension and obesity experienced by Black, Indigenous, and people of color (BIPOC) communities including immigrants and refugees across Minnesota. C2DREAM will promote innovative, multilevel interventions that target fundamental causes of chronic disease inequities among BIPOC communities; generate knowledge, analytical and implementation approaches, and community engagement strategies to understand and develop solutions to address racism at multiple levels; develop and support the next generation of health equity researchers; create and sustain a community-engaged and equity-guided dissemination and implementation processes to translate research results and knowledge into action; and employ equity-guided evaluation approaches. Our regional partnership of academic institutions and community stakeholders is poised to understand and ultimately address the ways that racism undermines the well-being of BIPOC communities across Minnesota.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe burn injury triggers profound muscle wasting and weakness which continues long after hospital discharge and results in functional limitations that impair quality of life and contribute to increased morbidity and mortality among burn survivors. The information gained in this program will advance our current understanding of the mechanisms by which burn injury triggers skeletal muscle dysfunction, with a unique focus on fibrogenic and immunologic mechanisms. Elucidating non-canonical cellular and molecular mechanisms of burn-induced muscle dysfunction will unveil therapies to mitigate atrophy and weakness after burn injury, thus improving physical functional recovery in survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Type IV pili are important molecular machines and key virulence factors in many clinically important bacterial pathogens. Although the function of TFP is determined by the dynamics of this machine, we know little about the molecular processes that govern TFP dynamics or how TFP machines are assembled molecularly during the cell cycle. Here, we will use a combination of different single-molecule fluorescence microscopy techniques to understand the assembly of TFP machines molecule by molecule, to understand when and where new machines are being built, and how individual motor and effector molecules interact with individual machines, sensory systems, and regulatory systems inside the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychosocial resilience in spousal caregivers of spouses with cognitive decline is important in later life for maintaining health and well-being. This study leverages longitudinal data from four large, nationally representative cohorts of older adults with Harmonized Cognitive Assessment Protocol studies to examine associations with psychosocial resilience at an individual-, community- and societal-level. Study results will identify risk and protective factors to inform priorities for social and community-level services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Health disparities in the burden of multiple chronic conditions in the Chicago region are attributed to a history of racial segregation leaving gaps in economic opportunities and gaps in the healthcare system. The Chicago Chronic Condition Equity Network (C3EN) will address these gaps by strengthening and building collaborations across community-based organizations, practice networks, and academic researchers, by promoting a comprehensive approach to the prevention and management of multiple chronic conditions that accounts for mental health, functional health and social life, and by supporting interventions that actively seek to cross boundaries of disease-specific management, professional training, community and practice.

PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL The Center for Research, Health, and Social Justice (CRHS) will use a social justice framework to conduct research, engage communities, and build a diverse and competent research workforce to reduce disparities in cancer and cardiovascular disease. Social justice focuses on improving lives and wellbeing of historically marginalized and oppressed groups that face racism and discrimination. The CRHS is designed to become a national model for eliminating chronic disease disparities using social justice informed research, training, and community engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Acute and chronic bladder toxicities can occur in patients treated with pelvic radiotherapy, often causing severe and progressively debilitating sequalae. The proposed project investigates the mechanisms of tissue injury in the irradiated bladder and a urine-based injury biomarker to evaluate well-tolerated FDA-approved modifiers of the renin angiotensin pathway that we have shown can prevent these radiotherapy side-effects, using preclinical models and human biosamples. In terms of long-term goals, this study aims to prevent radiotherapy toxicities by offering an inexpensive and safe therapy for cancer patients most susceptible to developing bladder injury.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research examines the influence of pancreas dynamics during pregnancy on the development of diabetes. MRI measurements of pancreas size, shape, and composition will be made over time in both the mother and the fetus to see how the pancreas is affected by maternal diabetes. Pancreas phenotypes will be correlated with metabolic phenotypes as assessed by glucose tolerance testing and continuous glucose monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the Deep South Center to Reduce Disparities in Chronic Diseases is to promote health equity and reduce the burden of cardiometabolic diseases, including obesity, diabetes, and hypertension, among Black Americans and low-income populations in our tri-state region (i.e., Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana). The Center represents a partnership between the University of Alabama at Birmingham, Tuskegee University, Pennington Biomedical Research Center, and the University of Mississippi Medical Center, along with regional non-academic partners to translate and sustain cardiometabolic research in real-world community and clinical settings. The Center is focused on expanding and diversifying the region’s research workforce, promoting equitable collaborations between researchers and non-academic partners, and advancing scientific discovery through synergistic research projects focused on multi-level, multi-domain interventions for the prevention, treatment, and management of cardiometabolic diseases in the Deep South.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: The burden of chronic disease disparities is most evident among African American and Hispanic/Latino populations in the southeastern United States. To address these pervasive health inequities, the Southeast Collaborative for Innovative and Equitable Solutions to Chronic Disease Disparities we will bring together expertise at Vanderbilt University Medical Center, University of Miami School of Medicine, and Meharry Medical College to collaboratively develop and implement multi-level interventions. The Center will partner with communities and will leverage advances in technology and data science to reduce risk factors for and disparities in diabetes, cardiovascular disease, obesity, and related conditions among African American and Latino populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: NARRATIVE Compelling evidence indicates that the key to increasing lifespan equality is saving lives at ages below ~70 years. The ACHIEVE GREATER Center is designed to do just that by ameliorating cardiometabolic health disparities during early phases of pathogenesis in order to improve Black-White lifespan inequality in two uniquely comparable, densely populated, and severely affected cities: Detroit, MI, and Cleveland, OH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative This project will focus on understanding the fundamental mechanisms of tissues closing millimeter-size gaps, which is important for embryo development, regeneration, and wound healing. The proposed work will develop new tools to measure physical parameters and identify key biomolecules that are involved in such processes for various tissue types under different environmental stimuli.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiovascular disease accounts for 1 in every 3 deaths in the US, many of which are caused by ischemic heart disease and acute myocardial infarction, which can lead to heart failure, for which there is no cure. Our proposed studies aim to decipher the molecular mechanisms contributing to ischemic heart disease. We anticipate that in the future this knowledge will help to develop new, mechanistically specific and selective treatments for heart disease and, thus, reduce mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE When a genetic variant causes increased risk of developing a disease, it can provide valuable insight into disease biology. However, a major challenge is often to understand the functional effect of disease-causing variants. This application proposes the development of computational methods to link disease association data with diverse functional datasets, in order to understand the relationship between the functional effect of a variant and its effect on the risk of disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The use of genetically engineered (GE) pigs is critical for advancing both biomedical and agricultural applications but are underutilized, in part, due to the safety and efficacy of the technology, as well as, the time required to establish and propagate these models. Developing strategies that assist in preserving genome integrity and for rapid identification of phenotypes will allow for the rapid expansion of GE pig models. Increasing the availability of GE pig models will have clear impacts on preclinical models for gene therapy and quickly identifying pigs with improved agricultural traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low-income pregnant and postpartum people (PPP) enrolled in Medicaid experience suboptimal and inequitable quality of care and pregnancy-related outcomes, especially PPP from racial/ethnic minorized groups. Federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) could play a key role in improving maternal health outcomes and equity at scale by addressing drivers of maternal health care inequities, as FQHCs may improve access, care integration and coordination, and address unmet social needs, yet very limited evidence is available to guide policymakers, health systems, managed care plans, or FQHCs. This research will therefore fill this critical evidence gap by evaluating if and how FQHCs, and direct provision of maternity care at FQHCs, can improve quality and equity of care for PPP by leveraging a novel natural experiment using national claims data and qualitative interview data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE – OVERALL COMPONENT The Core Grant for Vision Research supports the work of a diverse group of vision scientists in the Pittsburgh area conducting research on vision, infectious disease, causes of blindness, and developing new therapies to prevent blindness. The grant provides critical support to NEI-funded investigators, and it supports pilot studies that can be incorporated into new NIH/NEI R01 applications from new investigators or established investigators moving into vision research. The services and equipment provided by this grant allow our vision scientists to integrate diverse scientific approaches into their vision research projects and thereby enhance their overall impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Socioeconomically disadvantaged populations have a high prevalence of chronic pain, exacerbated by social isolation, intersectional stigma, and disparities in pain assessment and treatment options. Effective interventions using a multilevel, biopsychosocial approach are needed to decrease the unequal burden of pain. The proposed study will test group-based integrative models of pain management in primary care safety net clinics to improve pain care for racially and ethnically diverse low-income patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Obstructive sleep apnea is a life-threatening condition, disrupting multiple autonomic, mood, breathing, and cognitive functions, most likely from tissue and functional alterations in brain sites that regulate these functions, which are linked to morbidity, mortality, and quality of life. The pathological processes that induce such brain changes in obstructive sleep apnea are unclear, but likely include intermittent hypoxia-induced oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction; those aspects can be evaluated by assessing regional brain temperatures, metabolites, and antioxidant levels, links between temperature, metabolites, and disease severity, as well as examining the effect of continuous positive airway pressure, the gold standard intervention for obstructive sleep apnea, on brain temperature and metabolites. The outcomes will have important implications for identifying effective interventions to rescue brain injury, especially in obstructive sleep apnea patients with non- compliant continuous positive airway pressure or no treatment, with subsequent benefits for dysfunctional physiology and behavior, and could dramatically improve the morbidity, mortality, and quality of life in the condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Acne, the most common human skin disease, is associated with C. acnes, affects over 50 million people in the U.S., and has a significant psychological impact on patients affecting their self-esteem. We seek to understand the mechanisms by which C. acnes phylotypes induce T cell-derived mitochondrial proteins in acne and how these proteins contribute to skin health and homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Understanding the impact of viral biomolecular condensates on cellular processes, including translation and RNA interference, presents a promising avenue for improving human health. These processes are frequently disrupted during infections by various viral pathogens, offering the possibility of identifying new antiviral targets linked to viral condensate formation or virus-host interactions within these structures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many clinically and economically important traits are complex, i.e., they are under the influence of many underlying genes. Understanding how variation in genotype leads to variation in phenotype is a difficult problem as genes often interact with each other, such that knowing the effects of individual genes is not sufficient to predict how they will combine. This project will develop new computational tools for learning from large genotype-phenotype data for humans and model organisms in order to improve our ability to predict phenotype for new genotypes and detect novel gene interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Text Mining and Large Language Models to Enhance Functional Annotation in UniProt of Protein Variants Associated with Alzheimer's Disease Hundreds of genetic variants associated with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) have been discovered, and better understanding of the impact of these variants is key to developing effective strategies for diagnosing, preventing, and treating AD. However, much of the information about AD-related variants is scattered throughout the scientific literature, so it is challenging for AD researchers to find and piece together this knowledge. To address this problem, we will use a combination of custom-built text-mining tools and Large Language Models (e.g., ChatGPT) to automatically extract information about AD-related variants from the literature, and we will present the results in UniProt in a variety of accessible, user-friendly formats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies focus on an important, yet understudied area of meningeal biology and dementia research. The overall goal is to improve our understanding of the contribution of meningeal plaque accumulation in cognitive decline, the role that inflammation plays, and the key mechanistic players involved. These studies will further address whether brain trauma plays a causal role in modulating the meningeal milieu, which may support strategies aimed at monitoring meningeal inflammation during aging in prior TBI patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Surveillance for cancer recurrence is a critically important part of CRC survivorship care, as CRC recurrences are common and may be curable if detected early. However, up to 60% of the 1.5 million CRC survivors in the U.S. fail to receive surveillance as recommended by the American Society for Clinical Oncology and the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. Identifying an effective intervention to improve survivors’ knowledge about and self-efficacy in managing surveillance, and improve their receipt of surveillance, will lead to improved clinical outcomes for the large and growing population of CRC survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative DNA-protein cross-links at 3′-DNA termini arising from apurinic/apyrimidinic sites that are induced by various endogenous and exogenous genotoxins, if not repaired, can have toxic effects and may lead to cell death. TREX1, the major human 3′ to 5′ exonuclease, has an unexpected role in processing DNA lesions at 3′-termini. We propose to study the formation and repair mechanisms of these DNA-protein cross-links, and investigate the functions and regulatory mechanisms of TREX1 in DNA repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transposable elements constitute a significant part of the non-coding genome, while their inappropriate activation has been implicated in pathogenesis of over 120 human diseases including autoimmune disorders. In this application, we will address the following questions: 1) Are there any differences in the expression of genome transposable elements between epidermal keratinocytes isolated from the skin of African American, Hispanic and Asian origin and non-Hispanic White origin, 2) Which mechanisms regulate transposable element silencing in keratinocytes of different ethnic groups, and 3) Whether modulation of inflammatory response by nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors might serve as new approach for management of skin inflammatory conditions in individuals with understudied skin types. The generated outputs on this project will provide a platform for translation of these results into clinics and will promote the development of novel therapeutic interventions, which hopefully could serve as new paradigm for management of skin inflammatory conditions in patients with skin of color and their prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE R-loops, considered by-products of transcription, are important epigenetic regulators of gene expression and contribute to fundamental biological processes in various organisms. The proposed studies will investigate the functions of R-loops and the R-loop-dependent factors that regulate gene transcription, epigenetic modification, and DNA damage repair. A successful completion of these studies will elucidate novel mechanisms of regulatory R-loops in the context of pluripotency, early development, and tissue homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autologous and allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT) survivors experience a substantial and drastic deterioration in their sexual function, which persists for many years following their transplant. Despite the prevalence of sexual dysfunction in HCT survivors, interventions to address the multidimensional sexual health concerns of HCT survivors are lacking. This proposal seeks to assess the efficacy of a patient-centered, evidence-based, self-administered, digital app (SHIFT) for improving sexual health outcomes, quality of life, and psychological distress in HCT survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: We propose the development of a new automated frailty and fitness scoring system, the Pittsburgh Transplant Fitness Score (PTFS), for predicting lung transplant outcomes. The PTFS will be designed to provide an objective, reliable, and efficient assessment of a patient's fitness for lung transplant using pre-transplant data, enabling accurate predictions of intra-operative and post-operative transplant outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Therapeutics formulated through nanotechnology approaches (Nanotherapeutics) are at the forefront of clinical translation for treating a variety of diseases. In this project, we will interrogate the fundamental mechanisms of how myeloid cell – a critical mediator of inflammation, interact with nanotherapeutics and direct their targeting to inflammation. The results of this study will enable the rationale design and of inflammation-targeting nanotherapeutics for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ligand gated ion channels are proteins that enable our cells to fine-tune their intracellular environments based on chemical cues, and the dysregulation of these proteins is a major driver of human disease. The details of how ligand gated ion channels function are critical to understand for therapeutic design, yet despite their importance, the mechanisms of function are unclear. We are elucidating the molecular mechanisms of how ligand gated ion channels function to understand how they regulate our cells in health and provide foundations for disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The ability to construct complex molecules is crucial to the development of modern medicines. As traditional paradigms of molecular complexity, natural products have long served to fuel the development of modern organic synthesis and as rich sources of therapeutic agents. This proposal seeks to expand access to molecular complexity through two distinct approaches to such compounds: leveraging readily available aromatic building blocks to access highly oxygenated anticancer terpenes via novel dearomatization strategies, and breaking symmetry within simple symmetrical starting materials en route to complex bioactive alkaloids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Since the 1950’s we have known about the existence of ‘jumping genes’ – transposable elements that selfishly increase in copy number within host genomes. However only recently did we come to understand that the host has a defense system based on small RNAs for combating unchecked proliferation of these genomic parasites. To date we know very little about how this defense system evolves within and between populations to combat new and active transposable elements, or about the actual mechanisms of transposable element suppression by this system. This proposal aims to address this shortfall by developing a comparative genomics approach to the small RNA defense system, both within populations and between species. This will yield new insights into the genomic conflict of transposable elements and their hosts and variability in host susceptibility to transposable elements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project focuses on prion-based behaviors of components within the chromatin remodeling complexes - SWI/SNF (SWItch/Sucrose Non-Fermentable) in yeast and BAF (BRG1- or BRM-Associated Factor complex) in humans. The research will provide mechanistic insights into prion-conferred transcriptomic modifications and phenotypes. It will also characterize prion-like activities of BAF proteins and their mutants linked to cancers and neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are cumulative childhood exposures to potentially traumatic family and community experiences that can have lasting, negative impact on health, with potential intergenerational transmission of effects. The purpose of this mixed methods study is to understand how parents' exposures to ACEs and positive childhood experiences (PCEs) impact their parenting practices, particularly in the context of living in unsafe neighborhoods. This study will advance the science of ACEs by elucidating protective and health-promoting factors in the intergenerational transmission of ACEs and explore a method of understanding how neighborhoods influence the impact of ACEs and PCEs on parenting practices using community-level geospatial data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral immune aberrancies are recently reported in individuals with AD; however, the immune mechanisms connected to the onset and progression of neurological disease is unknown. In this proposal, we describe a comprehensive, ‘systems biology’ approach to determine AD-linked immune signatures in both the peripheral blood and brain to gain new insight into the precise immune drivers that cause neuroinflammation and cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many intensive care unit survivors suffer from pervasive cognitive impairment comparable to patients with early-stage Alzheimer’s disease. While the causative mechanisms that lead to abrupt cognitive impairment are unclear, recent studies show that lung vascular endothelium produces cytotoxins after nosocomial bacterial infection. This application seeks to examine the effects of lung infection and sepsis using a novel, humanized amyloid-β mouse model to increase the translational relevance of studies described in the parent award.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cerebral blood flow (CBF) measures cerebrovascular health and regional brain function and has broad range of applications in both neuroscience and clinical care. In this Academic Industrial Partnership, neuroimaging investigators from the University of Pennsylvania and the University of Maryland partner with investigators from Siemens Medical Solutions, USA to develop and disseminate a robust MRI technology that can noninvasively quantify CBF. This supplemental project specifically focuses on optimizing CBF measurements for use in Alzheimer's disease and related disorders research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Project Narrative There is an ongoing substance abuse epidemic in western society. Synthetic psychoactive agents are among the newest, most popular, and least understood of the abused substances. This work focuses on the development of a new platform to understand bath salts and related agents to define novel therapeutic targets to treat toxicity and episodic lethality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Despite its centrality to the human condition, susceptibility to disease, and decades of intense research, there are still many fundamental mysteries surrounding the biological basis of memory. I present a new, reductionist system that will allow rapid progress in our understanding of memory formation and removal. The preliminary findings in Drosophila show extensive molecular and phenomenological similarities to mammalian memory and identify a novel population of neurons that set the threshold for memory formation and control its removal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by painful skin scars, nodules, abscesses, and sinus tracts in the skin-fold areas that can cause low quality of life. Racial disparities exist in HS; however, contributing factors to these disparities remain unclear. The overall goal of this project is to define the genetic contributors to HS risk using whole-exome sequencing and functional mechanism studies, which may provide new therapeutic targets and treatments for HS patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  COPD is the third leading cause of death in the world, and yet roughly half of patients remain undiagnosed. At the same time, a significant proportion of individuals at risk for COPD are undergoing low-dose computed tomography for lung cancer screening. As imaging features such as emphysema can help to identify COPD, the goal of this proposal is to determine how to leverage imaging being performed for lung cancer screening to improve early diagnosis of COPD, which will facilitate earlier risk modification, treatment and reduced disease morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project investigates the link between paternal phthalate exposure, seminal plasma metabolomics, and reproductive health outcomes. The study has important public health implications by determining potential pathways by which paternal toxicant exposures influence reproductive health. Seminal plasma metabolomic results will constitute major advances in the fields of environmental and reproductive health by improving clinical assessments of male fertility, and thus, is a critical step toward developing interventions to improve male reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to identify connections between biological factors – not only of neurodegeneration but of vascular, nutritional, and inflammatory systems – underlying ADRD pathology and cognitive outcomes across socioeconomically diverse contexts. We will use cross-national data in the US and India to assess the interplay between context, social factors, and ADRD biology using recently collected cross-nationally harmonized neurodegenerative biomarkers as well as information on cognitive outcomes and other markers of vascular, nutritional, and inflammatory systems. Our results will set the stage to leverage biology to understand social differences in cognition that would not be clear from research in just one country, with the ultimate goal of preventing and/or delaying the onset of ADRD from a global perspective.

ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project narrative: The Moffitt Consortium is poised to support the goals of the Blood and Marrow Transplant Clinical Trial Network (BMT CTN) through conduct of important national clinical trials. In addition, we propose a trial testing different chemotherapy regimens given before immunotherapy (CAR-T) for lymphoma patients. The trial aims to determine which chemotherapy approach can improve the likelihood of patients living long term without relapse of lymphoma, and enhance safety of this treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene therapy for many blood diseases requires growing blood stem cells in cultures and introducing genes to correct the genetic defects of blood cells. Expanding and modifying blood stem cells in cultured condition is associated with poor quality of proteins which leads to loss of stem cell functions. Our studies will identify and test new small molecular compounds to improve protein quality to preserve blood stem cell function after culture which has the potential to improve the efficiency of gene therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Gene mis-regulation is linked to a wide variety of disorders, including developmental defects and cancer. By determining fundamental mechanisms underlying the control of gene expression, this research will increase our understanding of how genes are regulated so that the causes of mis-regulation can be identified in diseased cells. This research will also advance our basic knowledge of quiescence, a cell state implicated in cancer recurrence, with the eventual goal of providing insight into potential targets for drug therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative This research aims to create a controlled vocabulary for terms defining and classifying dental-care related fear, anxiety, and/or phobia (DFA). We do this by developing the Ontology of Dental care-related Fear, and Anxiety, and/or Phobia (ODFA). The ODFA’s concepts and relations facilitate the development of tools and resources capable of enhancing our understanding of the impacts of DFA, and when applied to study data, the ODFA enables the integration and interoperability of data from multiple studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The severity of traumatic injuries, as well as complications arising during wound healing, are on the rise, resulting in increased disability and mortality in the US population. The goal of this project is to study the acute imbalance in inflammation that leads to disease progression, and apply this knowledge to engineer nano- and micro-scale biomaterial strategies to resolve chronic inflammation in traumatic and non-healing wounds. These studies will lead to the development of bio-inspired material that can remediate intrinsic and extrinsic inflammatory pathways, resulting in a unifying traumatic injury and wound care strategy for improved patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Oral cancer represents a significant societal burden. In this project, we propose to identify the key underlying causes of oral cancer by investigating changes in the chromatin environment brought about by an enzyme, lysine-specific demethylase 1 (LSD1). We anticipate that this study will increase knowledge about the biology of oral cancer, explore a synergistic combination of effective therapy, and lead to the development of novel treatment strategies for this pernicious disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Protein quality control (PQC) is the balance of protein folding and degradation that is regulated by molecular chaperones and the 26S proteasome. Proper PQC is essential for human health, and an imbalance leads to disease, including cancer or neurodegeneration. This proposal seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying how chaperones can directly target substrates to the proteasome for degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Gene expression relies on RNA regulation to orchestrate where and when a distinct transcript is translated to alter cell fate. These processes allow for dynamic responses to internal and environmental cues that can depict even where along an RNA translation initiation begins during the final stage of gene expression, enhancing genetic diversity through non-conventional protein synthesis. This proposal seeks to map the complete proteome during cellular growth and adaptation, while uncovering the regulatory mechanisms of RNA epigenetics in these processes, with opportunity for improved diagnostics and innovative RNA therapeutics in disease states.

In this MIRA R35 proposal, we will elucidate the mechanisms that promote BIR in the genome and at telomeres to better understand the relationship between transcription and genome instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cells in the human body use actin bound force sensitive proteins to sense directionality of external forces and drive development, maintenance, and remodeling of tissues. These studies will provide quantitative microscopy methods and materials systems for a new approach to simultaneously analyze actin orientation, actin velocity, and forces in these complexes. The themes outlined here will form the basis for a research program that is focused on identifying and manipulating the molecular basis of directional mechanosensing, in order to prevent or reverse disease processes that involve mechanosensing driven tissue remodeling (fibrosis and degeneration) or aberrant cellular migration (developmental diseases and cancers).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to identify modifiable factors and effective strategies throughout the life course that can promote cognitive function, delay cognitive decline, and mitigate Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) risk in diverse populations across sociocultural and economic contexts. This project will use cross- nationally harmonized data to investigate the impact of labor force participation and key stimulating activities in middle and later life on cognitive aging outcomes by gender and across sociocultural contexts. Findings from this study will provide critical insights to inform global prevention of ADRD—especially in low- and middle- income countries' populations that are growing rapidly and are most vulnerable to the challenges posed by ADRD—by informing tailored interventions and policies in the US and globally to improve population health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease is associated with pathophysiological processes many years prior to clinical symptom onset, characterized by the accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques. Beta-amyloid burden serves as a critical biomarker for identifying individuals at high risk of clinical progression and for evaluating treatment efficacy. In this project, we aim to develop a novel, non-invasive MRI method that is sensitive to beta-amyloid, with the goal of supplementing or potentially replacing amyloid PET.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Dense core secretory granules are organelles for the intracellular storage of peptide hormones and stimulus- dependent exocytosis in regulated secretory cells. Defects in maturation and secretion of secretory granules can lead to several mental and metabolic disorders, but the causes of these disorders are poorly understood and there is a critical need for more effective therapeutics. We seek to understand how different cellular signals effect granule maturation and secretory efficiency to identify targets for future design of improved therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Little is known about the changes in single-cell level protein composition in the brain during Alzheimer’s disease (AD) progression. This project will use a novel Gel-based Optical-isolation 3D (GO3D) single-cell-type multiomics to spatially profile proteins, RNAs, and chromatin accessibility of an AD-associated cell type, astrocyte. The outcomes of this project will unbiasedly provide a list of AD-associated proteins and PTMs, which can be new potential targets for AD treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The blood-brain and blood-retinal barriers play a crucial role in regulating the transportation of essential nutrients, waste products, and harmful pathogens between the bloodstream and the brain and eye. In-depth research on the molecular mechanisms governing the formation and maintenance of these barriers serves as the cornerstone for developing effective therapeutic approaches to address vascular defects in the brain and retina. The outcome of this project will demonstrate the mechanisms of retinal and CNS angiogenesis and pave the way for groundbreaking advancements in treating various conditions affecting the brain and retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Neuroactive steroids (NASs) are synthesized in the brain from progesterone and play a central role in regulating neuronal excitability and behavior. Here we will test the role that a novel family of G-protein receptors for NAS play in mediating the their sustained effects on neuronal excitability. The results of this studies will provide new information on NAS signaling which may ultimately lead to new strategies to improve mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) methods offer a promising approach to improve the timely recognition and management of patients with and at risk for sepsis. However, several important clinical and analytic questions about the development of sepsis-focused AI/ML clinical decision support systems remain unanswered, thereby limiting the development of useful clinical decision support systems. Therefore, this pro- posal will explore several foundational questions in sepsis care to develop AI/ML systems that are timely, useful at the bedside, and scale across diverse clinical contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this administrative supplement application, we will construct a computable ADRD knowledge hub (ADKH) from Pubmed literature to accelerate ADRD knowledge discovery, and evaluate several longitudinal deep learning architectures for real-time ADRD risk assessment with electronic health record (EHR) incorporating knowledge from ADKH. This research will meet a pressing and unresolved need to conduct ADRD predictive modeling leveraging knowledge from literature. This supplement project aims to deliver novel informatics methods for graph embedding and build gated recurrent unit with decay (GRU- D) based models for dynamic ADRD risk assessment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gut microbes and host cells are connected within an intricate bioelectrical network, with microbial electrical signals potentially shaping gut health and broader host-wide functions. This project delves into a previously unexplored aspect of the gut microbiota: bacterial electro-signaling via extracellular, conductive nanowires. By investigating bioelectrical communication along the gut-host axis, we aim to unveil new avenues for gut-focused therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research details the development of reaction methodology to enable molecular rigidification. We will develop stoichiometric dialkyl carbene transfer reactions using alkyl sulfones as carbene precursors to obtain chiral orphaned cyclopropanes and apply this reaction to the synthesis medium-ring heterocycles and the synthesis of the antifungal compound jawsamycin. Simultaneously, we will study the mechanism of Pd and Ni- catalyzed dialkylcarbene transfer reactions, which will enable access to medicinally relevant bioisosteres such as [2.1.0]-bicyclopentanes (housanes), annulated heterocycles, and cerorubenic acids I, II and III.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE My research focuses on understanding the underlying principles and mechanisms that enable an animal's body plan to regenerate, using the experimentally tractable research model planaria. Through my recent work, I have discovered that Hox genes play a crucial role in restricting body size and facilitating asexual reproduction, both of which are functionally linked with the planarian's impressive regenerative abilities. My lab is now poised to delve deeper into the molecular mechanisms behind how Hox genes regulate body size, how that size regulation facilitates regenerative processes, and how Hox functions in asexual reproduction are molecularly intertwined with the ability to regenerate the entire body.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The key clinical hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease (AD) are amyloid β (Aβ) plaque and synaptic degeneration which are observed in both the brain and the retina. This project is aimed to study the molecular mechanism through which Aβ induces synaptic degeneration in the retina with a specific focus on a previously identified molecule α2δ4 and its downstream signaling. The results from the proposed research will advance our understanding of retinal changes in AD and AD pathology overall and facilitate mechanism-based AD clinical interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell migration is utilized many times in human health including embryonic tissue morphogenesis, immune cell surveillance, and cancer cell metastasis – each of these events require careful communication with the surrounding environment through the plasma membrane. Thus, a comprehensive understanding of how the plasma membrane is organized during in vivo cell migration is critical to understand the basic mechanisms underlying migratory cell behavior. Research in my laboratory will interrogate the role of plasma lipid metabolism in regulating membrane organization, fluidity, and cell signaling during in vivo cell migration with the ultimate goal of identifying new strategies to combat aberrant cell migration during development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public health gains could be substantial if people who use combusted cigarettes, the most harmful nicotine delivery products, switch to a less harmful nicotine product. This research will examine the ability of 3-mg and 6-mg nicotine pouches to serve as a replacement for cigarettes during a 3-week switching trial and compare them to nicotine mini lozenges or no-study product. This data could inform regulatory policy decisions regarding the public health impact of nicotine pouches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE City of Hope, as a Core Clinical Center of the Blood and Marrow Transplant Clinical Trials Network, proposes to continue leadership in the development and execution of prospective clinical trials addressing key issues in hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT). We also propose a Phase 2, platform clinical trial of post-HCT maintenance therapeutics in patients undergoing allogeneic HCT for treatment of TP53-mutated AML or MDS, to be conducted by BMT CTN. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In addition to supporting sight, light regulates diverse aspects of physiology and behavior. In mammals, the intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells are essential for this regulation. We propose to develop basic knowledge of these cells and thereby deepen the foundation for improving health; for example, light acts through ipRGCs to regulate the circadian clock, and circadian dysregulation is implicated in cancer, cardiovascular disease, metabolic disorder, and mental illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Prostate cancer is the most prevalent neoplasm in the male population worldwide, and MRI is now a key modality for detection and biopsy guidance of clinically significant prostate cancer. Due to suboptimal sensitivity of current MRI techniques, 30% of patients with a negative MRI still end up proceeding to invasive biopsy, which leads to unnecessary treatment and post-procedure complications. As experts in Magnetic Resonance Fingerprinting and prostate diagnoses along with expertise in artificial intelligence, we aim to develop novel quantitative imaging biomarkers to improve the characterization of prostatic tissues to ensure optimal detection of clinically significant prostate cancer while avoiding overdiagnosis and unnecessary procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Although high-throughput screening yields a number of small-molecule modulators of biomedically relevant proteins, these ‘hits’ typically require substantial optimization to improve their biological functions via costly medicinal chemistry approaches, creating a significant hurdle to development of efficacious chemical probes and drugs. The proposed research program aims to address this limitation through two complementary research directions focused on developing generally applicable medicinal chemistry workflows for underexplored biological targets. Ultimately, application of these approaches and the resulting probes will advance our fundamental understanding of living systems and provide proof-of-concept for novel therapeutic mechanisms of action, thereby enhancing human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. As the cases of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) continue to grow worldwide, it is critical more than ever to improve our identification of those at greatest risk for ADRD earliest in the disease process. Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is meant to capture individuals in the prodromal phase between cognitively healthy and dementia, yet not everyone diagnosed with MCI eventually progresses to dementia. By harmonizing large longitudinal population-based studies in the United States, Mexico, and India, we will be able to uncover, from a global perspective, the sociodemographic, health, and biological factors that predict progression from MCI to dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Where one lives is an important contributor to disparities in health behaviors and outcomes. It has been difficult to draw firm conclusions on the relations between regional/neighborhood contexts and alcohol misuse. The results of this project will enhance our understanding of the relation between neighborhood contexts and alcohol misuse from adolescence through mid-adulthood, that may inform the development of more effective, tailored programs of prevention and intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the known adverse effects of genetic risk for Alzheimer’s disease and its related dementias (including Apolipoprotein (APOEε4) and related variants), chronic alcohol misuse, traumatic stress, and PTSD on brain health, there are few studies that have specifically examined the relationship between Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) in this context. In response to NOT-AG-23-032, which requests administrative supplements for existing NIH grants to develop a new focus on ADRD, the primary aim of this study is to investigate the association of genomic risk for ADRD (including and excluding APOEε4) with longitudinal measures of brain functioning (i.e., neural connectivity), and the role of alcohol use behavior, traumatic stress and PTSD. Study findings will enhance understanding of how Alzheimer’s risk factors (genetics, problematic alcohol use, traumatic stress, PTSD, neural development) typically studied later in life, manifest earlier in the lifespan, and inform interventions or preventive measures that may help prevent downstream health conditions.

PHR: Project Narrative This research program will elucidate the rules governing the binding of proteins to DNA and the contributions of epigenetics, co-factors, and chromatin to modulate binding. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In proliferating cells, metabolism must be coordinated with the cell cycle to meet phase-specific biosynthetic demands, but how this coordination occurs is unknown. This project will determine the role of the master metabolic regulator mTOR Complex 1 as a crucial effector through which the cell cycle orchestrates changes in metabolism. This study will provide new understanding of the mechanisms that integrate cell cycle control with cellular metabolism, critically advancing our fundamental knowledge of how cells grow and proliferate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative: Our program aims to build a molecular and optical cell atlas of the human inner ear as a resource for the scientific community to accelerate progress in discovering effective therapies for auditory and vestibular disorders. To achieve this objective, we will apply the latest molecular and optical imaging tools to live human inner ear tissues from organ donors, vestibular schwannoma patients, and rapid autopsy participants. We will also raise awareness of human inner ear research and enhance opportunities for collaboration by making our data and tissues widely available, by providing technical instruction, and by outreach activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance This project seeks to enroll patients onto clinical trials that explore strategies to improve outcomes after hematopoietic stem cell transplant and genetically modified T cell therapies. Based in the Southeast, our consortium will be important in enrolling increased numbers of minorities and rural individuals to these studies. This application also proposes a clinical trial to directly compare outcomes of two currently-used methods to reduce post-transplant graft-versus-host disease, to determine if one is more advantageous than the other.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will characterize a chemokine receptor inhibitor as a radiation countermeasure to mitigate radiation induced Paneth cell dysfunction. Paneth cells are intestinal cell type involved in intestinal epithelial homeostasis and mucosal innate immune response. This proposal will define the mechanism of action of the countermeasure which will provide data necessary for product licensure requirements according to the FDA Animal Rule.
