IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: While venetoclax-based therapies lead to remission for 60-70% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the majority will relapse due to the emergence of drug resistance. We propose that clonal heterogeneity in leukemia initiating cells (LIC) underlies the failure to achieve durable responses. Here, we propose determine the characteristics of AML LIC subpopulations that mediate therapy sensitivity/resistance, in order to design combinatorial therapeutic strategies that lead to more durable remissions for patients with AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The mission of the PsycheMERGE Network is to advance equitable precision psychiatry in learning healthcare system frameworks across the United States. During the course of this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators at twelve academic medical centers will bring together clinical data (>29 million individuals), genetic data (>1.9 million), and an extraordinary range of scientific expertise (psychiatry, medical informatics, machine learning, statistics, genetics, sociomedical sciences, decision sciences, and ethics) to advance this mission. We will leverage this expertise and data to build on our prior success and address barriers to scalability, utility of genomic data, clinical application, and translation to clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative It has been difficult to elucidate the neural mechanisms of drug action in detail using traditional pharmacological approaches that are slow and poorly localized in the brain. This work aims to develop light-activated variants of clinically used drugs that can be photoreleased in awake, behaving experimental animals to study the mechanisms of drug action with exceptional precision. These research reagents may also lead to novel phototherapies for pain and disorders involving the nervous system. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Upstream open reading frames (uORFs) are associated with numerous diseases, as they regulate mRNA stability and translation. This study investigates uORF features and functions involved in mRNA decay and translation controlled by evolutionarily conserved regulators using a model system that enables in vivo and whole-organism level studies. Our findings could open doors to innovative diagnosis and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative  Chronic exposure to elevated manganese (Mn) levels, typically found in occupational environments, has been associated with olfactory dysfunction, cognitive impairment, and neurological symptoms resembling those seen in AD/ADRD. Nevertheless, the precise molecular mechanisms underlying these compromised olfaction and cognition in environmentally related AD/ADRD remain unclear. This proposal aims to investigate the involvement of a compensatory signaling pathway, mediated by the neuropeptide prokineticin 2 (PK2), in the context of an environmentally linked AD model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sickle cell disease (SCD), which arises from a missense mutation in the β-globin gene that causes polymerization of sickle hemoglobin (HbS), affects approximately 100,000 individuals in the United States and is associated with shortened life expectancy, with only 50% of patients surviving beyond their fifth decade. The use of hydroxyurea, newer second-line therapies, and chronic blood transfusion may alleviate some of the complications of SCD, but allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) using a matched related donor is the only potential cure and is considered standard of care for patients with severe SCD. The proposed phase II clinical trial in adults and children with severe SCD will evaluate a pharmacologic immunosuppressive strategy prior to reduced toxicity myeloablative mismatched unrelated donor (MMUD) HCT, followed by post-transplant cyclophosphamide (PTCY)-based graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) prophylaxis, in order to mitigate risk of graft failure in a patient population at high risk for allograft rejection and treatment-related complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic diversity is a fundamental aspect of human natural history. Variations in susceptibility to complex diseases within the human population highlight the significance of understanding genomic diversity to uncover previously unknown mechanisms of common diseases risk. This proposal seeks to elucidate the contribution of human-specific genomic diversity to the regulation of cell fate commitment and the maintenance of cellular states across a spectrum of cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Major questions in photobiology are how environmental ultraviolet radiation (UVR)-treated skin sends systemic signals, as well as potential interactions of UVR with other agents such as pollutants found on skin. This project applies multiple well-established techniques and approaches at cellular and molecular levels to investigate the involvement of the lipid mediator Platelet-activating factor (PAF) in the augmentation of UVR-induced microvesicle particle (MVP) release by the polyaromatic hydrocarbons, anthracene, chrysene, and pyrene. These studies will define the exact mechanism by which these ubiquitous pollutants can interact with UVR with one of the major outcomes being the generation of ROS, PAF, and MVP.

PHR: Co-localization of Tyrosine sulfation and O-glycosylation plays critical roles in binding/signaling pathways in biological systems. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A better understanding on how limitations in pediatric onco-critical care resources impact ongoing use and sustainability of evidence-based interventions is urgently needed to improve childhood cancer survival in low- resource settings. This project studies how resource availability in low-resource hospitals in Latin American impact the clinical capacity to sustain Pediatric Early Warning System (PEWS)—evidence-based intervention to improve childhood cancer outcomes. Upon completion, this study will identify hospital resources that contribute to sustainability of interventions low-resource hospitals, thus advancing the parent grant’s goal to develop strategies to promote sustainability, thus advancing the field of science of implementation and improving global childhood cancer survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need to identify the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying cerebrovascular function in both healthy and disease states associated with aging. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With assistance from this diversity supplement to R01DK127138 (PI: Anand), Dr. Marimar Contreras-Nieves MD, MS candidate will obtain hands-on research training in her field of interest, kidney disease among agricultural workers. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Premature birth increases the risk of a chronic lung condition called bronchopulmonary dysplasia, which increases the lifetime burden of medical needs and developmental deficits. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of the BMT CTN are to identify and address gaps in transplantation and cellular therapy for blood diseases, train new clinical investigators, contribute to the database and build a biorepository for non-malignant diseases, disseminate results, and improve patient quality of life. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this project we will perform pilot studies to determine how actomyosin defects in neurons contribute to Alzheimer’s disease (AD) pathology. This work will create a better understanding of the cellular events that cause AD and potentially identify new targets for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: Concentrative nucleoside transporters (CNTs) encoded by the SLC28 gene family, belong to the second nucleoside transporter (NT) family, and contribute to the uptake and biodistribution of nucleoside derived anti-HIV drugs. Unfortunately, while potent and highly selective inhibitors and probes are available to study the biology and pharmacology of their equilibrative transporter (ENT) counterparts, none of such probes are available for CNTs, thus severely hampering progress in their biological studies. This proposal aims at developing the first highly potent and subtype-selective inhibitors for each of the three human (h) CNTs, hCNT1, hCNT2 and hCNT3, to provide chemical tool compounds for studying their physiological and pathophysiology, to allow rational design and optimization of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) as HIV/AIDS therapeutic regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tissue-resident macrophages (TRMs) are critical component of innate immune response and are also involved in maintaining body homeostasis and resolving inflammation after injury. Loss of abundance of TRMs and their tissue repair abilities results to tissue damage and diseases. Nociceptor sensory neurons innervate the peripheral sites and tissue microenvironment where TRMs are co-localized but the knowledge about their interactions in maintenance and function of TRMs is lacking. This proposed research will address the key knowledge gaps pertaining to the role of neuron-TRM interactions in inflammation and repair and will ultimately improve our ability to develop therapeutics against inflammatory diseases by targeting their interactions.

PHR: Project narrative: The imagery, data and experimental tools of biomedical science are inaccessible to people with blindness, leading to systemic exclusion. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In Chicago, youth from disadvantaged backgrounds on the South and West sides are exposed to alarmingly high levels of community violence, which detrimentally impacts their overall well-being. This project aims to evaluate a novel violence prevention program to address structural inequities—Community Health Advocates in Mitigating and Preventing Violence (CHAMP-V) with and without Legal Aid Wraparound (LAW). Results from this project will provide rigorous evidence about the effect of community health advocacy and legal advocacy strategies to prevent community violence for youth and their families while offering a scalable approach can target all levels of the social-ecological model.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study takes a multi-modal approach to investigate root causes of aberrant brain-gut signaling in children diagnosed with ‘functional’ gastrointestinal disorders but suffering from multisystem complaints concerning for autonomic dysregulation. The project brings together a team of productive scientists across several disciplines, applying cutting-edge technology and validated metrics to build on established, successful collaborations. Guided by solid preliminary data and published evidence, this multidisciplinary proposal investigates brain-gut physiology while providing a path towards personalized medicine using non-invasive, evidence-based neuromodulation therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed administrative supplement will support pilot work for a project to quantify the effect of structural white advantage (SWA) – policies and practices that provide greater resources and power to people racialized as white – on cognitive health and Alzheimer’s diseases and related dementias (ADRD) risk among older US adults. Understanding the linkage between SWA and cognitive health may reveal the effectiveness of policies/programs that target the distribution of resources to dominated groups (non-white) to promote health equity. Additionally, the SWA framework provides a theoretical grounding to dissect potential heterogeneities in cognitive reserve processes and outcomes among those racialized as white, providing additional clues on how the intersection among structural inequities (e.g., SWA and classism) determine ADRD disparities at the population level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The discovery and characterization of BRCA1 and BRCA2 and their sister genes have had tremendous impact on prevention and treatment of breast and ovarian cancer, yet family history remains one of the most important risk factors for these cancers, and a great deal of that risk remains unexplained as the result of technical limitations of current genomics technologies. The goal of this project is to deploy transformative new technologies on behalf of these families. This project is intended to stimulate discovery of causal genetic events for inherited breast and ovarian cancer and thereby for other inherited illnesses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Repurposing thermally-activated enzymes with photoexcitation has emerged as a promising strategy for realizing challenging reactions in pharmaceutical synthesis, such as asymmetric radical reactions. We propose to develop computational tools for understanding the mechanisms of photoenzymes and for designing new enzyme variants and protein scaffolds capable of photoenzymatic reactions. We envision that our computational framework will greatly accelerate the development of photoenzymes for synthesizing pharmaceuticals and will in the long term also facilitate the identification of natural enzymes that may have previously unknown photoenzymatic activity as new drug targets, thus having high impact on human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circadian rhythms allow organisms to coordinate their behavior and physiology with daily and seasonal changes but also temporally coordinate internal processes across organ systems. Although the overall architecture of circadian systems is conserved across phylogeny and between sexes, circadian systems are not identical between sexes. The goal of this proposal is to investigate fundamental biology of sex differences in circadian function from the brain to peripheral tissues across the lifespan and under conditions of dietary stress, identifying principles that will allow us to leverage chronobiology to improve human health in more personalized ways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to build the Sickle Cell Disease Pain Analgesia and Integrative Network (SCDPAIN) as an innovative, dynamic and interactive platform that will advance the NCCIH's mission for research on pain mechanisms in sickle cell disease (SCD) through multimodal dissemination efforts. Guided by an unmet need to address the morbidity associated with pain in SCD, we will assemble leading investigators in SCD pathobiology, pain, organ damage and integrative medicine to collaborate for advancing basic and translational science using cutting-edge technology, passionate mentoring and pilot funding to the future leaders, promoting diversity and inclusion to conduct innovative research to transform scientific advancements in SCD pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Systemic amyloidosis is a disease caused by the continual build-up of misfolded proteins in organs and tissues throughout the body. These proteins, not naturally recognized and cleared by the body, fibrilize and destroy organ architecture thereby limiting effective organ function. Here we report that collagen-1 impedes immune cell recognition of amyloid deposits and propose therapeutic intervention strategies to overcome this effect.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will examine the fundamental mechanism underlying alcohol effects on the vulnerability to the cognitive impairments associated with Alzheimer Disease (AD). We will explore the hypothesis that genetic risk for alcohol consumption contributes to the risk of developing AD, even in the absence of exposure to alcohol. We will use the largest available genetic studies of AD in humans to extract genetic component of the risk of AD, and, using sophisticated statistical techniques, will estimate the contribution of genetic risk for alcohol consumption, measured in a rat model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The role of late life depression in cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s Disease risk Narrative The risk of developing Alzheimer’s Disease increases by three-fold for people who experience symptoms of depression in older age. The goal of this administrative supplement to parent R01 MH128286 is to identify shared neural mechanisms of depressive symptoms and cognitive decline in late life, and to establish how late life depression influences the development of cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s Disease pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative While regulation of the shape and form of the energy generating organelles, mitochondria, through fission and fusion (mitochondrial dynamics) is linked to a variety of complex cellular processes, the exact relations between mitochondrial form and function are still not fully understood. In this study, we will examine the roles of mitochondrial dynamics in retinal rod photoreceptor cells that display unique shape and arrangement of mitochondria using mouse models. Successful completion of this study will provide novel insights into the relationship between mitochondrial form and function as well as the functional significance of mitochondrial dynamics in the retinal health, and may suggest novel therapeutic strategies for retinal conditions associated with mitochondrial abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vasoproliferative retinopathies are the leading causes of blindness. Understanding the molecular underpinnings of retinal vascular diseases is essential for discovering novel or improved therapeutic options. This proposal aims to determine how distinct innate immune signaling controls the growth and regression of neovessels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: DNA methylation is a heritable epigenetic mark that is dynamically remodeled in development and largely stable in adult soma. Recurrent genome wide DNA methylation aberrations are common upon excessive proliferations, whose molecular basis and functional consequences remain poorly understood. Using mouse skin as our model, we study the role of DNA methylation in bridging retrotransposon control and adult stem cell fate decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public health relevance statement Transmembrane transporters play vital roles in cell physiology, diseases, and therapy; however, their insertion into lipid bilayers makes them challenging systems to investigate computationally and experimentally. Among transmembrane transporters, alkali and alkaline earth metal cation transporters received significant attention, while the anion and transition metal transporters have not. The proposed project will establish a computational framework to systematically investigate the complex anion and transition metal transporters to uncover the underlying biochemical and molecular basis for ion selectivity and transport mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of the RCMI Specialized Center, Ola HAWAII, is to improve minority health and reduce health disparities for those communities in Hawaii which suffer disproportionately in health outcomes and healthcare access. In the next five years, the objective of the Center is to lead and advance minority health and health disparities research in Hawaii. Ola HAWAII has assembled an exemplary team to build institutional capacity in basic biomedical, clinical and behavioral research; engage underserved communities; mentor and support a diversified workforce; and enhance core facilities and resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While phosphate is involved in many fundamental cell processes including DNA synthesis, bone formation, and storage of energy in high energy phosphates, it is unknown how mammalian cells sense and regulate phosphate homeostasis to avoid deficiency or excess. Phosphate deficiency can lead to serious complications including muscle breakdown; conversely, phosphate excess predisposes to heart attacks and strokes, which is especially problematic for many of the 60% of Americans who are affected by chronic kidney disease over their lifetime. Our preliminary work has identified several pathways that regulate cellular phosphate homeostasis and sensing of phosphate availability that are the foundation of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early social interactions, especially negative ones, can result in long lasting behavior phenotypes. Here we introduce a unique ant species Harpegnathos saltator as a model for studying how epigenetic factors and gene regulation influence neuronal circuitry and social behaviors. The aims of this research proposal are how social interactions induce epigenetic changes, create ant models for autism spectrum disorders, and to uncover the epigenetic mechanisms underlying social behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Our research aims to design new protocols that enable sustainable access to a range of nitrogenated compounds. Specifically, the installment of amines, amides and nitriles is targeted due to the ubiquity of these groups in biologically active molecules, commercial drugs, and their versatility as synthetic building blocks. From a broader perspective, it is expected that this work will contribute to an increase in the use of Ni-mediated transformations in industrial and academic lab settings by designing protocols that are easily scalable and avoid using toxic reagents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative Hearingloss has been reported in 37% of people living withAlzheimer's disease (AD), a global health crisis with no cure. The link between these two pathologies has not been established and it is not known if hearing loss and AD share a common underlying mechanism. Completion of this project will establish if tissue-resident macrophage populations in the cochlea and microglia in the brain are the common pathological link between hearing loss and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intimate partner sexual violence (IPSV) is a significant public health problem; however, research is needed to understand how and among whom ISPV is most likely to occur. By accounting for effects at both the individual- and couple-level in sexual minority and heterosexual couples, this study will be the first to determine (1) how alcohol intoxication and sexual communication predict IPSV perpetration in laboratory and real-world contexts and (2) the temporal relationship between alcohol use and IPSV. Results from this study will directly inform an etiological framework on IPSV, from which researchers and clinicians can develop programs to curb rates of alcohol-related IPSV among sexual minority and heterosexual couples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we will use freshwater planarians (flatworms) and zebrafish to understand the roles of the ELMO pathway in the clearance of dying cells in adult tissue turnover and injury regeneration. We will identify the engulfing cell types and molecular pathways needed for adult dying cell clearance, then determine how altering cell death and corpse clearance function to ensure successful regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative [Parent project] Pancreatic cancer is one of the most deadly malignancies in the United States. In this highly collaborative study, a multidisciplinary team of investigators from the University of California at Davis, TargaGenix and Northeastern University, will collaborate to develop a clinically translatable nanoemulsion-based delivery system for our lead agent in combination with immunotherapy for effective treatment of pancreatic tumors. The proposed solution will lead to the development of a promising new combination anticancer therapeutic modality, especially against aggressive and highly metastatic diseases, such as pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROEJCT NARRATIVE In the Multiethnic Cohort (MEC) based in Hawaii and Los Angeles, the risk of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) showed a two-fold difference by race/ethnicity; highest among African Americans and Native Hawaiians, lowest in Asian Americans, and intermediate in Latinos and Whites. Emerging evidence suggests that non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), detected in over 30% of older adults, increases the risk of ADRD, and that pro-inflammatory gut microbiota may be involved in the liver-brain connection. We propose to evaluate whether ADRD risk is higher among NAFLD patients in MEC, whether the exclusive blood marker for microbial inflammation is related to the blood marker for brain inflammation, and whether and how gut microbial characteristics (diversity, composition, functions) are related to the blood marker for brain inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Colorectal cancer (CRC) is common and deadly, but screening has been demonstrated to reduce incidence and mortality. Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHCs) are government-funded primary care facilities that frequently use stool-based CRC screening tests that are effective yet require colonoscopy follow-up when results are abnormal. The proposed study will evaluate the impact of a multilevel, multicomponent intervention on follow-up colonoscopy rates after abnormal screening test results in a large FQHC with low colonoscopy follow-up rates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PI: Mitra, Sharmistha Project Narrative Amylopectinosis is a process by which soluble glycogen becomes insoluble and precipitates into toxic aggregates in tissues. Linear ubiquitin chain assembly complex (LUBAC) controls glycogen solubility and the absence of it results in life claiming polyglucosan body myopathy-1 disease. Our work is set to uncover the mechanisms through which LUBAC controls glycogen solubility with the expectation of insights into the treatments for this rare condition as well as other common adult diseases where both LUBAC and glycogen are known to play critical roles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the PsycheMERGE Network is to advance equitable precision psychiatry in learning healthcare system frameworks across the United States. During the course of this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators at twelve academic medical centers will bring together clinical data (>29 million individuals), genetic data (>1.9 million), and an extraordinary range of scientific expertise (psychiatry, medical informatics, machine learning, statistics, genetics, sociomedical sciences, decision sciences, and ethics) to advance this mission. We will leverage this expertise and data to build on our prior success and address barriers to scalability, utility of genomic data, clinical application, and translation to clinical practice.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The ability to treat and prevent illness and improve human health requires not only a detailed understanding of the complex interplay of biological systems contributing to disease processes but also the mechanisms underlying the influence of social complexity on biological systems. The systems science approach provides methods uniquely suited to elucidate the mechanisms by which social systems influence health. The proposed research adopts this approach by modeling the short- and long-term effects of social interventions on the multiscale and multilayer networks and their effects on biomarkers of individual health in a well- established nonhuman primate model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The present Supplement will investigate the detrimental interactions of drugs of abuse and AD with or without concomitant HIV. To this end we will use iPCS-derived neural cultures to model AD in vitro. Ultimately, the proposed experimental-computational approach will result in a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms that are behind the neurodegeneration in HIV, drug abuse, and AD as well as their interactions and will highlight mechanisms of pathogenesis and candidate new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The concept of this program derives from our observations that the involution of the human thymus does not follow linear kinetics and is tailored to each individual. We ask how often we can find a functional thymus in the elderly population and find predictors of the thymic function longevity in the elderly. The preliminary results strongly support our hypothesis that the thymus, or part of the organ, may function into old age. In this research proposal, we aim (1) to meet the research goals specified in three research aims, and (2) to provide the Kentucky College of Osteopathic Medicine students with much-needed exposure to basic biomedical research through this REAP funding mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed Center for Pacific Innovations, Knowledge, and Opportunities (PIKO) addresses several issues of central importance to building a robust clinical and translational research (CTR) infrastructure that directly improves the health and wellbeing of indigenous Pacific People (IPP), defined as Native Hawaiians, Other Pacific Islanders, and Filipinos, and other underserved populations. The Center will establish a strong collaborative among three academic institutions and a statewide network of stakeholders, including practice-based and community-based organizations and health care providers; convert basic discoveries into real-world solutions to improve IPP health and reduce IPP health disparities; and increase the number of junior and other investigators, particularly from IPP backgrounds, for CTR careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proteins are the functional workhorses of cells, and a protein’s function is related to and can be predicted from its structure. There is, however, a large class of proteins that have essential biological roles and yet do not have a defined structure (i.e., they’re disordered) and whose function cannot be predicted. This study will use a novel computational approach to comprehensively classify this enigmatic class of sequences to develop a predictive understanding of their function.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed CDA-2 will provide Dr. Loflin with the training and data to advance research aimed at improving mental health care among Veterans. The proposed study will include a novel RCT to investigate the efficacy of PE+CBD compared to PE+placebo using a sample of 136 Veterans with PTSD. This will be the first study to test a cannabinoid therapeutic for PTSD within VA. Results from this study will directly inform patient care among Veterans with PTSD, and will be used to inform development of future clinical trial and implementation studies that seek to improve the lives and functioning of Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ribonucleic acid (RNA)-protein complexes are integral for every step of gene regulation in the cell, and noncoding RNA-protein complexes especially represent a large unexplored landscape of novel biology and potential therapeutic targets. We have a limited understanding of the contexts – nucleotide sequence, structure, and interaction networks – that determine how and where proteins assemble on RNAs in the cell, and how these complexes might be targeted by small molecules for therapeutic benefit. This proposal describes multiple technological advances in chemical probing and sequencing that will in the long term create a new encyclopedia of RNA-protein network elements, supporting new fundamental discoveries and highlighting the therapeutic potential of noncoding RNA-protein complexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA damage arising from oxidative stress promotes multiple human diseases, and the cell’s primary defense against these lesions is the base excision repair (BER) pathway. The overarching goal of this study is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms coupling two key biological tasks in response to oxidative DNA damage at certain G- quadruplex promoter sequences –specifically, BER and the transcriptional activation of genes associated with cancer and other diseases. By elucidating the mechanism of gene activation, the findings of this proposal will provide the details required for rational drug design towards targeting their expression by disrupting the key regulatory protein:DNA interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Blood flow is essential for ensuring that brain cells have enough energy to fulfill their functions and this energy is extracted from the sugar and the oxygen carried in the blood. Here, we reveal an important novel aspect of an electrical signaling mechanism that brain pericytes (cells that sit on the smallest blood vessels - capillaries) use to precisely match blood flow to local brain energy needs. Through this work we will uncover the unique interactions of ion channels and signaling proteins that constitute this mechanism, which we call the “pericyte chloride clamp”, and thus completing these studies may help to identify novel drug targets on pericytes for therapies that aim to protect or restore blood flow in brain disorders with a blood flow component, such as Alzheimer’s disease and other neurodegenerative conditions.

PHR: Project Narrative The three-dimensional folding of the genome is crucial for the regulation of gene expression. Dysregulations in genome folding have been linked to various diseases, including cancer and developmental disorders. The objective of my proposal is to elucidate the regulatory mechanism of genome folding in living cells, enhancing our understanding of its role in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: U.S. NATIONAL HEART LUNG AND BLOOD INST
PHR: Project Narrative  Fold-switching proteins challenge the expectation that amino acid sequence dictates only one secondary structure  fold with little understanding of the evolution pathway that made fold-switching prevalent in multiple species downstream of the mutation event. Recent work has identiﬁed fold-switching proteins in human disease, ORF9b in  SARS-CoV-2, but there continues to be a limitation in analyzing fold-switching proteins using techniques that rely  on in vitro techniques. At the completion of this this proposed work I anticipate to not only have an ancestral  reconstruction of the RfaH fold-switching protein, but also structural characterization of mutations to identify  critical residues that support folding dynamics using a new robust and rapid technique, FLIM-FRET.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This competing renewal requests continued support for the U19 “Center without Walls” entitled “Center Without Walls for Imaging Proteinopathies with PET”. This Center consists of the scientific integration of individuals with an international reputation in the fields of neurobiology, neurology, medicinal chemistry, PET radiochemistry and CNS PET imaging studies towards the common goal of developing PET radiotracers for imaging aggregated alpha synuclein and 4R tau, and investigating their role in neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson’s disease (PD), Multiple System Atrophy (MSA) and Frontotemporal Dementia. The scientific resources created by the funding of this U19 Center has led to the first application of the use of ultrahigh throughput screening of large in silico compound libraries in PET radiotracer development. Two radiotracers for imaging alpha synuclein in MSA and PD have been translated to date to the Clinical Core; a third radiotracer for 4R tau is anticipated in year 5 of the current application. The radiotracers developed by this U19 Center are expected to have an important impact on the scientific mission of the National Institute on Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) in the study of the synucleinopathies and 4R tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Significance Understanding the alterations in neuropil and connectivity pattern in multiple layers of networks involving structural covariance, white matter and functional connectomes is critical to elucidate adolescent brain maturation. Alterations in these processe may elucidate potential mechanisms underlying nearly 50% of psychiatric illnesses beginning during adolescence which are increasing in the last 2 decades especially among adolescents from lower socioeconomic status (SES) with its adverse consequences on school performance, family relationships, substance use and criminal justice system. This is more onerous for persons who have a first-degree relative with schizophrenia where our proposal could highlight neural pathways as targets for developing new treatment approaches and develop better predictive models to potentially mitigate the risk and develop preventative efforts.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of this work is to study the structure-function relationship of fibrin(ogen) and its relation to health and disease. These fundamental properties of fibrin(ogen) have pathological implications for a variety of diseases and conditions including cancer, thrombosis, pregnancy, and wound healing.

PHR: Project Narrative: A fundamental question for the field of biology is understanding the molecular and cellular mechanisms that regulate tissue regeneration. This work will expand our understanding of how tissue regeneration is regulated and provide insights for the advancement of regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a library of switchable and functional fluorescent probes for multi-functional single-molecule super-resolution imaging of live cells. I will encode distinct single-molecule spectral features of the switchable fluorophores and integrate them with a spectroscopic single-molecule optical imaging platform in the three research thrusts to collectively achieve multi-functional nanoscopic imaging capabilities. This project will allow biomedical researchers, for the first time, to achieve simultaneous interaction imaging of multiple molecules and functional imaging of their surrounding nanoenvironment which fundamentally regulate distinct subcellular processes.

PHR: Project Narrative Dissecting synaptic connectivity is essential for understanding normal brain functions and diseases. However, current available fluorescent sensors that are aimed for detecting synaptic contacts have limitations in in vivo settings. We propose to demonstrate the versatility of a newly developed sensor and apply it to investigate both excitatory and inhibitory connectivity in the context of learning, which will yield valuable resources that contribute significantly to the study of neural circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: NARRATIVE: Mitochondrial dysfunction is closely linked to a spectrum of disorders, ranging from primary mitochondrial diseases to age-associated conditions like neurodegenerative diseases. The proposed work here seeks to comprehensively uncover the intricate molecular mechanisms governing the maintenance of mitochondrial homeostasis. These findings hold significant promise for unlocking potential therapeutic avenues to treat diseases associated with mitochondrial dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project addresses fundamental questions about the genetic, molecular, and evolutionary mechanisms underlying changes in gene regulation. Gene regulation is a fundamental process that underlies human health, and how regulation evolves is a key determinant of how it can break down and contribute to disease. A better understanding of the causes and consequences of regulatory change will improve our ability to predict the effects of genetic variation on health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Digital therapeutics for alcohol use disorder are modestly effective but their benefits may be constrained because engagement is often not sustained or matched to patients’ needs. “Smart” digital therapeutics that are enhanced by personal sensing and embedded machine learning lapse prediction models that provide individualized, temporally-precise, risk-relevant information to patients may address these limitations. Our broad goal is to develop a machine learning guided engagement message system that can be added to any smart digital therapeutic to increase risk-relevant engagement and improve clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian innate immune system is essential for host survival, and dysregulation is associated with many human diseases. Activation of the innate immune system is mediated by multiprotein signaling complexes called inflammasomes, but the mechanism of how inflammasomes assemble are not well understood. The goal of this proposal is to systematically map out the assembly of inflammasomes in space and time, which will yield unprecedented mechanistic insights about human immunology that may help develop new treatments for inflammatory diseases and also provide a blueprint for studying other multiprotein signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Administrative burdens—the compliance, learning, and psychological costs people face when interacting with and applying for government services—are a key barrier to obtaining health insurance for the over 11 million uninsured Americans that are eligible for subsidized coverage in the Health Insurance Marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act, as well as millions of Americans that lost Medicaid coverage at the end of the Public Health Emergency and are now eligible to enroll in subsidized Marketplace coverage. This project will use com- plementary quantitative and qualitative research methods from economics, public administration, and anthro- pology to: (1) determine whether premium payment-related compliance costs affects reenrollment in Market- place coverage; (2) determine whether reducing the burden of information costs through advertising affects Marketplace coverage take-up; and (3) create a person-centered understanding of how compliance, infor- mation, and psychological costs erect barriers to Marketplace coverage. This project is relevant to public health because it will identify policy changes state and federal policymakers could make to increase Marketplace health insurance take-up that are not dependent on federal legislation or significant state budget outlays, thereby providing health insurance coverage, which has been shown to reduce mortality, to the remaining un- insured, who disproportionately consist of AHRQ priority populations.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Reducing Uninsurance by Addressing Administrative Burdens in the Health Insurance Marketplaces

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative By 2030 almost half of adults are projected to be obese, with nearly 25% projected to have severe obesity. As relatively little is known about how to reduce the prevalence of obesity, our proposal will provide new evidence on the effects of awards from the CDC’s Division of Nutrition, Physical Activity, and Obesity to state and local health departments, land-grant universities, and community-focused organizations, aimed at promoting healthy eating and physical activity. To study the effects of federal funding for obesity prevention on weight-related health behaviors, the prevalence of obesity, and the incidence of obesity-related chronic conditions, we will leverage variation in which states and counties received these awards, when they received the awards, the size of the awards, and the demographic groups targeted by the awards.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapy leverages the body’s immune system to target cancer, but it can lead to off-target side effects that present as acute interstitial nephritis in the kidneys. There are no non-invasive biomarkers of ICI-induced acute interstitial nephritis, which poses significant diagnostic and therapeutic challenges. We will recruit a longitudinal cohort of 400 participants receiving ICIs who develop acute kidney injury to identify biomarkers and dysregulated pathways in acute tubulointerstitial nephritis to improve diagnosis and treatment response phenotyping.

PHR: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a painful and disabling joint disorder affecting more than 30 million Americans, and none of the current treatments for OA are clinically demonstrated to reverse OA progression. The successful completion of this study will generate a potential drug pool that is ready for study in human clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conflicts between transcription and replication machinery are frequent and the consequences on DNA replication are the subject of many studies. In contrast, the consequences on transcription and gene expression remain essentially unexplored. As accurate regulation of gene expression is crucial for normal development and dysregulation of transcription is a key factor in disease states, this proposal aims to investigate how these conflicts affect transcription and their physiological significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this work we will develop advanced cellular labeling and imaging tools to address a range of biophysical questions related to molecular mechanisms behind cellular function, including how the dynamics of chromatin organization affect gene expression and what the molecular mechanisms are that underlie Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome (HGPS). HGPS is caused by mutations in the nuclear lamina protein prelamin A. Determining the molecular mechanisms of how mutated prelamin A distributes and interacts with other proteins and DNA and how these mechanisms are affected by available and novel drugs will lay the foundation for advances in disease treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Addressing the pivotal challenge of re-delivering gene therapy via Adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) due to immune constraints, this research pioneers advanced delivery and targeting strategies across three distinct pharmaceutical platforms to modulate immune responses and enable repeated gene therapy. By overcoming specific biological barriers and controlling adverse immune reactions, this work aspires to significantly advance the safety and efficacy of gene therapies while developing novel delivery platforms for therapeutic cells, enzymes, and vaccines. The realization of this research promises to mitigate illnesses and disabilities associated with genetic disorders, thereby contributing to enhanced public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Mast cells (MC) are potent inflammatory cells that dramatically increase in concentration in the lungs of asthmatics and nasal polyps, however the committed progenitor from which they are thought to arise from is one of the rarest cells in circulation. After identifying a series of markers to better identify MC progenitors (MCps) within inflamed airway tissue, we observed that MCp robustly proliferative within inflamed tissue, likely explaining their disproportionate relationship with tissue resident MC concentration. This proposal seeks to better characterize infiltrating MCp in human airway tissue, identify the discrete epithelial- and fibroblast- derived signals responsible for directing MCp proliferation and differentiation, and determining the transcription factor networks that underly the resulting MC phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to elucidate the mechanisms and extent of two key processes involved in oral drug absorption, the particle drifting effect and precipitation kinetics, and to provide guidance for the development of oral enabling formulations. The proposed work will develop a combined experimental and modeling framework to achieve model-based formulation development and improved bioavailability prediction. The generated knowledge will greatly decrease drug development costs, reduce the need of animal pharmacokinetic experiments, allow more drugs to enter the market, lessen patients’ financial burden, and ultimately save more patients’ lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to develop new synthetic methods that will improve access to critical materials for the discovery and manufacture of medicinal agents. These methods will include (a) olefin difunctionalizations to rapidly convert simple and abundant chemical feedstocks into complex skeletons and pharmacophores, and (b) stereoselective α-functionalizations of carbonyls to generate novel amino acids and medicinal products and intermediates. Owing to their “radical-mediated migration” mechanisms that have significant latent potential, these new approaches will afford clear advances in pharmaceutical synthesis by enabling reactions with improved stereocontrol and a significantly expanded range of medicinally valuable motifs they can access.

PROJECT_TITLE: Harnessing the Latent Potential of Radical Migration to Drive Synthetic Innovation

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Great Plains and Midwestern states lack scientists with the cross-cutting training to both push forward foundational, biomedical research, and effectively educate the scholars of the future. The IRACDA at the University of Kansas (KU) seeks to address this challenge by providing postdoctoral scholars expertise in research through experiential training with an accomplished KU faculty member. Additionally, our KU-IRACDA scholars will gain instructional experience via collaborations with Haskell Indian Nations University (a tribal college dedicated to educating members of American Indian and Alaska Native communities) and Kansas City Kansas Community College (a 2-year college with a diverse student body), where they will simultaneously act as early career mentors for students from groups underrepresented in the biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alterations in the human microbiome have been associated with a wide variety of diseases; however, the specific mechanisms that allow microbiota to regulate host health have not been fully elucidated. This work will explore the microbiome’s role in tissue homeostasis by investigating how commensal bacteria degrade ECM, identifying microbial enzymes involved in this process, and understanding the impact of remodeled ECM on innate immune cell behavior. In the long term, these studies will lead to the identification of mechanisms that link human microbiota to ECM dysregulation and inflammation, potentially paving the way towards novel diagnostic and therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulated aldosterone production from one or both adrenal glands (primary aldosteronism, PA) is the most common cause of endocrine hypertension, accounting for 5-10% of hypertension and 14-20% of resistant hypertension. Research focused on defining the genetic causes of PA in Black Americans is limited despite their high prevalence of hypertension, and the higher susceptibility to hyperaldosteronism and cardiovascular mortality. The central goals of this proposal are to define the spectrum of adrenal aldosterone-driver somatic mutations in Black American PA patients and identify targeted therapeutics that block mutation-driven aldosterone production in endocrine hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Body development requires precise gene expression in a spatial and temporal manner, which is controlled by epigenetic modifications. We aim to understand how a critical epigenetic mark is regulated to control gene expression. A complete understanding of the regulation program will reveal new cellular or pharmacological strategies for treating genetic disorders with dysregulated gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic screens, in which mutations are randomly made in a large number of genes in the genome and their phenotypic effect on tissues of interest are assayed, have been a predominant approach for functionally characterizing the roles of genes in development. However, traditional genetic screens are limited because some genes are required for multiple functions, some functions can be accomplished by multiple genes, and because screens are very laborious especially in vertebrates. Here, we leverage recent technological advances in single cell perturbation and measurement along with the “regulative ability” of vertebrates to develop a new type of genetic screen in which cells with different mutations compete within an embryo to form a normal embryo, and use this approach to study the eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Nearly 50% of the human genome is made up of mobile elements and ancient retroviruses called RetroElements (REs) that are present in thousands of nearly identical copies. As REs are paradoxically expressed during preimplantation development and recent findings reveal that RE reactivation is precise and essential for mammalian development, this proposal seeks to establish the functional importance and mechanistic basis of RE reactivation through gene editing, comparative biology and novel CRISPR based screening. Notably, REs are unintentionally reactivated in aging, autoimmunity, neurodegeneration and cancer and we predict that by cataloging RE-based mechanisms in embryos and identifying RE-regulation, we can therapeutically manipulate REs in adult tissue to mitigate or potentially reverse disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Although inflammation is a major driver of mortality in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), systemic immunomodulation remains plagued by poor biodistribution to the lung, toxicity, infections due to deleterious systemic immunosuppression, and paradoxical pro-inflammatory responses, all of which limit clinical translation. This project will address these shortcomings by utilizing a novel cell therapy platform to: (i) enable sustained cell survival and delivery of secretory proteins locally to the lung via the airway or pleural cavity; (ii) understand local cytokine delivery modulates lung immune populations to promote lung tissue repair; and (iii) translate therapy in a clinically relevant fashion to a large animal model of ARDS. Overall, these studies will develop therapeutic “off-the-shelf” cell therapy system with sustained survival and functionality for application for ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Advances in omics technologies – such as genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics, and microbiomes – have introduced an unprecedented level of granularity into both clinical and bio- logical measurements. However, using these data to discern causal factors and mechanisms under- lying diseases is challenging due to their high dimensionality, correlation, and complexity. The current proposal aims to address this gap by developing rigorous causal inference methods and software for integrative analysis of omics data, providing new insights on disease etiology and ultimately transform the potential of massive biomedical data into trustworthy, actionable, and generalizable knowledge to solve public health challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Narrative While Hispanics are the fastest growing segment of the U.S. population, they are significantly underrepresented at all levels in the scientific community. This proposal is designed to increase the numbers of underrepresented minorities into academic science by promoting the career development of postdoctoral scholars as science researchers and educators through a partnership between Einstein as a research-intensive institution and Hostos Community College and Lehman College, both Hispanic-serving teaching institutions. The activities of this program and of postdoctoral scholar scientist/educators supported by the program will increase the pool of capable undergraduates interested in research at the partner institutions. Ultimately, it is expected that this program will enhance the numbers of underrepresented minorities in academic science, who will, in turn, contribute research findings of benefit to the health and welfare of diverse US citizenry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Scalable approaches for increasing physical activity are needed for the growing population of adults with knee replacement. This project aims to identify which supplemental non-automated intervention components added to a fully-automated online physical activity program contribute to the greatest increases in physical activity at 6 and 12 months. Based on these results, an optimized remotely delivered physical activity program will be developed for adults with knee replacement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Narrative Persons with spinal cord injury (SCI) develop diabetes more than able-bodied persons at an earlier age. Yet, the effectiveness and tolerability of recently developed anti-diabetic drugs, such as glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonists (GLP-1RAs), after SCI remains unknown, contributing to health inequity in diabetes management in this high-risk population. This project will examine the effectiveness of GLP-1R activation by 24-week administration of semaglutide on glucose tolerance, insulin action, and body lean/ fat mass in patients with SCI and diabetes subtype that manifests by severe sarcopenia and beta-cell and autonomic dysfunction in addition to exaggerated insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Small molecular drugs play a pivotal role in treating a wide range of diseases including cancer and infection, yet many of them suffer from unsatisfactory efficacy and severe side effects with current drug delivery systems. This proposal aims to develop innovative strategies to improve the biodistribution and pharmacokinetics of small molecular drugs, especially those with unfavorable physiochemical properties, ultimately offering novel tools to improve disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resistance to current AR-targeted therapies poses a significant hurdle in treating advanced prostate cancer (PCa), severely affecting clinical outcomes for patients battling this lethal disease. Our research has identified UBE2J1 as the bona fide E2 ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme regulating AR ubiquitination and revealed its frequent loss in 10-15% patients leads to dysregulated AR degradation and therapy resistance. This study seeks to elucidate the previously uncharted molecular mechanisms behind AR degradation and resistance to therapy in the context of UBE2J1-loss, with the ultimate goal of devising novel therapeutic strategies to counteract resistance and enhance patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Prenatal insults elevate risks to both maternal and offspring health. We will investigate enhanced tryptophan to kynurenine metabolism as a shared mechanism of prenatal insults in an effort to define, treat, and prevent adverse sleep and metabolism dynamics that disrupt a healthy pregnancy. The following proposal is designed to test the novel hypothesis that elevated kynurenic acid during the prenatal developmental period is causally linked to poor quality sleep and cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Feeding is crucial for survival, but dysregulation can cause disorders like obesity and anorexia; many animals, including humans, have distinct meal patterns that are tightly regulated by satiety signals; however, the specific roles of macronutrients in regulating feeding remain unclear. By using Drosophila as a model organism, this project aims to uncover the intricate molecular and neural mechanisms that underlie nutrient- specific feeding behavior. The expected mechanistic insights from this investigation will provide a valuable understanding of how the brain integrates information about specific macronutrients to regulate feeding behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) has financial incentive programs, where families enrolled in SNAP can purchase fruits and vegetables (F&V), at select sites, for half the price or less, leading to increased F&V consumption and projected savings in healthcare costs. Yet, limited awareness and uptake of SNAP F&V incentive programs presents a major barrier to widespread utilization and limits the potential impact of these existing programs. This study aims to leverage pediatric clinic settings to identify eligible families and increase awareness and utilization of SNAP F&V incentive programs by offering vouchers for an initial “free trial” and home delivery services of F&V purchased as part of this program to improve diet quality and lower long-term disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our research program is to advance spectroscopic methods capable of providing new insight into structural changes induced by protein-protein and protein-surface interactions in complex environments that impact human health. Our first research direction aims to develop methods that can be applied broadly to extract the detailed structural dynamics of protein complexes within biological media, which will be demonstrated by studying the aggregation of β-amyloid in cerebrospinal fluid to gain unprecedented insight into physiologically relevant prefibrillar structures and self-assembly pathways that may drive the pathology of Alzheimer’s Disease. Our second research direction aims to resolve the residue-level structural changes that occur when proteins interact with nanoparticle surfaces in order to understand the underlying cause of adverse responses to nanoparticle exposure, as well as design bio-nano conjugated materials with specific functionalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Supernumerary chromosomes are extra, nonessential chromosomes that are derived from the essential chromosomes. Despite their ability to negatively impact human health, many fundamental aspects regarding their formation and dynamics are understudied. The proposed research aims to use the newly established B chromosome model system in D. melanogaster to answer outstanding scientific questions about supernumerary chromosome biology, which will reveal the genetic conditions that permit them to form, how they disrupt the stability of the essential chromosomes, and what defenses the cell uses to protect against their passage to the next generation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Once the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer is made, the possibility of survival is dismal at only 12% over 5 years despite conventional therapy––making this cancer type amongst the most difficult to treat. However, it has been gleaned that early pre–cancer progresses to cancer over a decade and those at a high risk of progression can be identified by genetic testing and radiology. Here, we will test the ability of a new vaccine against a cancer driver molecule KRAS to halt cancer progression in high–risk patients by activating the immue system to detect and kill pre–malignant cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria, a disease caused by Plasmodia parasites, afflicts approximately 240 million individuals and kills up to 630,000 each year. A significant problem with fielding effective antimalarial medicines is that the malaria parasites become resistant to treatment over time, causing drugs to stop working. We are using our understanding of the mechanism of action of a new class of antimalarial drugs, the ATP4 inhibitors, to direct selection of the best medicines from other classes to combine with ATP4 inhibitors to minimize drug resistance arising and lengthen the time they can be effectively used to treat malaria.

NIH MIRA project narrative Title: Chemical labeling strategies using biomolecule-compatible, nonaqueous media The proposed research is relevant to public health because chemical labeling of proteins allows for the deeper understanding of their roles in living systems including disease states as well as the application of such labeled biomolecules for therapeutic and diagnostic applications. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The social environment has profound effects on human biology and health, but we understand little about how and why these effects vary across individuals. We will address this knowledge gap by studying variability in responses to social stimuli in prairie voles, a uniquely social animal model in which individuals differ in their genetics, neurobiology, and behavior. Because many biological features are conserved between humans and other animals, this research is likely to identify candidate genetic, molecular, cellular, and neural circuit mechanisms underlying individual differences in human health and disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human interactome, comprising over 650,000 interactions between various proteins, remains an underexplored frontier in therapeutic discovery. The significance of these interactions is highlighted by an exemplary interaction between MAGE-A4 (a melanoma protein) and RAD18 (a protein involved in DNA replication and repair), which is believed to enhance DNA damage tolerance and contribute to the resistance of cancer cells to chemotherapies. The work proposed herein aims to address fundamental questions about the design of potent macromolecule therapeutics targeting these protein-protein interactions, with anticipated outcomes including increased efficacy of chemotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Barth syndrome (BTHS) is a mitochondrial X-linked genetic disease with severe cardio/skeletal myopathy which limits the quality of life or even causes premature death. Effective BTHS therapies are lacking due to incomplete understanding of the leading pathogenic mechanism. We propose expeditious pre-clinical testing of drugs targeting an entirely new pathogenic mechanism that have not been tested as BTHS mitigators. The mechanism is based on a newly discovered role of the major biochemical process of remodeling of essential and unique mitochondrial phospholipid, cardiolipin. We established that a remodeling intermediate, monolyso- cardiolipin, forms an aberrant complex with a Fe-protein, cytochrome c, with a calamitous new pro-oxidant function of a peroxidase. The latter triggers massive and lipotoxic lipid peroxidation. We propose three new types of potent and selective inhibitors of the peroxidase as potential new treatments for BTHS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The assembly states and secondary structures of biomolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids are crucial for their functions in biological processes. My research program leverages supramolecular chemistry to design new materials and structures that can interact with and modulate how biomolecules assemble and fold. Specifically, the work proposed here will develop synthetic, supramolecular chaperones to prevent protein aggregation and establish a platform for DNA and RNA targeting based on novel bifacial nucleobases, laying the foundation for future diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) affects >10% of the US population and is characterized by chronic, recurrent abdominal pain and abnormal bowel habits that significantly impact health-related quality of life; current pharmacologic treatments, though, often fall short in delivering meaningful improvements in symptoms and are commonly limited by side effects. While cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is very effective and safe in IBS and endorsed in national guidelines, there is a paucity of CBT-trained clinicians in the US; to address this gap, we aim to conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial to collect preliminary data on the clinical impact and feasibility of a self-administered, home-based virtual reality (VR) CBT program that we developed vs. sham VR among patients with IBS. If this pilot study demonstrates that the VR CBT program is both feasible and meaningfully improves IBS symptoms, it will provide a strong platform to undertake an adequately powered, hypothesis-testing Phase II efficacy trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and other neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by age-associated neuronal loss, which involves neuroinflammation induced by reactive microglia. Our preliminary analyses from three AD cohorts and with three sequencing technologies consistently revealed an excess of clonal somatic mutations in AD brains, particularly in proliferation-related genes of microglia. We plan to test our hypothesis that the accumulation of somatic mutation contributes to an age-related increase in AD risk by driving the clonal expansion of microglia, which subsequently induces neuroinflammation and neuronal loss in AD brains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Communal living and cooperative behavior can help ensure group success, the health and well-being of adults and children, and survival of the species. Perhaps the single most important brain system for pro-social behavior and parenting is the hypothalamic oxytocin neuron population, but little is known about how oxytocin neurons respond during group interactions, including in complex outdoor environments. The experiments to be performed in this proposal provide essential data on neural activity during collective behavior of groups of mice first studied in the lab and then examined in the outdoor Stony Ford field station, including a focus on oxytocin for social hierarchy formation, foraging, burrow building, and co-parenting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Improper cell division is linked to developmental defects and cancers. A critical irreversible step in cell division is the precise positioning of the cell cleavage site to form two equal daughter cells. Here we examine how an essential mitotic kinase, which is required for proper completion of cell division, finds the cell center. Our findings will uncover fundamental mechanisms underlying error-free cell division and has the potential to uncover new therapeutic strategies for targeting cell division.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Collective migration, when cells migrate as an entire unit, is the foundation not only for successful development of many tissues but also dysregulation in collective migration is a hallmark for development abnormalities or disease progression. Our understanding of collective migration, especially the mechanics and mechanisms driving this phenomenon is very limited and thus the objective of this proposal. Our proposal will significantly accelerate our progress towards a comprehensive understanding of collective migration and lay the foundation for advancing treatment for developmental abnormalities or diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Almost every cell in an individual has the same DNA sequence yet vary greatly in the chemical modifications on DNA called epigenetics that can give rise to different cell types. Failure to regulate the epigenetic content of human cells is a hallmark of aging, cancer cells, and many human diseases. My research aims to understand how epigenetic modifications are established on the human genome and to understand how aberrant epigenetic patterns in human DNA can lead to disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Decisions of fate for an activated cell are complex processes that are tightly regulated in the human body to ensure organ functionality while safeguarding against deleterious consequences of uncontrolled cell proliferation or death. One such mechanism, namely the metabolic clock operates as a countdown to self-destruction through metabolic instability, which is initiated when a cell receives an activation signal and can only be defused by receiving secondary signals validating the initial stimulus. Our proposed studies will elucidate the mechanistic underpinnings of the metabolic clock and identify molecular targets that can be used for generating novel therapeutics against disorders stemming from errors in cell fate decision processes, including degenerative diseases, malignancies and autoimmune conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal utilizes a family-based approach to address how culturally-relevant family relationship dynamics among Latinx sexual and gender minority (SGM) adolescents and their parents inform health inequalities. A new parallel adolescent-report measure of Latinx parent acceptance will be developed to work with an existing parent- report measure of Latinx parent acceptance of their SGM adolescents; this new measure – along with other key indicators of general and SGM-specific family relationships and structural and social determinants of health will be studied as predictors of family mental health. The new dyadic tool and intersectional approach will provide novel information to develop culturally-relevant, family-based interventions to reduce health disparities among Latinx SGM adolescent populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Nuclear receptors regulate a myriad of genetic programs to control metabolism, inflammation, and development in a precise spatiotemporal manner. In this project, we seek to determine molecular mechanisms by which these multi-domain nuclear receptors act, focusing on the emerging roles of the highly disordered domains and allosteric communications between folded domains. Understanding the molecular basis of these regulation mechanisms will help to understand and treat many human disorders ranging from cardiovascular to metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Classical psychedelics such as psilocybin are being investigated as potential treatment for major depression. It is known that psilocybin can induce neural plasticity in the neocortex, however the brain region contains many different cell types and how they may interact to mediate drug action is not known. This proposal seeks to address this knowledge gap, which can provide insights into the neurobiology of psilocybin and may lead to better treatments for depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Title: Advancing computational modeling of disease metabolism by integrating AI and systems biology Project Narrative: The goal of this project is to design and implement an omics-centric framework to systematically delineate metabolic variations and their implications in complex disease, by leveraging advanced data-driven and AI- enhanced systems biology methodologies. Specifically, we will harness the power of multi-omics data to innovatively characterize metabolic landscapes, quantify metabolic shifts, mechanistically decode the impact of metabolic variations, and advance precision medicine, through novel computational tools, metrics, and a public knowledge base. This project promises transformative insights into metabolic dysregulation underpinning the complex disease pathology, which is directly relevant to the missions of NIGMS to improve fundamental principles and mechanisms underlying living organisms.
