IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The composition and function of the human microbiota is significantly influenced by access to key metal micronutrients, including iron, copper, zinc, and cobalt, because microorganisms must compete with one another for limited resources. Although mechanisms and effects of metal competition have been extensively studied in metal-limited environmental systems, how the human microbiota acquires metals through the production of metallophores, small-molecule natural products that bind metals with high affinity and selectivity, remains underexplored due to various analytical, chemical, and biological challenges. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the structure and functions of microbially-derived metallophores as modulating microbe-microbe and community interactions within human microbiomes; not only will this contribute fundamental chemical and microbiological knowledge, but can also enable targeted modulation of the microbiota and precision medicine approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Gaucher disease is a common inherited lysosomal storage disease affecting 1 in 500 in Ashkenazi Jews and 1 in 60,000 in the general population. Available enzyme treatment is adequate for the form of the disease affecting organs outside the brain, but a highly lethal central nervous system subtype, unfortunately, lacks any effective therapy, primarily because current enzyme treatments do not cross the blood-brain barrier. We have developed a therapeutic approach utilizing a more stable enzyme linked to Saposin C-based nanovesicles that can cross through the blood-brain barrier, allowing delivery of the replacement enzyme into the brain and promising an effective treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Biomolecular condensates are intracellular structures that organize cellular components into “membraneless organelles,” which play essential roles in a wide range of biological processes including gene transcription, protein translation, and cell signaling. This research program will determine the biochemical features of protein/RNA molecules that govern the molecular compositions and assembly mechanisms of biomolecular condensates, allowing us to connect changes in protein/RNA sequences to changes in membraneless compartmentalization within the complex intracellular environment. By leveraging modern simulation and machine-learning methods, our work will (1) provide vital insights into the mechanisms that cells use to control condensate assembly and composition, (2) introduce sequence design tools for engineering protein/RNA molecules to regulate condensate assembly and composition, and (3) lay the groundwork for future therapeutic strategies based on manipulating this form of intracellular spatial organization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Decades of research have strongly linked disruptions in the serotonin (5HT) system to mental health disorders such as depression, and social and communication difficulties. Microglia colonize the developing dorsal raphe nucleus (DRN) where 5HT cell bodies are localized starting as early as embryonic day (E)10 and thus are likely to shape this brain region as it develops. Our data point to microglia as a critical effector cell between maternal inflammatory signals in response to a high fat diet and subsequent neural development, which we examine in this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many patients with a heart attack or stroke do not receive high-quality care and certain patient groups (for example rural residents) are less likely to get the best care. A number of changes are taking place in the organization of the health care delivery system that may have a positive or negative impact on the delivery of heart attack and stroke care such as hospital mergers and acquisitions and hospital and emergency department openings and closures. Our goal is to understand the impact of these changes on heart attack and stroke care and whether certain patients and communities are more likely to be positively or negatively impacted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: NARRATIVE Sepsis is a rapid-developing and life-threatening condition caused by the body’s extreme reaction to an infection. Early detection of sepsis-causing agents enables precise treatment and higher chance of survival for patients, but current molecular diagnostic technologies still depend on lengthy blood culture. This MIRA project aims to develop a blood culture-independent sensing device to accurately detect sepsis-causing pathogens in about 2 hours after blood sampling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is an overlooked risk factor for chronic pain for which we have identified a novel potential target: senescent dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons induced by age and injury. In this proposal, we will validate subpopulations of senescent DRG neurons that contribute to inflammation and neuronal hyperexcitability in mouse models of chronic pain. We further extend these analyses to aged human post-mortem DRG tissues to strengthen the evidence that our target will be robust in translation, thereby opening a new therapeutic avenue for the treatment of pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Iron is integral to vital physiological functions in humans, and maintaining proper iron levels is critical due to the severe health problems that can arise from imbalances. This project will investigate the metalloproteins associated with human iron homeostasis, employing structural and spectroscopic methods to deepen understanding of their molecular mechanisms. The insights obtained could facilitate the development of innovative therapeutic approaches for various diseases, including cancer and neurodegenerative conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Heterogeneity in attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) diagnoses and among existing genomic studies poses a major challenge that has left much of the underlying genetic etiology of well-defined primary ADHD (i.e., ADHD without co-occurring intellectual disability or autism spectrum disorder) unknown. The proposed study will be the first to assess the genetic architecture of ADHD through the development a large cohort of children with primary ADHD and their families using consistent, precise, and comprehensive diagnostic criteria. Findings from our family-based study will improve our understanding of genomic architecture of ADHD, provide important genetic diagnoses for families, and inform future genomic and neurobiological functional studies that are likely to impact clinical management for families with ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Imaging specific biological processes in cells is a fundamental capability for researchers and clinicians in the disease diagnosis and monitoring of therapeutic cells. This proposal builds on the recently introduced ultrasound- based reporter genes, which may enable one to use ultrasound to follow the state of engineered cells in human patients. Specifically, the project aims to develop the next-generation genetic design of these reporters to enable order-of-magnitude increase of the brightness of their ultrasound signals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial infection continues to be a major global health threat that has been exacerbated by the emergence and unabated spread of antimicrobial-resistance. The goal of this proposal is to develop a new rapid identification and antimicrobial susceptibility testing platform for clinical isolates utilizing an exclusive liquid repellency-based under- oil open microfluidic system to ensure 1) prompt coverage of infecting organisms and 2) prevention of overuse of broad-spectrum antimicrobials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Animal models of oxygen-induced retinopathy (OIR) have provided the foundation for our understanding of molecular responses to ischemic injury in the retina and the pathophysiology of ischemic retinal vascular diseases such as diabetic retinopathy and retinopathy of prematurity. Visible-light optical coherence tomography (vis-OCT) is a newer imaging technology that provides both retinal structure and blood vessel patterns and direct measures of retinal vascular oxygen levels in animal models of disease. In this study, we will develop a new wide-field (WF)-vis-OCT to establish normative data for longitudinal changes in tissue oxygenation and blood flow in the rat OIR model, and in vivo assessment of nonperfusion and neovascularization, with comparison to the traditional ex vivo OIR biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Small organic molecules and nucleic acid polymers are essential to developing next-generation therapeutics. Existing small molecules that can target RNA are limited by their selectivity and efficacy, and nucleic acid therapies are challenged by their off-target effects and suboptimal biostabilities. In this MIRA application, we propose to address these limitations and challenges by developing small molecule-based RNA degraders with high selectivity and efficacy, and biostable and programmable nucleic acid polymers with advanced therapeutic capabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This is the first effectiveness test of a highly portable home-based exercise intervention after an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD), delivered using the expertise of cardiac rehabilitation staff using technology monitoring (Step Watch, Polar HR Monitor) of intervention progress and outcomes. Evidence for intervention effectiveness and implementation feasibility will lay a strong foundation that provides patients and clinicians the tools to initiate and monitor exercise for a broad spectrum of ICD recipients, and identifies protocols and training that will promote high fidelity implementation in subsequent trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gut microbial ene-reductases mediate critical biotransformations impacting both microbial and host physiology. Stool metabolomics data implicates the existence of numerous unidentified ene-reductases, constituting a gap in our understanding of gut microbial metabolism. The proposed research will develop a platform combining microbiology, biochemistry, and bioinformatics to systematically identify novel gut microbial ene-reductases, elucidating their genetic basis, their impact on microbial physiology, and illuminating ways they may interact with host physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative Vocalization is used in many species for social and emotional communications. Here we will not only identify the hitherto unknown cell types and circuits that trigger emotional cries but also reveal precise neurons and mechanisms underlying vocal-respiration coordination. Our study will provide foundational knowledge for finding potential treatment targets for disorders of motor speech productions, and other diseases involving vocal cord dysfunction such as dysphagia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precision medicine approaches are urgently needed to improve self-management support for adults with type 2 diabetes. Our innovative validated typology of diabetes-specific family functioning will be applied to get the right intervention to the right person at the right time. In a randomized controlled trial, we will evaluate the benefits of an adaptive intervention - tailored over time using typology assessments and delivered via basic mobile phone technology - on participants' hemoglobin A1c, diabetes distress and global well-being.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of autism and symptoms of autism typically emerge during early infancy, a time when the neocortex undergoes extensive synaptogenesis and synapse elimination, so-called transient connectivity. Using multi-facetted approaches, including electrophysiology, single-cell transcriptomics and CRISPR strategy, we will investigate the role of sensory and neuromodulatory transient connections in the development of healthy and FXS cortical maturation. This work will provide novel insights into the role of transient connectivity on sensory and cognitive experience-dependent cortical maturation and lay the foundations for exploring approaches targeting the onset of circuit dysfunctions in FXS.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Emergency Medical Services (EMS) 2050 Agenda for Future Systems envisions integration of telehealth tools to make prehospital care safer and more effective, so we need to demonstrate whether this technology can improve patient safety. This study tests the efficacy of using low-cost, mobile technology for infants and children who need life-saving care outside hospitals in two ways—(1) using pediatric experts in hospitals to support EMS clinicians in ambulances by video, and (2) reviewing video recorded EMS encounters as a method to measure care safety and quality. If this strategy produces measurably safer care with real EMS- physician teams in realistic simulated environments, it will provide the scientific basis for EMS systems to adopt and use telehealth tools to improve care for children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The influence of tissue mechanics on cell behavior has been widely acknowledged, especially in the contexts of wound healing, disease advancement, and regenerative medicine, however, there is a critical shortage of materials that can effectively elucidate the intricate relationship between tissue mechanics and cellular responses. In this proposal, our primary goal is to enhance the applicability of hydrogel biomaterials by harnessing clinically approved plasmid deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) to create materials that emulate the properties of living tissues. This approach will allow us to integrate unique structural and functional attributes inspired by the versatile and dynamic characteristics of DNA enabling fundamental understanding of cell- environment homeostasis research and facilitating transition into clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of this research project is to understand the neural mechanisms underlying the control of behavior in two domains: self-control (motivation) and response inhibition (motor). We will record neurons from 5 different areas in the prefrontal cortex, while NHPs engage in two oculomotor decision tasks that require them to exert self-control and motor-control, respectively. This will allow us to determine the functional overlap and separation between these control systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this project is to develop a robust multi-modal platform for remote monitoring of speech, psychomotor and cognitive function in Frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) syndromes - focusing initially on Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP, a rapidly progressing FTLD syndrome), and later extending to Corticobasal syndrome and Frontotemporal dementia. In this Direct Phase II project, we will use wearable sensors and computerized speech, psychomotor, and cognitive assessments to create outcome measures and digital biomarkers for FTLD syndromes and will use the solution to monitor 60 PSP patients for 12 months. The developed tools will facilitate clinical trials that are focused on novel therapeutics for tau-related diseases and can be readily adapted to other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will create a computational framework capable of describing and estimating the time-dynamic adaptation of biological systems that occur in variable environments using imputed data sampled over multiple time points. We will apply our developed model to study the adaptation strategies utilized by SARS-CoV-2 and leukemia to evade targeting by the immune system. This project will contribute to our fundamental knowledge on the adaptation strategies that are utilized by biological systems in navigating dynamical environments, which is directly useful for better understanding treatment failure in many medical contexts such as infectious diseases and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Antimicrobial cyclic and lasso peptide natural products motivate the development of chemical strategies and novel reactions to prepare protease-resistant scaffolds for use in drug discovery. In the short term, this research will develop peptide cyclization methods to access constrained antimicrobial peptides that combat multidrug resistant bacteria. Longer term, we will use reversible peptide chemistry and computational tools to design folded lasso peptides with the goal to enable their use as customizable frameworks for addressing unmet therapeutic challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The PI will address three significant challenges in biomechanics: the lack of a versatile technique for quantifying multiscale cell mechanics, the absence of high-precision, real-time force measurement tools at the nanoscale, and challenges in measuring in vivo dynamic mechanical regulations. This MIRA program will establish a pioneering analytical platform for biomechanics, from building a comprehensive library of Molecular Force Gauges (MFGs), integrating MFGs into various biological targets for precise biomechanical measurements, to developing a state-of-the-art super-resolution biomechanical microscopy, BM-STORM, to visualize cellular and subcellular biomechanics with unprecedented detail. Our long-term vision is to advance biomechanics for in vivo biomechanical testing, three-dimensional biomechanical mapping, and deep-tissue biomechanical monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposed strategy utilizes both ontology and NLP methods to streamline ADRD-related BSSR data standardization and integration. By establishing a shared ontological framework and employing NLP for information extraction, we aim to foster interdisciplinary collaboration among researchers from diverse fields, facilitating a more comprehensive understanding of ADRD and its behavioral and social aspects. This integrated approach improves data quality, accessibility, and the ability to uncover insights critical to ADRD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the PsycheMERGE Network is to advance equitable precision psychiatry in learning healthcare system frameworks across the United States. During the course of this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators at twelve academic medical centers will bring together clinical data (>29 million individuals), genetic data (>1.9 million), and an extraordinary range of scientific expertise (psychiatry, medical informatics, machine learning, statistics, genetics, sociomedical sciences, decision sciences, and ethics) to advance this mission. We will leverage this expertise and data to build on our prior success and address barriers to scalability, utility of genomic data, clinical application, and translation to clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Ischemic stroke is a leading cause of death and disability worldwide. New therapeutic approaches to stroke prevention are needed to reduce its growing public health burden. By combining proteomics and genomics methods in two high-risk populations, the goal of this proposal is to identify plasma proteins that are likely to be etiologic factors for ischemic stroke, and thus potential treatment targets for its prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative During embryogenesis, cells orient their behaviors along a tissue or body axis to drive essential processes such as neural tube closure and axis elongation. The highly conserved Planar Cell Polarity pathway allows cells to coordinate directional information between neighbors but the ‘directional cues’ that function upstream of the pathway to link it to a tissue axis remain unknown. Utilizing the mammalian skin as a model system, this research aims to overcome challenges in identifying and characterizing directional cues to yield fundamental insight into the mechanisms that organize cells across great distances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Microtubule networks in neurons are coated in an array of microtubule associated proteins (MAPs) which regulate microtubule stability, spacing, and motor protein binding, but the mechanisms governing their formation into distinct patterns for efficient cargo transport remain unclear. The proposed experiments aim to use human neurons to elucidate the establishment of MAP pattern and their impact on microtubule modifications and intracellular transport. Given the large number of neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative disorders linked to MAP or tubulin PTM disfunction, this project will provide insights into understanding disease mechanism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will investigate biomolecular aspects of thiyl radical formation, chemistry, and reduction relevant to the fidelity of thiyl radical enzymes and their non‐specific reactivity. These studies will employ a variety of techniques and investigate thiyl radicals in a number of distinct contexts, broadening the impact of the findings. Ultimately, outcomes of the proposed work will inform rational therapeutic design, open the door for thiyl radical biocatalysis engineering, and strategic approaches to intercept reactive sulfur species involved in oxidative stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE Despite being a key step in the central dogma of biology, there are major gaps in our knowledge of the dynamics and downstream effects of the interaction between codons and tRNAs. This project explores the evolutionary and cellular consequences of codon biases and tRNA fluctuations. The findings of this work are critical to the construction of evolutionary models and our understanding of cellular regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: NARRATIVE Alternative splicing is coupled with nonsense-mediated mRNA decay (AS-NMD) to regulate gene expression. AS-NMD is often fine-tuned in a tissue-specific manner and frequently dysregulated in diseases, including neurological disorders, cardiac myopathies, diabetes, lupus, and different malignancies. Here, we will elucidate molecular mechanisms and therapeutic strategies targeting AS-NMD errors in specific diseases.

PHR: Project Narrative Environmental enrichment demonstrates promise as a therapeutic tool for excessive alcohol use in animal models. However, studying the effects of environmental enrichment in humans has been difficult. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Based on strong preliminary data we propose that the transcription factor ThPOK serves as a critical transcriptional checkpoint for neutrophil commitment in granulocyte lineage-specified cells and thereby enforces a set point for granulocyte lineage output. Here we will dissect the upstream pathways that control ThPOK induction during myelopoiesis, the modus operandi by which ThPOK controls transcription, and its importance for emergency myelopoiesis. Completion of these studies will provide critical insights into the contribution of ThPOK to homeostatic and emergency myelopoiesis and provide a conceptual basis for the future design of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of neutropenia, sepsis, and Myeloproliferative Disorder through targeting of ThPOK and its associated pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of metabolites in the human body remain unknown, yet these metabolites may play a critical role in important biological mechanisms such as disease pathogenesis. This proposal uses a strategy called reverse metabolomics, which combines organic synthesis, mass spectrometry and public data mining for the high-throughput characterization of small molecules in humans. Ultimately, this approach offers insight into new disease biomarkers, druggable pathways and bioactive small molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Complementary medicine (CM) interventions are increasingly used by health care consumers and accepted by the medical community, although much remains poorly understood about their effectiveness and safety as well as the underlying biological mechanisms through which they affect health and well-being. Published literature is a growing source of evidence on CM approaches; however, much of this evidence remains in unstructured text in specialty journals, creating barriers for effectively integrating the evidence with conventional medicine. The proposed research will develop informatics resources (ontology, knowledge graphs) and literature mining tools to consolidate the high-quality evidence on CM approaches and integrate it with conventional medicine in a machine-readable and AI-ready form, and will demonstrate the utility of these resources for knowledge management and scientific discovery in complementary and integrative health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In Bangladesh and other low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) antibiotics are readily used to treat acute lower respiratory infections even though most are caused by viruses. Novel tools for diagnosing pediatric respiratory diseases that are feasible for application in LMICs are desperately needed to safely improve outcomes while strengthening antibiotic stewardship. The BLAAST Project plans to conduct a randomized, double-blinded, placebo, non-inferiority trial of pediatric care enhanced by a novel automated digital stethoscope, compared to standard care, in Bangladesh (Aim 1) with an integrated implementation assessment (Aim 2) and economic evaluation (Aim 3) over a period of three years among low-risk children with IMCI-defined pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteria communicate through molecules on their surface, called glycans, which can help them invade our bodies. Our research investigates these molecules and how they interact, using advanced computational techniques. In doing so, our goal is to advance our knowledge of bacterial glycan behavior, leading to new ways to enhance health and prevent infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the volume of human genome sequencing data continues to grow, most sequence variants identified are of unknown biological significance, thus our ability to leverage these data for the improvement of human health is limited by variant interpretation challenges. We have developed novel bioinformatic tools to interrogate human sequencing data and deployed these tools to discover rare and putatively deleterious variants in genes involved in inflammation. In this project, we will use in-depth molecular and cellular assays to decipher the functional impacts of these novel variants, and in addition, we will use a DNA biobank linked to electronic health records to uncover new genotype-phenotype relationships at a population scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Internal ribosome entry sites (IRESs) are structured RNAs essential for translation of viral mRNAs and for translation of circular mRNAs—a promising new class of mRNA therapeutics with applications ranging from cancer immunotherapy to genome editing. This proposal will investigate how IRESs initiate translation and build potent IRES-based expression technologies. These studies will inform the treatment and prevention of viral infectious diseases and advance circular-mRNA technologies for research and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women at high risk of breast cancer have opportunities for breast cancer risk reduction, including risk-reducing medications and more intensive breast cancer screening. The goal of this proposal is to determine whether new Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies can accurately identify women at high risk of breast cancer who may benefit from risk reduction. The project will draw on a large, diverse group of women undergoing routine mammography screening across the United States to ensure that these new AI technologies perform equally well in women of all race and ethnicity groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Intestinal mucus serves as a nutrient source and signaling molecule for microbes residing in the gut. Our understanding of the impact of mucus on the composition and function of gut bacteria, as well as the reciprocal regulation of goblet cells by microbes, is still in its early stages. This proposal has the potential to advance our comprehension of bacterial ecology and the interactions between bacteria and their host, offering exciting prospects for further exploration in this field.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gut microbiome contributes to interindividual variability in drug responses, including efficacy and toxicity. By studying bacterial drug metabolism, we will develop strategies to predict and prevent drug-induced injury and reduce medication side effects, thus promoting public health. This research program will utilize samples from individuals of diverse races and ethnicities often understudied in biomedical research to understand how the microbiome alters drug response, thereby delivering on the promise of precision medicine for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative  PRMT5 is a therapeutic target in cancer and neurodegenerative disease; however, why cells require arginine methylation by PRMT5 for survival remains largely unresolved. The following research proposal will comprehensively dissect the role of the essential methyltransferase PRMT5. In the present work, we will discern which PRMT5 methyl substrates are required for cell survival in disease and normal settings, and how arginine methyl events impact substrate protein function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Both soluble and bound ligands play pivotal roles in regulating cell behavior and function, particularly in tissue vascularization and chronic wound healing. This proposal aims to pioneer innovative methods to fabricate multi-structured, heterogenous angiogenic hydrogels with variable ligand binding affinities as a platform to better understand how combined structural and biochemical cues orchestrate cell signaling, and to harness these insights for enhanced vasculature. Outcomes from the proposed research will elucidate differential signaling impacts and mechanisms for binding growth factors and adhesive ligands covalently and noncovalently, offering accelerated vascularization strategies for therapeutic wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The natural wound microenvironment and the biomaterials implanted to support its healing present complex biophysical and biochemical properties that must be navigated by invading endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and mesenchymal stromal cells during tissue repair. Hydrogels with tailorable properties like the one we propose to use allow the controlled culture of relevant cells in biomimetic environments allowing fundamental insights into cell behavior and their sensitivity to microenvironmental features. Our proposed projects will advance the basic understanding of endothelial cell invasion leading to angiogenesis, fibroblast activation leading to fibrotic scarring, and stromal cell paracrine signaling in wound-mimicking environments, ultimately enabling the discovery of broadly applicable tissue regenerative therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Mutations that impact the processing of miRNAs cause different genetic syndromes, including the bone marrow failure syndrome poikiloderma with neutropenia, where patients have mutations in the 3' - end miRNA deandenylase USB 1. In this proposal our goal is to understand the molecular mechanisms leading to hematopoietic failure in settings of altered miRNA processing, and find mechanisms to restore blood development in patients. We will use a unique combination of molecular and cellular tools that will significantly increase current knowledge on miRNA stability and function in blood cells that are deficient in patients with mutant USB 1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) remains a leading cause of childhood morbidity and mortality, and a full understanding of how this disease develops is lacking. In this study, we will integrate genetic epidemiology with innovative functional genomic approaches to determine the mechanisms through which germline genetic risk variants associated with B-ALL can impact B cell development and leukemogenic processes. Our unique approach will reveal novel insights into the etiology of B-ALL and may inform targeted therapeutic and preventive strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Transcription factor (TF) networks access, decode and implement genomic information to provide a differentiated cell with its identity as well as the plasticity to respond to incoming signals (such as environmental and developmental cues). In some instances, incoming signals can destabilize TF network function and force the cell into a dysfunctional state known as senescence, which promotes disease across multiple tissues. In this proposal, we will harness the power of time-resolved multiomic profiling to define and manipulate the TF networks of cells transitioning through senescence states linked to disease as a novel approach to restore cell function and to develop diagnostic/prognostic tools for disease monitoring, potentially paving the way for a new era of epigenomic medicine.

PROJECT_TITLE: Transcription Factor Network-Mediated Modulation of Transitional Senescence States

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will open avenues to translate novel intervention strategies using IND precursors and ELVs to protect the ischemic stroke penumbra. The results will move the field of stroke research and other neurological diseases forward and pave the way to a therapeutic neuroprotection paradigm shift away from just blocking neuroinflammation, as is often the case. Ultimately, the new knowledge will improve the quality of life of young and older individuals of both genders after ischemic stroke, which remains among the most significant challenges to public health.

PHR: The risk and burden of stroke are disparately experienced by Black, Latino/a/x, and low-income people. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Elucidating Context-Specific FERONIA Receptor Kinase Signaling Project Narrative The proposed studies will provide unprecedent new insights into how FER receptor kinase achieves signaling specificity. Receptor kinases signaling pathways play critical roles in diverse cellular processes and deregulation of the pathways leads to serious human diseases such as cancer. Understanding the pathway specificity has been a major area of study in developing effective therapies. Better understanding cell signaling specificity of FER receptor kinase can help shed light on receptor kinase signaling pathways related to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Translational approaches to unravel organ-specific microvascular endothelial responses in sepsis. NARRATIVE: My laboratory is focused on understanding how injury to blood vessel cells contributes to organ damage in children with sepsis –a life-threatening condition caused by an infection. By detailed study of free-floating blood vessel cells and by treating miniature blood vessel organs in petri dishes with plasma collected from children with sepsis, we seek to identify genes that lead to organ damage. Our studies may lead to the discovery of medicines that can help recover from organ damage and help save the lives of very sick children with sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polyelectrolyte complex micelles (PCMs) are attractive as a nucleic acid delivery system, but the design parameters that control key aspects of delivery are not yet defined, preventing PCM technology from being easily adapted for new targets. The goal of this proposal, and of our research lab, is to develop quantitative design rules that govern nucleic acid PCM assembly, physical properties, delivery capabilities, and dynamic behavior. Developing a comprehensive and quantitative understanding of the parameters that control nucleic acid PCM assembly, distribution, and delivery will build a foundation for a new class of PCMs with predictive properties that can be tailored for specific treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Despite being traditionally studied in simplified experimental systems, human pathogens experience complex environmental dynamics during infection. Here, I propose to use microfluidics to study how shear flow impacts H2O2 stress responses and surface adhesion of the human pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa. By providing mechanistic insight into bacterial processes in dynamic host-relevant environments, our work will lay a solid foundation for innovative advances in the treatment of bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we aim to uncover the evolutionary processes and regulatory mechanisms by which Y chromosomes generate diversity within the sexes. To accomplish this, we will leverage the unique power of the Poecilia parae system, in which male morphs (that differ in size, color, and behavior) are inherited perfectly through highly diverged Y chromosomes. This work has direct implications on our understanding of how gene regulation and developmental processes encoded by Y chromosomes generate diversity within the sexes of the same population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Intrinsic molecular circadian rhythms in adipose tissue control metabolic processes that are dysregulated in people with specific types of obesity, however, these same functions are highly responsive to intermittent food intake over the day. As such, these studies will determine the relative contribution of adipose tissue intrinsic circadian rhythms and intermittent meal delivery on molecular and systemic adipose tissue function in humans in the context of obesity. By better understanding the relationship between these processes we can develop new treatments for people with obesity and those with regular disruptions in circadian rhythms such as shift workers, who have increased risk of obesity and Type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Mechanistic details pertinent to heme enzymatic pathways that interconvert nitrogen oxides are cornerstones to a variety of pathogenic situations in humans, and yet they continue to be faintly understood. The central goal of this project is to unveil detailed insights into these reaction landscapes using meticulously designed synthetic model systems that closely mimic those reactivities. Outcome of this work will therefore directly benefit the understanding of the origination and progression of a medley of disease conditions, and will contribute toward escalating the effectivity and precision of next generation therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Controlling the properties of biomedical interfaces is critical for studying, diagnosing, and treating disease. This research program aims to develop a versatile platform based on interfacial protein self-assembly for increasing the functionality of biomedical and biological surfaces. Proof-of-concept projects explored in the proposed work include enhancing nerve tissue repair using coatings with temporally orchestrated growth factor release, improving the long-term performance of biosensors, and engineering live cell surfaces to control cell fate in therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding the multifunctional roles of proteins is essential for designing therapeutic strategies to treat genetic causes of disease, yet our knowledge of these secondary roles for many proteins remains incomplete. We will elucidate the multifunctional roles of a protein involved in cancer, microcephaly, and infertility, while also using our expertise in high resolution 3D X-Ray imaging and artificial intelligence to establish an experimental workflow that will accelerate the discovery of multifunctional protein roles in model organisms such as Drosophila melanogaster and Xenopus laevis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress is a key driver of several chronic diseases, with toxic exposures resulting in elevated mortality across all ages. When stressed, mammalian cells invoke counter measures that are crucial for their survival and restoration of homeostasis, while aberrations in these stress response programs are hallmarks of ageing, degenerative pathologies, and cancer. The proposed research investigates transcriptional responses to environmental stress, which has broad implications in understanding the basis of organismal resilience and unraveling new disease mechanisms, diagnostics, and therapeutics for a range of stress-associated pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R01 project is a multi-site clinical trial of transcranial magnetic stimulation-electroencephalography (TMS- EEG), whose goal is to determine whether TMS-EEG measurements of brain complexity detect and predict recovery of consciousness in critically ill patients with acute severe brain injuries. The clinical motivation for this trial is that TMS-EEG measurements of brain complexity have the potential to improve the accuracy of diagnosis and prognosis in the intensive care unit, thereby informing decisions about life-sustaining therapy for patients with severe brain injuries. We will also use functional MRI and EEG in this project to provide mechanistic insights into the brain network connectivity properties that underly TMS-EEG measurements of brain complexity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Modeling of cell-specific LRP1 signaling in acute myocardial infarction The American Heart Association estimates that every 42 seconds an American will have an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), and despite the improvement in treatment and prognosis, a significant number of patients continue to die and AMI survivors remain at high risk of developing heart failure (HF). Low-density lipoprotein receptor related protein-1 (LRP1) is a membrane receptor known as a scavenger for the serine protease inhibitors (SERPINs) that also possesses anti-inflammatory and pro-survival signals in cultures cardiomyocytes and proliferative signals in fibroblasts. We propose that using modeling to define the differential signaling pathways of LRP1 in cardiomyocytes and cardiac fibroblasts may open the way to novel therapeutic strategies targeting LRP1 in AMI, heart failure, and other related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The program aims to develop novel intravital two-photon microscopy techniques with scattering correction for deep tissue imaging. By jointly developing optical hardware and computational software, the proposed techniques will correct dynamic tissue scattering with high-speed, high-efficiency light modulation. This program will offer a timely and reliable solution for imaging intact tissues and organs, catalyzing a broad range of fundamental biological research, including the imaging of nervous systems, immune responses, embryo development, and cancer metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The PI3K signaling pathway is one of, if not the most, commonly activated pathways in human cancers. Although a small number of FDA approved PI3K inhibitors have reached the market in recent years, there remains a pressing need for more potent and selective therapeutics and chemical tools. This project will use a combination of evolutionally and biosynthetic considerations to prepare a large family of natural product-derived anticancer drug-leads/chemical probes, which have the potential to significantly bolster our arsenal of available cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA interference (RNAi) is a highly conserved mechanism of regulation that silences a wide range of targets in a precise, temporal, and cell-specific manner to ensure proper execution of many essential cellular and physiological processes; yet we know almost nothing about how RNAi pathways are regulated in any organism. Defects in RNAi cause devastating gene mis-regulation and allows de-repressed transposons to wreak havoc on the genome, resulting in the onset of cancers, infertility, neurodegenerative disorders, and many other diseases; therefore, it is critical we gain a mechanistic knowledge of how balancing between the interdependent RNAi pathways is maintained, and how RNAi homeostasis is impacted by real-world stresses, to advance our understanding of small RNAs in human health and disease. Work from this proposal will provide the foundation for our mechanistic understanding of the higher order interactions between RNAi pathways that ensure cellular homeostasis and will be of key importance in determining the underlying causes of RNAi-mediated disease states and identifying potential therapeutic targets, in line with the NIH mission to reduce the burden of human illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The three-dimensional (3D) genome folding organization within the nucleus plays a key role in epigenomic regulation but whether and how changes in the 3D organization of cancer genomes drive tumorigenesis is not well understood. In this proposal, we aim to elucidate the functional importance and regulation of 3D genome alterations during lung adenocarcinoma progression in vivo. Study results may establish in situ 3D genomics as a new tissue-based modality for diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic biomarker development in cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Limited access to life-saving albuterol sulfate for respiratory distress impacts school children's health and education. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Gene expression is mediated by the activity of non-coding cis-regulatory elements, enhancers and repressors, that control the spatial and temporal context and level of transcription. Work in vertebrates has identified a causal relationship between the 3D folding of the genome into discrete territories and the control of gene regulation – disruption of 3D architecture results in aberrant gene regulation leading to dysgenesis and cancer. Using comparative and functional approaches, this project will investigate when 3D structures including TADs and factories emerged in animals and the role that 3D architecture plays in the establishment of cell fate, the progression of development, and, over evolutionary timescales, the generation of novel phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Traumatic stress disproportionately impacts the biopsychosocial health of Black women experiencing homelessness (WEH), yet few models of trauma-focused care are tailored or accessible to this growing population. In partnership with two women’s homelessness organizations, we will conduct a randomized controlled trial of our co-adapted trauma-focused intervention—NurseNET—to determine its effects in treating PTSD, co-occurring symptoms, and improving SDoH outcomes in Black WEH. In so doing, we will generate the evidence necessary to scale a nurse-led model of care to mitigate the trauma burden faced by Black WEH and other disinvested populations, towards reducing health inequities in trauma-affected communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer patients positive for human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 are at a high risk of relapse with brain metastasis, months to years after the initial disease diagnosis and primary therapy. Proposed study will identify and characterize the tumor and host specific alterations that promote metachronous brain metastasis and assess the impact of AXL inhibitor in limiting tumor cell survival and reactivating NK mediated innate immune surveillance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. The proposed project is relevant to public health because it focuses on identifying precisely how the gut microbiome contributes to the onset of Parkinson’s disease. This work is a critical next step toward developing new and needed therapeutics that target gut processes to prevent and treat this disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.
